NOTES: Around 1 January 2018 (beginning of month), a female petitioner from Heze, Shandong was suspected of pharmacological torture during her sentence at Jinan Female Prison (Jinan, Shandong) when the prison informed her family around 17 Jan that she would be transferred for hospital treatment due to the deterioration of her health. It was reported that she developed respiratory and cardiovascular diseases after serving her sentence in prison, but her illness became more severe since her daughter last visited around 17 December 2017.

On 1 January 2018, a Kazakh poet and author was taken away by the local authorities at his home in Yining City (Ili, Xinjiang). His whereabouts and circumstances remained unknown at the time of reporting on 6 March 2018. Previously, he was sent to the ''deradicalisation training centre'' twice by the local authorities in 2017 for writing a book on the Kazakh independence movement before the Russian October Revolution.

Around 1 January 2018 (as reported), a Kazakh woman was taken away by police in Emin county (Tacheng, Xinjiang) and sent to a re-education camp for having dual citizenship. She had returned to China on 25 December 2017 for medical treatment but was questioned by local police soon after her arrival. She was reportedly released 38 days later. She was taken to a re-education camp a second time on 25 February but was briefly released on 9 March 2018 for medial treatment. On 26 June 2018, she was moved to yet another camp. She was finally released on 21 November 2018 and reportedly returned to Kazakhstan in early 2019.

On 4 January 2018, a Uyghur teacher was arrested after returning to China (coded to her home address in Tianshan, Urumqi, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado for assembling a crowd to disturb social order. She had returned from a 6 month stay in the US. In August 2019, she was released briefly and allowed to see her family, who reported that she was receiving 'education' and would 'finish school' very soon, presumably referring to a re-education camp. On 15 September 2019, the family received news that she had been released but was still under house arrest, and they were able to speak to her by phone with police supervision. The family remained in contact with her until 25 December 2019.

On 5 January 2018, the Party Committee Secretary of Nantai village of Jinxian county (Nanchang, Jiangxi) was stabbed and killed in his office by a sanitation worker who had been laid off by the town government. The sanitation worker used a fruit knife, and was arrested afterwards. His motive was not revealed by enforcement authorities.

Around 6 January 2018 (between 3-10 January), a Uyghur female student disappeared after returning to Yili (Ili, Xinjiang) in the midst of studying abroad for her master's degree. An ongoing government campaign targeted Uyghur families with members living abroad, and police authorities had previously threatened to send her father to prison if she did not return home after university graduation.

On 6 January 2018, a female Falun Gong practitioner-cum-kindergarten teacher was transferred to the Qiaokou District Legal Education Center on the last day of her detention period at No.1 Detention Centre in Wuhan (Hubei). She was first taken away and detained on 26 December 2017 while preaching about Falun Gong on Shuiguohu Street. It was allegedly possible that she would be subject to re-education efforts and solitary confinement at this Legal Education Center (Legal Education Centres are also referred to by some, including Falun Gong practitioners, as ''brainwashing centres'' and are regarded as ''black Jails'' by some victims). It was alleged that 12 Faun Gong practitioners had been tortured to death at this center.

On 6 January 2018, a disability activist and two petitioners from Binzhou, Shandong were taken away by interceptors from the government while they were calling for the legislation of harmful vaccines outside the Beijing Municipal Health Commission in Xicheng district (Beijing). Two of the petitioners were beaten up in a car by triad members hired by the interceptors.

Around 8 January 2018, a group of ''stability maintenance thugs'' rushed into a resident's home, and locked the family. They threaten the family to agree with demolishing the home for a real estate project. And recently they started to beat the husband and force him to sign the paper. No fatalities were reported.

On 9 January 2018, a Hong Kong pro-democracy activist and legislative by-election hopeful, who is also one of the Umbrella Movement leaders facing trial, was attacked by two unknown men in Hong Kong. According to Hong Kong police, the attack was politically motivated, since the activist received a threatening letter in the same day.

Around 10 January 2018 (between 10 - 11 January), a Uyghur woman (who had returned from Kazakhstan to China four months ago to sell her apartment) was arrested by the authorities in Qinggil County, Altay Prefecture (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang) and detained in a re-education camp for nine months. She had previously returned to China on 12 September 2017 but had her documents confiscated upon arrival. She was later released from the camp around September or October 2018 as she had to be rushed to the hospital for an operation. Following the operation, she was released to stay with her mother, while remaining under house arrest. According to her detention slip, she was detained for investigation because she had been 'classified as belonging to other untrustworthy people who may influence stability'.

Around 11 January 2018 (month of), a petitioner was physically assaulted during his detention at the police station in Shenyang prefecture (Liaoning). He was sent to a relief centre at Hongqiao Hospital for medical attention and was barely able to speak on 11 Jan. He died on 12 Jan. Family members were denied his certificate of death. The petitioner had initially been detained by authorities around 17 September 2017, to ''prepare'' for the National Congress of the CCP, and he had not been heard from since, until 11 January 2018.

On 11 January 2018, the husband of a disabled Falun Gong practitioner was abducted by police officers from Zhashui county (Shangluo, Shaanxi), and his whereabouts and reasons for disappearance were not reported as of 19 Jan. His wife was previously captured from their home on 11 Oct 2017 by over 40 police officers who wore helmets and were fully armed with guns and bullets. They sealed and raided the house, confiscating a computer, printer, satellite equipment and bank cards. She was illegally detained and denied lawyer visitation since.

On 11 January 2018, the son and daughter - at least one of them a Buddhist believer - of an arrested female Falun Gong believer were beaten by five six officers at a police station in Hutai town of Xinmin county (Shenyang, Liaoning), and again when they were restrained and interrogated by the police at one of their houses. During the interrogation, the police tortured them with further beatings, suffocation, and forcing them to kneel or squat on a cold floor. They threatened to soak the son in water then leave him in the cold. The daughter's limbs were numb by the end. Their original intention of visiting the police station was to report that their mother had gone missing after a trip to the market.

On 11 January 2018, villagers were assaulted and arrested during a forced eviction operation in Yunqiao village, Dabanqiao sub-district of Guandu district (Kunming, Yunnan) led by as many as 1500 well-equipped chengguan police force members (equipped with shields, helmets and batons) and special police forces who were followed by a dozen ambulances, excavators and police cars. The police were reported to be the main perpetrator, rounding up villagers and beating them up. A dozen villagers suffered injuries with two receiving treatment at major hospitals and around 12-13 at the community hospital. Around 7-8 villagers were arrested with two released on bail.

Around 12 January 2018 (from 11 - 13 January), a female Falun Gong practitioner was beaten, during which her face and hands were targeted, during a three-day detention at the police station in Hutai town (Xinmin, Liaoning).

On 12 January 2018, a dozen villagers were kicked and beaten during a forced land collectivisation operation in Pingle village, Yudong subdistrict of Liangqing district (Nanning, Guangxi) by around 100 people wearing police uniforms. The villagers called for compromise and negotiation between both sides before property developers resumed their work. 6 villagers were injured, and all of them were sent to the police station.

On 12 January 2018, about six national security officers forcibly abducted a human rights activist to the local police station in Mudu Town (Suzhou, Jiangsu) without providing any legal official documents. She was also beaten by those officers during detention.

On 13 January 2018, 14 Christian missionaries, including a pastor, were taken into custody by the local authorities from a house church in Wenzhou City, Zhejiang Province. Their whereabouts and circumstances remained unknown at the time of reporting on 31 January 2018. On 13 January 2018, the Wenzhou government executed the planned crackdown on the house churches of Wenzhou Diocese for the reason that this branch engaged in the missionary mission in the Middle East.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps
NOTES: On 14 January 2018, the brother-in-law of a human rights defender was taken away by a group of people from the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps (XPCC) of Zhaosu County (Ili, Xinjiang) and is suspected to have been kidnapped. The people from the XPCC had been standing guard outside the human rights defender's home with police cars and cut off the water and power supply over the last 2 days.

On 14 January 2018, a petitioner-cum-forced evictee from Taohe village, Weiji town of Suining county (Xuzhou, Jiangsu) was forced into a vehicle by eight thugs after he petitioned at the State Bureau of Letters and Calls in Xicheng district (Beijing). He was punched ''viciously'' while they wore iron knuckles on their hands, until he knelt on the highway and ''begged for mercy.'' They took all his belongings, and sent a coerced video statement to the State Bureau of him promising never to petition again. The man had been targeted by demolition authorities and police forces since reporting the Taohe Village Party Secretary for corruption twice in 2016.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); Teachers (China); Muslim Group (China)
NOTES: Around 16 January 2018 (month of), 4 Uyghur literature professors from Xinjiang University were arrested by the authorities in Urumqi city (Xinjiang) (coded as Shuimogou) and detained in re-education camps. It's reported that authorities in the region began jailing and detaining Uyghurs accused of harbouring ''strong religious views'' and ''politically incorrect'' ideas since April 2017. At least two of them were reportedly released in May 2019.

Around 16 January 2018 (month of), a Uyghur woman from Qiemo County (Bayingolin, Xinjiang) was taken away by the local authorities from her hometown. She was taken to a hospital for a medical examination before she was detained at a re-education camp for three months and was released on 5 April 2018. This was her third detention since she returned from Cairo, Egypt to China in 2015. The official reason for her detention was for inciting ethnic hatred and discrimination, though some sources also report that her time spent abroad after she left for Egypt in 2010 to study English may also have been a factor. She was previously detained in May 2015, and a second time in April 2017 where she tortured in an interrogation room with an electric chair. She finally left China on 28 April 2018.

Around 16 January 2018 (month of), a Uyghur woman from Huocheng county (Ili, Xinjiang) was detained and sent to a re-education camp. At some point since then she was sentenced to 4 years in prison. Her current status and the reason for her detention are unknown.

Around 16 January 2018 (month of), a Uyghur professor from Xinjiang University in Urumqi City, Xinjiang (coded as Shuimogou) was taken away by the police and reportedly detained in a re-education camp. He was believed to have been taken away for exhibiting 'two-faced tendencies'. It was reported that he was released in May 2019.

On 16 January 2018, crowds of petitioners were told at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng district (Beijing) that they would not be received today, and that arrangements had been made for them to be ''received'' at the Jiujingzhuang ''black jail'' Relief Service Centre. Afterwards, they arranged for buses to transport the petitioners to Jiujingzhuang. It was reported that the petitioners were later repatriated to their respective hometowns. This was suspected to be a move to reduce the number of petitions recording ahead of the 18-19 January second plenary session of the 19th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China.

Around 16 January 2018 (as reported), a banker went incommunicado in Hong Kong after his father, General and Former Vice Chairman of the Central Military Commission, was summoned for case review. The disappearance was suspected to be related to a change of power within the Communist Party and an anti-corruption campaign led by President Xi.

Around 16 January 2018 (month of), all villagers except for elders and children from a village in Shihezi Township (Shihezi City, Xinjiang) were taken away and escorted by troops (armed with live ammunition) deployed by the central government to a re-education camp, they were forced to undertake political indoctrination and pledge allegiance to the Chinese state every day. This was part of the ramped-up efforts to persecute Muslims in Xinjiang under the pretext of ''sinicization of religion''.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Kazakh Ethnic Group (China); Muslim Group (China); Women (China)
NOTES: Around 16 January 2018 (month of), four police officers arrested a female, Muslim Kazakh cancer patient at her home in Manas county (Changji Hui Autonomous Region, Xinjiang) and took her a ''transformation through education'' camp at the Manas County Hospital. She was reportedly arrested for owning a Kazakh passport. Despite being housed at a hospital, her health condition declined as she didn't receive appropriate medical treatment.

Around 16 January 2018 (month of), a Kazakh man was taken away by local authorities from a hospital in Xinjiang where he had surgery, and sent to a re-education camp for the reason that his wife and son emigrated to Kazakhstan. He remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 5 October 2018. In February 2017, the whole family applied for passports with the intention of emigrating to Kazakhstan, but the government demanded one person in the family to stay in China as the guarantor. The husband stayed, but was taken into custody and detained by the government for 15 days in September 2017.

Around 16 January 2018 (month of), a Kazakh man was taken in Xinjiang and sent to a re-education camp. He remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 5 October 2018. He married a Kazakhstani local in August 2017, and when they went back to China to visit relatives, he was sent to the camp, while his wife returned to Kazakhstan.

Around 16 January 2018 (month of), a Uyghur woman from Ghulja City was taken away, likely by the authorities from her hometown in Ghulja City (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang). She was then held incommunicado for over two years until early May 2020, where she made a phone call to her family stating that she was well and working as an English teacher in the city's development zone. She first returned to China on 26 December 2017, before changing her WeChat profile picture to an image resembling a prison cell with a shadow of a person. One of her testifiers believed that she was taken away around this period.

On 17 January 2018, a female Uyghur official working in Yawage town (also known as Yarbagh) in Kashi, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, disappeared after she ''expressed sympathy'' for fellow members of her ethnic group that were sent to ''Re-Education Camps''. It was reported that she was taken by the authorities and held in a ''Re-Education Camp'' according to leaked information from the National Security Agency, and a testimony by a Ugyhur businessman living in exile in Turkey. [women targeted: government officials]

On 17 January 2018, a Christian pastor was taken away by the police in Jiyuan City, Henan Province after he got out of the hospital and arrived at home. At the time of reporting on 19 January 2018, his situation remained unknown.

Around 17 January 2018 (as reported), a victim of a forced eviction who had protested by streaking was transferred to a mental hospital to continue being detained after being detained at the police station in Binhu District (Wuxi, Jiangsu). Her mother and daughters had enquired about her situation on 15 January 2018 but did not received a response.

Around 18 January 2018, a Kazakh man was taken away by the local police near the village police station in Aqbaldau village (Tacheng, Xinjiang). He was then taken back to the police station before being sent to a hospital for a medical examination later that evening. He was then transferred to a re-education camp. Three days after he first arrived at the camp, he was taken into an interrogation room and seated in a tiger chair for half an hour. He was released at the end of November 2018, and continued to be under house or village arrest for eight months before he received his passport and returned to Kazakhstan on 31 July 2019.

On 20 January 2018, an elderly Protestant woman died in Xiayi county (Henan) after authorities repeatedly harrassed and questioned her for allowing friends to gather by her side with Christian songs and prayers following her discharged from the hospital on 16 Jan. On 17 Jan, four township officials came to the woman's home to question her, disregarding that she was severely ill and in the process of recuperating. They harrassed her again on 18 Jan. She suffered from great psychological stress as a result and died on 20 Jan.

On 20 January 2018, a petitioner was forced into a vehicle by triad members in Nanmofang Area, Chaoyang District (Beijing) and beaten by triad members, reportedly working on behalf of the person's local government. The triad members took her back to Wu'an Town, Nanzhang County (Xiangyang, Hubei) overnight. She was then held in two separate hotels over a period of two days and suffered further beatings by local officials. Following this, she was detained in the local Wu'an police station for 15 days during which she was again beaten.

On 20 January 2018, a Swedish scholar and bookseller was arrested by authorities while on a train to Beijing. He has been incommunicado for at least 2 weeks since. The book merchant had been arrested in 2015 and kept under surveillance in Beijing for more than 2 years in connection with the Causeway bookstore incident in Hong Kong.

On 24 January 2018, a few hundred human rights defenders from all over Shanghai were forced onto a bus by plain clothes police in Pudong, Shanghai. They were then detained in a government-established ''black jail'' at Fucun street/Fu Cun Lu in Putuo District (Shanghai). Police detained these petitioners to prevent them from protesting during a municipal meeting which was going to be held in Shanghai.

On 24 January 2018, a human rights activist currently being held in Shangbancheng Prison in Shangbancheng Town (Chengde, Hebei) was attacked by guards who, despite the prisoner's poor health did not allow him to rest, even physically beating him and pouring pepper spray on him.

On 24 January 2018, a female petitioner was abducted by unidentified men from a hotel in Changchun, Jilin, where she was preparing to hand over some materials for her mother's grievances to the Jilin representative ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions. She had since lost contact.

On 25 January 2018, a petitioner was detained at the high-speed railway station in Kunshan City (Suzhou, Jiangsu) by 7-8 stability maintenance personnel led by the secretary of Chaoyang Community. The petitioner was placed in a car and taken to a hotel in Kunshan and detained in a room without heating and not provided with food for two days. It was reported that the Kunshan municipal government arranged for over 10 personnel to guard the petitioner every day. The petitioner had sought to petition for her rights after her former employee demanded money for a road accident involving the petitioner and another driver. She remained detained illegally at the hotel at the time of reporting on 25 February 2018.

On 26 January 2018, during the ''two sessions'' of Jiangsu Province, a female petitioner was taken by 7 to 8 people from the Kunshan City Urban Management Committee including the Secretary of Chaoyang District from the train station in Kunshan county-level city (Suzhou, Jiangsu) and first detained at Hongfeng sub-district office and then at Baigao Hotel for 65 days in Kunshan until 30 March 2018 when the national ''two sessions'' ended. The petitioner has been petitioning for many years on house demolitions and contracting of bus routes. In the past, she was also repeatedly illegally detained by the government in the name of maintaining stability.

Around 27 January 2018 (between 23-31 January), a man was administered psychotropic drugs at the Liaocheng No.4 People's Hospital in Dongchangfu district (Liaocheng, Shandong). He had been forcibly admitted and held incommunicado from 23 to 31 Jan by the CPC Secretary and Chief of Yangdian village, Dutang town of Dingtao county. It was reported that he appealed on behalf of his father three times that year, resulting in three forced psychiatric ward admissions.

On 27 January 2018, five petitioners from Pingnan County were taken away from the entrance of a hotel at Gulou District (Fuzhou, Fujian) by the police. They were then taken to the nearby Huada Police Station, before local government officials from their county took them away and detained them in a hotel (a ''black jail'') in the same district. It was reported that the local officials told the petitioners that they would be detained at the hotel for a few days until the ''two sessions'' had concluded.

On 27 January 2018, a human rights lawyer who was responsible for defending the human rights lawyers in the 709 crackdown was transferred from a detention centre in Shijingshan District (Beijing) and held under ''Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location'' in Xuzhou, Jiangsu by the police. He was first taken away by the authorities in Beijing on 19 January and criminally detained. He was later charged with ''inciting subversion of state power''.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); Uzbek Ethnic Group (China)
SOURCE: Xinjiang Victims Database; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 27 January 2018, a Uyghur-Uzbek man was taken away by the police from his home in Herembagh subdistrict, Ghulja City (or Yining City) (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang) and detained in two separate 'facilities' - reported as re-education camp by RFA. It was suspected that his detention was due to him studying in Turkey. In June 2020, he was reportedly sentenced to 15 years in prison a month earlier, though official reasons were not known.

On 28 January 2018, a Tibetan political activist went missing in Lhasa, Tibet and was believed to be in police custody, likely in connection to a protest the man conducted in front of the Potala Palace in Lhasa calling for the return of the Dalai Lama to Tibet. He had since been held incommunicado until it was reported on 18 April 2019 that he was sentenced to eighteen years in prison, likely around September or October 2018, according to his nephew who resides in India, for releasing a video on social media calling for world peace. His partner was also given a two-year prison sentence for filming the video. He was last traced to a prison in his hometown Sog county (Nagchu prefecture) as of 7 Feb. Both of them were allegedly sentenced without a court trial, and their location remained unknown as of 18 April 2019.

Around 28 January 2018 (as reported), the husband of an environmental activist involved in a dispute with the local government in Funing County, Jiangsu over the illegal occupation of farmers' land has been missing for almost a month. He was last seen in Beijing and is suspected to have been abducted, but it is unclear as to whom he was abducted by.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Muslim Group (China); Prisoners (China); Uyghur Ethnic Group (China)
NOTES: Around 29 January 2018 (as reported), approximately 40 days after an Uyghur Islamic scholar was detained in Urumqi (Xinjiang) (coded to Shuimogou), it was reported than he had died in police custody, possibly in an 'internment camp'. The reason for his death is unclear and local police said they were unsure when he died.

On 29 January 2018, a Uyghur literature professor from Xinjiang Normal University was taken away by the police after the police reportedly raided his home in Urumqi City, Xinjiang. According to a local official, the authorities brought him into a political re-education camp. While the reason for his detention is unknown, it took place during a period where intellectuals of ethnic minority groups in Xinjiang were heavily targeted.

On 30 January 2018, a Uyghur writer and poet was arrested in Tianshan district of Urumqi (Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado. He was later reportedly sentenced to 16 years in prison in early October 2019. The suspected reason for his detention is his signing of the 2005 petition for the protection of Uyghur language education.

On 30 January 2018, a Uyghur scholar was arrested in Tianshan (Urumqi, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado. He was later sentenced to 16 years in prison in early October 2019. The reasons for his detention and subsequent sentencing are unknown, but it is speculated to be related to his support for the protection of Uyghur language education by signing a 2005 petition.

Around 30 January 2018 (as reported), a female Uyghur scholar from Xinjiang Normal University was arrested in Urumqi city, Xinjiang (coded as Shuimogou) and detained in a camp, a day after her husband was taken away. While the reason for her detention was unknown, it took place during a period where intellectuals of ethnic minority groups in Xinjiang were heavily targeted. She was released from camp in March 2019.

On 31 January 2018, more than 100 people hired by a demolition company forcibly demolished villagers homes in Miaohu Village, Hancheng, Shaanxi in the early hours of the morning. The demolishment personnel used sticks to break down doors before using excavators to demolish the homes. Some people narrowly escaped being hurt during the process and an elderly couple who resisted the demolition was beated up and taken away in a car. These homes had been marked for demolition by the local government for a development project.

On 31 January 2018, an ethnic minority Kazakh state-approved imam from Qapqal Xibe Autonomous county (Ili, Xinjiang) was taken away by police and held at a re-education camp for six months. After six months, he was officially arrested and put in custody for reading Quran. In the second half of 2018, he was sentenced to 23 years in prison for 'reading Quran' and sent to the 7th Division of Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps Kuytun Prison.

On 2 February 2018, an Uyghur man living in Yengi'sheher Neighbourhood of Moyu Municipality (also known as Karakash) (Hotan, Xinjiang) was sent to the Qaraqash No. 2 camp for having moved to Urumqi without obtaining permission from the local authorities. He was also listed as a 'terrorist suspect' according to a police document. He was approved for release in early 2019 but was still held in a camp, as reported on 05 October 2021.

On 2 February 2018, an Uyghur man living in Yengi'sheher Neighbourhood of Moyu Municipality (also known as Karakash) (Hotan, Xinjiang) was sent to the Qaraqash No. 2 camp for having moved to Urumqi without obtaining permission from the local authorities. He was also listed as a 'terrorist suspect' according to a police document. He was approved for release in early 2019 but was still held in a camp, as reported on 05 October 2021.

On 4 February 2018, a female human rights activist from Guangdong and two of her family members were forcibly taken away from a hotel in Guangzhou, Guangdong by the police and sent on a ''mandatory vacation'' to Huizhou, Guangdong. It was reported that the activist went to the Guangdong Provincial Department of Justice the day before to apply to audit the hearing for the proposed suspension of the license of a human rights lawyer. The activist believed that she was taken away to prevent her from gathering with her friends. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 4 February 2018, two female residents in Niezhuang in Cigouxiang (Xuchang, Henan) was injured by the forced eviction personnel when the residents try to prevent them from entering their home. The forced eviction was led by the officials from the local County Government and around 30 unidentified people.

On 6 February 2018, a Uyghur woman was taken away by the authorities in Ghulja (Yining) City (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang) and held incommunicado likely in a re-education camp. She was later forcefully sent home at an unknown date after being transferred to a hospital due to a broken backbone.

On 6 February 2018, a Kazakh businesswomen from Yining city (Ili, Xinjiang) was taken away by the police and detained incommunicado. She was reportedly taken to a re-education camp. She was released on 28 December 2018, but it is unknown what happened to her during this time and the reasons for her detention remain unclear. It has been reported that she has lost both her businesses since her release and is experiencing health problems. She is also reportedly subject to house arrest following her release.

Around 7 February 2018 (between 6 - 8 February 2018), a Kazakh man who used to work as a farmer and do odd jobs was taken away by the authorities from Ghulja (Yining) County (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang) and sent to a re-education camp. Based on his own testimony, he was released from the camp on 3 November 2018, before being sent to work at a factory for 53 days on 8 November 2018. He was returned his documents on 20 January 2019 and had returned to Kazakhstan, where he is a permanent resident.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 8 February 2018, nearly 800 special polices forces demolished a temple located in Leiyang, Hunan. Local residents were dragged and beaten by the police during their attempts to protect the temple. More than 30 believers were injured during the demolition. The police also subsequently seized items worth several hundred thousand RMB from the temple.

On 8 February 2018, a Fujianese woman was beaten up by community authorities as she was on her way to make photocopies of her land approval outsourcing documents in Changfen village, Gufeng township, Pingnan county of Ningde, Fujian. When she reported the incident, she was arrested and beaten up by the deputy head of the Pingnan county police, and detained for 10 days.

On 10 February 2018, a human rights activist went missing after being taken away by police in Fangshang District (Beijing). The activist had reportedly been planning an event for the Spring Festival and had received phone calls from Beijing officials demanding that he abandon his efforts.

Around 10 February 2018, a human rights activist was forcibly disappeared from her home in Gaoyou (Yangzhou, Jiangsu). It was reported that she had been tracked and monitored by personnel sent by the police since she applied to listen in the hearing of a lawyer on 31 January 2018 and was not able to be contacted from 10 Feb onwards. On 22 Feb, her son received a call from Gaoyou Police Station confirming that his mother had been detained at the police station. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 10 February 2018, 36 ethnic Kazakh Christians from Shawan County (Tacheng, Xinjiang) were sent to a transformation through education camp, on the grounds that they were holding illegal gatherings. At the time of reporting, their location and condition were unknown.

On 10 February 2018, a petitioner was beaten and abused by police officers from the local police station in Shuangliu District (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province), during Xi Jinping's visit to the district. He was taken away and detained in a detention centre in the district on the grounds of ''picking quarrels and provoking trouble''.

Around 14 February 2018 (month of), a family of ten members were forcibly taken away from Huocheng County (Ili Kazak Autonomous, Xinjiang) while they were reading the Quran at home. They were detained in a ''transformation through education camp'' for having a ''gang gathering''. They remained detained in the education camp at the time of reporting on 3 October 2018.

Around 14 February 2018 (middle of month), 180 ethnic Kazakhs from an unreported village in Fuhai County (Ili Kazak Autonomous, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region) were taken to re-education centres because they had visited Kazakhstan or Turkey.

Around 14 February 2018 (month of), an Uyghur man from Wensu (Onsu) County (Aksu Prefecture, Xinjiang) was taken away by the police and had since been held incommunicado. While there was no official information about his arrest, his brother received information that he had been sentenced to 7 years in prison in late 2019.

Around 14 February 2018 (month of), a Uyghur woman residing in Urumqi, Xinijang was taken away by the authorities and detained in an ''internment camp'' somewhere around Dawan neighbourhood in Urumqi. She was reportedly released on 1 May 2019, but was not allowed to contact her children who are residing in the US. The reasons for her detention were unclear.

Around 14 February 2018 (month of), a Uyghur singer was arrested in Sangzhuxiang (Pishan, Hotan, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado. Some sources report that he has been sentenced to 10 years prison, while his brother claimed that he is detained in a re-education camp. The reason for his detention is suspected to be related to the themes of his music and his charity work for the Uyghur community.

On 14 February 2018, a human rights activist was summoned to the police station in Zixi County (Fuzhou, Jiangxi) after having signed a petition in support of Sui Muqing, a human rights lawyer. After he refused to sign a statement saying he was forced to sign the petition by Sui Muqing, the activist was beaten.

Around 14 February 2018 (month of), a Kazakh certified imam from Shangkuokesu village (Tarbagatay, Xinjiang) was taken away by the police and detained incommunicado. It was reported that he was released either in December 2018 or January 2019. The reason for his detention was unknown.

Around 14 February 2018 (month of), a Uyghur professor from Saybag district (Urumqi, Xinjiang) was taken away by the police and detained incommunicado. The reason for his detention was unclear, but it was speculated that he was targeted as one of the scholars who signed a petition in 2005 to protect Uyghur-language education.

Around 14 February 2018 (month of), a Kazakhstan citizen originally from Tacheng county (Tacheng, Xinjiang) in China was first intercepted by authorities while travelling to Beijing for business, before being forced to fly to Tacheng, where he was held at a detention centre for four days and sent to several ''internment camps''. The official reason for his detention was for failing to ''de-register'' from his Chinese citizenship as a dual citizenship holder, although the victim stated this was completed back in 2002. In mid-April 2018, officials admitted to having no grounds for holding him, before he and two other Kazakhstan citizens were released and allowed to return home.

Around 15 February 2018 (month of), a top Uyghur soccer player who played professionally for Jiangsu Suning F.C. was captured by the police while visiting Dorbiljin Market in Emin (Dorbiljin) county of the Ili Kazakh Autonomous Prefecture. He had been reportedly detained at a re-education camp for visiting foreign countries after returning to China after training and competitions overseas.

Around 15 February 2018 (month of), men from 17 households in a village in Xinjiang were arrested by authorities and sent to ''transformation through education'' camps for unspecified sentences and release dates. At least one of these men practised Islamic worship.

Around 15 February 2018 (month of), an Uyghur student was taken to a re-education camp in Xinjiang and interrogated under abusive conditions for multiple days with hands and feet tied to a chair for up to nine hours daily. He was studying international relations at Kazakhstan when the police from Turpan called him threatening trouble to his family if he didn't return immediately.

Around 15 February 2018 (month of), a Uyghur language professor disappeared after he returned to Urumqi (Xinjiang) from his holiday in Turkey. He was suspected to be kept in a re-education camp as part of Chinese government efforts to crack down on academics in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region.

On 15 February 2018, a human rights activist was illegally detained in a hotel in Yuanbao District (Dandong, Liaoning) for 48 hours after having been detained in a police station, also in Yuanbao District, for the previous 26 hours. He had been forcibly taken away in Beijing and escorted back to Yuanbao District on 14 Feb. The human rights activist was the lead planner for the Petitioners' Spring Festival Gala.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); Muslim Group (China); CPC: Communist Party of China
NOTES: Around 15 February 2018 (month of), an Uyghur CCP member from Kashgar City, Xinjiang was seized by six to seven armed police officers, for performing an Islamic prayer at the burial ceremony of his mother several years ago. It was reported that he had remained in custody in an undisclosed location at the time of reporting.

Around 15 February 2018 (month of), an Uyghur linguistics professor was called to the Xinjiang University in Tianshan district (Urumqi, Xinjiang) by police and was sent to a re-education camp and became incommunicado until March 2021, when a source revealed that he was sentenced to 15 years in prison for an unknown reason. His detention was reportedly due to his previous study in Germany and his research on the Uyghur language.

Around 15 February 2018 (month of), a detained Uyghur man from Toutunhe district (Urumqi, Xinjiang) was transferred from a detention center to a camp after approximately 10 months. He was transferred to different camps before being released on 22 May 2019. He was arrested on 10 April 2017 while trying to travel to Australia with his wife.

Around 15 February 2018 (month of), a detained Uyghur man from Toutunhe district (Urumqi, Xinjiang) was transferred from a detention centre to a camp after approximately 10 months. He was transferred to different camps before being released on 22 May 2019. He was first arrested on 10 April 2017 while trying to travel to Australia with his wife. He was arrested on for having traveled to Turkey in 2014 and 2015, and on suspicion of 'organising, leading and participating in [a] terrorist organization.'

Around 16 February 2018 (as reported), a Kazakh man (also a Kazakhstani Green Card holder) who was a retired primary school teacher in Tuoli County (Ili, Xinjiang) was taken away by the authorities and detained in a re-education camp, according to the locals who told his wife. On July 2017, the Tuoli County Second Primary School contacted the retired teacher and asked him to go back to Xinjiang for retirement matters, but since 16 February 2018, his wife was not able to contact him anymore.

On 17 February 2018, three Kazakh men (who were brothers) from Qara'agashty Village, Kunes County (Ili Kazkah Autonomous, Xinjiang) were taken away by the authorities and detained in a re-education camp, as confirmed by their local village administrator. The wife of one of the brothers was also taken away to a re-education camp the next day, while the wife of another brother was also detained in a camp sometime in February. It was reported later that one of the brothers was sentenced to prison for between 8 and 18 years.

On 19 February 2018, a 24 years old Kazakh man from Koktagai Village, Aqdala Township (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang) was taken by the police and sent to a ''political education camp''. He had returned to Xinjiang from Kazakhstan in January 2018 to sell his residence, but had his passport confiscated by the local police. It was claimed that his sister was also sent to a ''political education camp'' after she returned to China, though reports from Xinjiang Victims Database suggest that she was put to a ''special camp'' for two months, likely between June and August, to attend classes daily and was allowed to return home each evening.

On 19 February 2018, three people, one of whom was released from a detention centre on the same day and the other two are her parents, were taken away by police in Pingnan (Ningde, Fujian). Their whereabouts were unknown. This happened on the same day the daughter was released after being held detained for 10 days for disrupting order and refusing to sign a land acquisition paper.

On 21 February 2018, a human rights activist was taken away by the police from Xiangtang Village in Pukou District (Nanjing, Jiangsu) and taken to the Zhujiang police station. The human rights activist was visiting a Nanjing dissident living in Xiangtang Village, who had been placed under house arrest for more than a year by the National Security Bureau. While at the police station, the activist was physically and verbally abused. He was later released after being detained for about 24 hours.

On 21 February 2018, 6 people (who had reportedly petitioned before) were abducted by triad members in Taoranting Park in Xicheng District (Beijing) and forcibly repatriated to Fuzhou. It was reported that the group had already been intercepted by police officers earlier in the afternoon while visiting Tiananmen Square and taken away to the Tiananmen Public Security Branch. The officials had attempted to transfer the group to a ''black jail'', but they were released as the ''black jail'' was closed during Chinese New Year. After making their way back to Taoranting Park, they were taken away by triad members and repatriated to Fuzhou (Fujian). 1 man in group was beaten during the journey, leaving his face bloodied.

On 23 February 2018, a female petitioner was beaten at home in Wu'an town (Nanzhang, Xiangyang, Hubei) by a local community officer and a dozen ''unemployed people'' hired by the government. She was then taken to the community office, a hotel and eventually a ''black jail'' at the intersection of Xinji (Nanzhang county), Leihe and Liuhou townships (Yicheng county). She was detained until the morning of 28 March 2018 when three people dropped her at a place more than 20 km away from her home. The petitioner was suspected to have been given illegal drugs and reported that she had been suffering weakness and motoric problems since being taken to detention.

On 24 February 2018, a woman farmer from Dashuijing Village, Chongqing was abducted by police and Chongqing South Railway Station administration in Chongqing South Railway Station, Yuzhong District when trying to visit Beijing. The next day, police illegally abducted her to a small island in Changshou Lake, Chongqing, where she was restricted.

On 24 February 2018, a Kazakh woman was arrested while visiting her birthplace in Barkol county (Hami, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado. She was later released on 24 December 2018 or 14 January 2019 (reports vary), and placed under house arrest. The reason for her detention is not known, but it is suspected to be related to her sending her son to live abroad in Kazakhstan. Some reports also mentioned that she is being forced to teach dance at a labour camp, and is undergoing multiple kidney surgeries.

On 24 February 2018, a female rights defender was taken by a government official from the Shanghai House Expropriation Department in Shanghai and detained in Houniao Resort in Shanghai Chongmin District Chenjia Town Qianyugong Road No. 888. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 24 February 2018, a human rights activist from Kunshan City, Jiangsu Province was taken away and beaten in Beijing by personnel from the Kunshan Municipal Government, on the eve of the ''lianghui''. Her two mobile phones and identity card were also forcibly taken away. She was later sent to a temporary residence in Kunshan City on 25 February 2018, where she was detained under surveillance. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 25 February 2018, a human rights activist from Kunshan City, Jiangsu Province was sent from Beijing to Kunshan City by government personnel who had beaten her up the day before. She was detained under surveillance in a temporary residence in Kunshan City, Jiangsu Province before being taken away on 26 February 2019 by unidentified persons, who then detained her in a ''black jail'' at an unreported location for one month. She was released on the evening of 24 March 2019. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 25 February 2018, a female rights defender was taken by unknown people when she was walking in the residential area where she lived in Shanghai and went incommunicado. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 25 February 2018, a female rights defender was taken back to Chongqing when she was taking a train in Guang'an District (Guang'an, Sichuan) by stability maintenance personnel, and her situation was unknown afterwards. It was later reported that she was illegally detained for more than 20 days, due to heightened security measures around the Lianghui conventions period. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 25 February 2018, before the Lianghui Conventions, eight petitioners were taken away by ten police officers from a rental house in Dadong Village (Fangshan, Beijing) and sent to Jingjiuzhuang ''black jail'' in Beijing. This was part of a broad campaign to prevent petitioners from travelling to Beijing to petition during the Lianghui Conventions.

On 25 February 2018, an Uyghur man from Bostan Subdistrict, Moyu (Karakax) County (Hotan, Xinjiang) was sent to a re-education camp by the authorities. It was reported that his detention was due to a previous attempt to flee the country, and for having more children than allowed by the family planning policy.

Around 26 February 2018, a human rights activist was detained in a black prison in a hotel in Nangang District (Harbin, Heilongjiang) after having met with the head of the Harbin Xiangyang Public Security Branch on the night of 26th and agreeing to return to Harbin to be interviewed by the head of the Criminal Investigation Department of the Provincial Public Security Department. The activist has been petitioning for 10 years after the death of his son while at school and is a member of an anti-corruption and human rights alliance.

On 26 February 2018, two rights defenders were taken to the Relief Administration Service Center of Beijing by the plain-clothes police officers in charge of stopping petitioners from the Beijing-based Office of the Shanghai Government at the Beijing South Railway Station in Fengtai District (Beijing), and on 27 February 2018, they were sent back to Shanghai, one detained in a ''black jail'', and the other becoming incommunicado. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets.

On 26 February 2018, a female rights defender was taken by interceptors from the Beijing-based Office of the Shanghai Government at the Supreme People's Court of China in Dongcheng District (Beijing), and later she was detained in a ''black jail'' in Shanghai from 27 February 2018. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders are their targets. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

Around 26 February 2018, a dissident from Rongchang District, Chongqing was taken away by the police from Rongchang District (Chongqing), and detained in a psychiatric hospital until his release on 15 April 2018. He had previously been summoned to the police station on 26 February 2018 and warned not to breach the firewall on the internet and criticise the government. This was the sixth time he had been taken away to a psychiatric hospital.

On 27 February 2018, a female rights defender went missing when she was at home in Jinyang Road Sub-district in Pudong New Area (Shanghai), and it was suspected that she was taken by the stability maintenance officers. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 27 February 2018, a female petitioner was beaten to unconsciousness by Nanmu Village Secretary in a restaurant in Yuanzhou (Yichun City, Jiangxi) during a dinner while the village secretary and two other colleagues of him tried to talk her out of further petitioning. She had just been taken back to Yichun by the same people from Nanchang on 26 February 2018 on her way to Beijing. After the assault, she was sent to the hospital by local police. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 27 February 2018, when a rights defender and his wife went to Beijing to seek for medical treatment and legal counsel, they were taken by the local authorities and detained in a hotel, once they arrived at the Beijing Railway Station in Dongcheng district (Beijing).

Around 27 February 2018, a Kazakh man was taken away by the authorities from a hospital likely in Jeminay county, Altay Prefecture (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang) and sent to a re-education camp in the same county, after he had received treatment at the hospital for a broken leg. He was first taken away by the police from Urumqi Airport on 7 February 2018 and detained at the Jeminay police station for questioning for over 20 days. It was reported that his leg became broken for reasons unknown during the detention. The suspected reasons for his detention are due to having restricted apps on his phone, and for minor prior incidents involving law enforcement

On 27 February 2018, a female farmer from Dashuijing Village, Chongqing was pushed from the second floor by stability maintenance personnel, while she was detained at a small island in Changshouhu town, Chongqing. She had been detained by the police on the island since 24 February 2018. The woman was injured and fractured both her feet. She was taken to a hospital for treatment.

On 27 February 2018, a female petitioner was intercepted and beaten by the Lanmu village party secretary and his associate at Nanchang, Jiangxi Province. She was preparing to take the train the next day with three other female petitioners from Nanchang to travel to Beijing to petition. The petitioner suffered severe injuries after being hit with a wine bottle in the head.

On 27 February 2018, shortly before the ''Lianghui'' period, police illegally detained a retired professor of Shandong University and held him incommunicado for 40 days in Yanzi Mountain Villa in Lixia District, Jinan, Shandong. He was detained as authorities feared he would carry out activities commemorating the Tiananmen massacre during this period. He was released on 7 April and went back to his home in Shandong University, Jinan City (Shandong), where he continued to be monitored.

On 27 February 2018, a female petitioner was violently punched in the head by a stability maintenance officer at her home in Luyang District (Hefei, Anhui) when she refused the officers to enter her home after they forced her to return home when she threatened to jump from the top of a building. Her door was also destroyed by the assailant. The petitioner was under residential surveillance by the sub-district office due to her petitions in the past.

On 27 February 2018, a rights defender was taken to Nanxiang Mahjong and Chess Room by a group of people hired by the Nanxiang Town Government in front of a residential area in Baoshan District (Shanghai), and later he was detained in a ''black jail''. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets.

On 27 February 2018, a human rights activist was sent back to Shanghai from Beijing by government interceptors and was handed over to 4-5 unknown individuals at an underground parking lot at the Shanghai railway station in Jing'an district. He was held in a villa in Changxing Island, Chongming District until being dropped on a road on 21 March 2018. He was forcibly searched, served tea that was drugged and made him unconscious for the first three days of going incommunicado, and had his mobile phone and belonging taken away.

On 27 February 2018, two rights defenders were taken from their home in Shanghai by the police officers from Jing'an Police Department Baoshan Road Office, and kept in a ''black jail'' on the opposite side of the Shanghai Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets.

On 28 February 2018, a female human rights defender - on a medical visit from Kunshan, Jiangsu - was kidnapped by five unidentifiable persons (likely hired by the government) near the Kaiyangli Post Office in Beijing (Fengtai district) and sent back to her hometown, after which she was held in a ''black jail'' until 21 March 2018 when she was released. When she was freed and visited Beijing to report her case, You'anmen police station recorded her witness account but refused to file it, effectively denying her due process. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 28 February 2018, a petitioner and human rights defender, who had suffered problems with forced demolition and land seizures, went missing in Beijing after having travelled to the city to seek medical advice. Upon arriving in Beijing, she was met by a police officer from her home town, Kunshan (Suzhou, Jiangsu), who asked her to return to Kunshan. She refused to return, and left a note saying if they disappeared then it was because they had been kidnapped by the government. She remained uncontactable as of 1 March 2018. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 28 February 2018, a local Muslim and his son were taken away from Huocheng County (Ili Kazak Autonomous, Xinjiang) by local authorities and detained in a ''transformation through education camp'' for applying for passports.

Around 28 February 2018 (end of month), a Kazakh woman (originally from Emin County, now a Kazakhstan citizen) was taken away by the authorities in Emin County (Tacheng, Xinjiang) and sent to a re-education camp. She had recently returned to China on 14 December 2017 to undergo a household de-registration process in order to give up her Chinese citizenship, which had been reported as a likely reason for her detention. During her detention, she was forced to learn ''red songs'' and the Chinese language. She was later released at the end of November 2018, and returned to Kazakhstan sometime after.

On 28 February 2018, a rights defender was physically assaulted in a police car in Beijing by a police officer, and the other two were holding him when he was picked up by four Shanghai Changning District police officers from the police station where he was held after the Beijing police broke into his hotel room and taken him to a police station nearby. He was later sent to the Beijing Taoranting Garden Hotel where Beijing-based Office of the Shanghai Government is, and on 1 March 2018, he was sent back to Shanghai and the Shanghai Chongming Island Fishing Vacation Center ''black jail''.

Around 28 February 2018 (end of month), a Kazakh woman from Nanyuan subdistrict, Wusu City (Tarbagatay, Xinjiang) was taken away by the authorities and detained in a re-education camp. She was later released in November 2018 and placed under house arrest, although her relatives overseas were still unable to contact her. She left for Kazakhstan in October 2019. It was reported that she was detained for communicating with her father who resides in Kazakhstan.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2012-); Police Forces of China (2012-)
NOTES: On 28 February 2018, a petitioner from Shanghai was beaten into unconsciousness in a car by five unidentified people on the way to a hotel after they took away his cane, cover his head with a black hood, and forced him into a car. He was subsequently detained for 22 days before they threw him by the side of a road. He believes his kidnappers were from the government.

Around 1 March 2018 (beginning of month), a female Uyghur insurance company worker and part-time Mandarin tutor residing in Yining City (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang) was detained in a 'transformation-through-education' facility. Although authorities provided no explicit reasons, the victim had made money transfers to Australia in 2013 to help pay for the house of her parents, who were accused for being 'fleeing terrorists.' Some photos of her wearing headscarves were accused of 'promoting extremism.' She suffered from liver damage in the facility but did not receive 'adequate medical treatment', and was released in Dec 2018. She was arrested again on 9 April 2019 and held in a pre-trial detention center. Her trial was reportedly held in June 2019, and she was finally sentenced for 'funding terrorism' in January 2020. She was released again on 4 September 2020 and admitted to hospital without a reason. After a stay of 'months' she was returned to the detention center. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 1 March 2018, before the Lianghui Conventions, an female elected head of village administration from Anhui Province was taken from her temporary residence around Xingong in Daxing District (Beijing) by seven or eight unidentified people in plain clothes. The head of village administration has defended the rights of the villagers for more than a decade. She remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 5 March 2018. [women targeted: politicians]

On 1 March 2018, two female rights defenders from Jiangsu were taken in Beijing by the Beijing police when they were staying at their friend's place and petitioning in Beijing. They remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 7 March 2018. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

Around 1 March 2018 (beginning of month), before the Lianghui conventions started, a female rights defender in Guangzhou (Guangdong) was sent to take on mandatory vacation by the local state security police. She was followed by stability maintenance personnel everyday and deprived of the freedom to go out, have contact with other people, and post comments on the Internet. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 1 March 2018, a female petitioner, who was a victim of the Huaxi Institute fundraising fraud, was taken by the vice-chairman of the Butterfly Watch Factory Employees' Family Residential Area Resident Committee and three people from her home in the residential area in Beilin District (Xi'an, Shaanxi) and kept her in a hotel in Mei County which is more than 100 km away from Xi'an. Three other petitioners, who were going to petition together with the female petitioner over the Huaxi Institute fundraising fraud, also went missing during the Lianghui Conventions.

On 1 March 2018, two petitioners, who were husband and wife, were taken away by the secretary of the Anqing City Bridge Subdistrict Office and the police from their apartment in Xiaobailou Village in Daxing District of Beijing. They were sent back to their hometown, Anqing City, and was subsequently detained in ''black jail'' separately. During the detention, subdistrict office personnel repeatedly threatened the wife to sign a resettlement agreement and refused her seeing a doctor. The husband was detained until 12 April. The wife was detained in an abandoned hostel until 3 May.
Around 1 March 2018 (between 20 February and 10 March), a Kazakh man died in a political re-education camp in Emin county (Tacheng, Xinjiang) after being beaten by camp guards.

On 1 March 2018, two petitioners, who were also brothers, were taken away by private security forces hired by a government official from Jiujingzhuang in Fengtai District (Beijing). One of the petitioners was carried into and violently beaten by the security forces in the car. They were then sent back to Guanling Buyei and Miao Autonomous County (Anshun, Guizhou).

On 1 March 2018, two female petitoners were taken from the KFC Youanmen Branch in Fengtai District (Beijing) by the chief police officer of the Henan Xuchang Xiangcheng County Cigouxiang Police Department when they were on their way to petition over forced eviction to the delegates of the National People's Congress, and they were kept in the Beijing-based Office of the Henan Government for several days.

On 1 March 2018, three female petitioners from Wuhan Jianrong Village went incommunicado after they were taken by the police officers when they passed by Tiananmen Square in Dongcheng District (Beijing) on their way to petition at the National Public Complaints and Proposals Administration.

Around 1 March 2018 (beginning of month), a female petitioner from Wuxi Beitang District was intercepted by inspectors while traveling on a bus in Beijing on her way to petition at the Supreme People's Court, and sent to an inspection centre. Later, she was sent to Jiujingzhuang ''black jail'' by the Tongzhou District Police. On the next day, she was sent back to Wuxi and placed under residential surveillance.

On 1 March 2018, a ''black security guard'' snatched a female petitioner's phone while she was walking about in Beijing. She was then sent back to her hometown, Wuhan City, and was subsequently detained in a ''black jail'' and had not been released by the date of report on 12 April 2018. Her disappearance is part of the authorities' crackdown on petitioners around the ''lianghui'' period.

On 1 March 2018, a rights defender from Wuhan was taken by more than ten unidentified people and went incommunicado when he was waiting for the bus at a bus station of 485 bus line in Beijing. He was in Beijing to petition together with a group of petitioners from Wuhan during the Lianghui conventions.

On 1 March 2018, a rights defender went to attend a trial in Chongqing and had since remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 8 March 2018. It was suspected that he might have been suppressed due to the heightened security measures around the Lianghui conventions period. It was reported that the local government sent more people to guard his house, for which he and the local government had not reached an eviction agreement.

On 1 March 2018, a rights defender was taken from his home in Shanghai by the police officers from Pudong Police Department Sanlin Police Station and went incommunicado. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets.

On 1 March 2018, a rights defender was physically abused by security personnel appointed by the government when they were taking him from Beijing back to Shanghai, after that he was detained in a ''black jail'' inside the Chongming Hengsha Island Fishing Resort. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets.

On 2 March 2018, a female petitioner who had been detained for the past 3 days was taken away by the Chief of the Yellow Crane Tower Police Station of Wuchang District (Wuhan, Hubei), and had been missing at least until the time of report on 12 April 2018. No further news about her whereabouts. It was suspected that she was taken to be detained in a ''black jail'' in Wuhan city. Her disappearance was part of the authorities' crackdown on petitioners around the ''lianghui'' period.

On 2 March 2018, a detained civilian was transferred to a 'black jail' in Jiangxia village, Liucheng town of Wuyi county (Jinhua, Zhejiang) after he was kidnapped from Beijing and interrogated at the Wuyi County Public Security Bureau. The transferal was authorized by the government head of Xinzhai town. When the detainee was young, he was owed wage arrears by a man whose son is currently an officer of Baiyang Police Station, Wuyi county. Since 2012, the police officer had been exercising his political power to 'avenge' and inflict harm on the victim by framing him for false crimes and deliberately mishandling his cases.

On 2 March 2018, a female petitioner from Jiang'an, Wuhan was intercepted by private security personnel sent by officials of the Jiang'an District Political and Legislative Affairs Committee of CCP in Tongzhou district, Beijing and detained in a residential area. During 34 days of detention, she suffered from torture and deprivation before being sent back to her home in Wuhan without having her money and personal belongings around.

On 2 March 2018, a rights defender went incommunicado after he was taken from Beijing back to Shanghai by interceptors from the Beijing-based Office of the Shanghai Government. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets.

On 2 March 2018, a petitioner was disappeared and detained in a ''black jail'' after lodging a police report in Beijing. He had been missing at least until the date of report on 12 April 2018. No further news on this person. His disappearance was part of the authorities' crackdown on petitioners around the ''lianghui'' period.

On 2 March 2018, several unidentified people, who claimed to be police but refused to show their documents, broke into a house in Beijing and beat the occupants before taking them away to the police station. Two of the occupants had just been released from prison, while another two were victims of forced demolition in Changzhou (Jiangsu). During the incident one of the victims attempted to take pictures, but then had their phone taken from them.

On 2 March 2018, a female petitioner from Chongqing Jiangbei District Nanqiaosi Village was taken to a police station by the police when she was at a bus station in Beijing on her way to petition at the National Public Complaints and Proposals Administration, and later the personnel from the Office of the Chongqing Government to Beijing sent her back to Chongqing, and the Chongqing police kept her in Zhulin Hotel. After she refused to stay in the hotel, the police officers attacked her, injured her eye, caused multiple bruises over her body and bleeding on her palms.

On 2 March 2018, a female petitioner from Jiang'an District, Wuhan was taken away from Beijing by the Beijing Police and sent back to Wuhan City, Hubei by the Wuhan stability maintenance agents while she was petitioning in Beijing during the Lianghui Conventions. She remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 6 March 2018.

On 2 March 2018, a human rights activist was taken away by the police in Beijing to ''take a mandatory vacation'' while the ''two sessions'' were being held in the city. It was reported that he was taken to Zhongshan until 22 March 2018 when the ''two sessions'' ended.

On 2 March 2018, a man was taken from his barber shop in Ranyizhen (Ya'an, Sichuan) by four local CCP leaders, government employees and more than 10 thugs. The man was beaten in a car with his head covered and was taken to a flat owned by the village committee to be detained until 2 April 2018 when he was repatriated to his shop by some thugs. During his detention, the sister and niece of the man went to CCP leaders to ask for his whereabouts and got beaten by some thugs as well. Similar abduction happened to the man in 2017 and lasted for 47 days. Reason for the abduction was to prevent him from petitioning in Beijing. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 3 March 2018, a rights defender from Hubei was taken from his home in Jingshan County (Jingmen, Hubei) and sent on ''mandatory vacation'' in Luoyang, Henan by the national security officers from Jingshan County, Hubei. This was part of the stability maintenance measures during the annual Lianghui conventions period.

On 3 March 2018, a human rights activist was preparing to travel to Harbin to aid a friend when they were intercepted by local police in Lutun Town (Yingkou, Liaoning) and taken to a black prison in a hotel where a team of special task forces kept guard. The task force was set up by the Liaoning government to maintain stability around and during the ''two sessions''. The activist and the friend are both members of an anti-corruption and human rights alliance.

On 3 March 2018, a Beijing rights defender was beaten and injured by a police at a hotel in Jiupu Town (Hangzhou, Zhejiang) while he was travelling there. The police and 3 other ''auxiliary police'' arrived at the hotel and knocked at the defender's door to carry out an ''inspection'' at night. When he requested that they produce a summons, he was beaten up and then handcuffed and taken to Jiupu Police Station for a few hours for getting his footprints and ID checked.

On 3 March 2018, a rights defender was taken in Linxiang County (Yueyang, Hunan) and kept in a ''black jail'' behind Linxiang City Chang'an Street Sub-district Office by the personnel from the government, due to convening of the Lianghui Conventions. The rights defender escaped the ''black jail'' on 13 March 2018 after being kept for ten days, but he was captured by five unidentified people, sent to the police station, taken away by the personnel from Chang'an Street Nanhua Sub-district office, and returned home on 22 March 2018.

On 3 March 2018, more than a hundred policemen took away 11 individuals, mostly previous petitioners, who were gathering for dinner at a human rights defender's home in Dongchangfu District (Liaocheng, Shandong). Three of the arrested people were detained in ''black jails''/hotels by their home district officials. Four were detained for criminal investigations and one was charged later on.

On 3 March 2018, a female petitioner was taken by the top officials from the Heilongjiang Jiamusi Police Department to the Longan Hotel when she arrived at the Harbin West Railway Station in Daoli district (Harbin, Heilongjiang). Although she was promised to have a meeting with the officials from the Heilongjiang Provincial Police Department, she was detained in the hotel and guarded by police and sub-district stability maintenance personnel instead.

On 3 March 2018, when the Lianghui conventions started, a female petitioner in Suzhou (Jiangsu) was kept by stability maintenance personnel in Suzhou Dingtai Garden, a ''black jail'' and suffered from headache, as well as fainting, caused by no food offered by the personnel. She was kept in ''black jail'' during the Lianghui conventions because she petitioned against forced eviction previously.

On 3 March 2018, a female petitioner was physically abused by a group of stability maintenance personnel at Line 157 Silihe Bus Station in Luyang District (Hefei, Anhui), after she was forced to get off the bus by them, and physically assaulted again after she was taken back home by the stability maintenance officers and had her shower. The petitioner was under residential surveillance by the sub-district office and attacked by stability maintenance officers previously due to her petitions in the past.

On 3 March 2018, three petitioners from Wuxi, Jiangsu was taken in Beijing by the Beijing police and sent to Beijing Jiujingzhuang Jieji Service Centre (black jail) after being interrogated by the Beijing police.

Around 3 March 2018 (week of), a female petitioner from Zhenjiang City Dantu District was kidnapped by around 8 Dantu District government personnel near Beijing South Railway Station in Fengtai District of Beijing. She was immediately transferred to the Dantu District Police Station and interrogated overnight. After that, she was detained and held incommunicado in the basement of a hotel for more than 20 days.

On 4 March 2018, a petitioner was taken from Haining (Jiaxing, Zhejiang) by police from Shanghai and sent back to Shanghai to be detained in a ''black jail'' in Qingpu District until 21 March 2018. The reason of the detention is to prevent him from petitioning during the ''two sessions'' of the National People's Congress and the Chinese Political Consultative Conference (NPC & CPPCC).

On 4 March 2018, a female petitioner was beaten by 4 thugs employed by the local government at her home in Luyang District (Hefei, Anhui) for the reason of ''stability maintenance''. She was severely injured with 2-6 fractured ribs and subarachnoid haemorrhage, but was only hospitalised on 11 March because the government employed people kept bringing her back from hospital. People from the local government offices denied connection with the gangsters. She reported to the police but the police refused to intervene.

On 4 March 2018, seven petitioners were taken away by the police from their rental house in Daxing District (Beijing). They were then taken away from the police station by interceptors from Luoyang and repatriated to Luoyang. Their phones were turned off and they remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 5 March 2018. The petitioners were in Beijing to petition on the wrongful convictions made by the Luoyang Politics and Law Committee Secretary and the Deputy Chief of Luoyang City Police Department.

On 4 March 2018, a civilian was beaten by police in Jianggan District (Hangzhou, Zhejiang) after having refused to go to the police station station the day before on account that he had permission to travel to Hangzhou from the Beijing Municipal Public Security Bureau. The next day 5 or 6 people returned, broke down the door to his hotel room and beat him using plastic rods and also kicked him.

On 4 March 2018, a rights defender from Panjin, Liaoning was taken away from Beijing Huangcun Underground Station in Daxing District (Beijing) by stability maintenance agents from Panjin. He remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 6 March 2018.

SOURCE: Weiquanwang; Radio Free Asia; Epoch Times
NOTES: On 4 March 2018, during the national ''two sessions'', a pro-democracy activist was ''taken on mandatory vacation'' in Qiandao Lake, together with his wife, by national security agents after being released from the Fourth Prison of Zhejiang Province in Yuhang District in Hangzhou (Zhejiang). During this period, he was placed under surveillance by the national security agents who stayed in the hotel room next to his. The activist was released after serving his sentence of seven years in prison for ''inciting subversion of state power'' on 10 February 2012.

On 4 March 2018, a female rights defender from Hangzhou Zhejiang was taken by the interceptors from the Hangzhou local government around the Beijing South Railway Station in Fengtai District (Beijing) and went incommunicado. During the Lianghui conventions, the Chinese government had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 5 March 2018, a Uyghur journalist was arrested in Yining city (Ili, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado. He was later sentenced on 5 May 2018 to 19 years and 10 months of prison for terrorism and inciting hatred and ethnic discrimination and helping criminals. Some sources believe the motivation for his detention to be more related to his profession or because his son is studying abroad.

On 5 March 2018, a Shanghainese human rights defender was sent back to Shanghai by police while he was taking the subway in Beijing. He was then detained at a private security firm for a day before being sent to a ''black jail'' in Jiangxi province where he was detained until the First Session of the 13th National People's Congress closed on 20 March 2018.

On 5 March 2018, a rights defender was intercepted by the interceptors from the Beijing-based Office of the Shanghai Government when he was taking the underground in Beijing to petition over the inaction of the government when he didn't get his pension. After that, he was taken back to Shanghai, sent to detention in Shanghai Hongzhi Company in Jing'an District (Shanghai) by the Lujiazui Sub-district office, and taken to a ''black jail'' in Jiangxi.

On 5 March 2018, a rights defender was taken at Tiananmen Square in Dongcheng District to Jiujingzhuang, a ''black jail'' in Beijing, by the Beijing police after checking his ID, when he was on his way to petition to the representatives of National People's Congress, and he was sent back and detained in Shanghai afterwards. During the Lianghui conventions, the Shanghai Government and the police department had a nationwide stability maintenance operation, and the rights defenders were their targets.

Around 5 March 2018, the daughter of a rights defender was taken away from Xinyang, Henan and detained in a hotel (a black jail) in Xi County in Xinyang by more than ten police officers from the Xiazhuang Town and the Xiaohuidian Town police stations led by Xi County Police Chief Officer, when she intended to go to Xinyang. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 5 March 2018, a Shanghai human rights activist was abducted in Tiananmen Square in Dongcheng District (Beijing) and taken to a black prison in Beijing Jiujingzhuang Jieji Service Centre by Tiananmen Public Security Bureau police. Afterwards, she was transferred to a black prison set up by the Shanghai Municipal Government in Fengtai District (Beijing). [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]
