One activist was taken into a police car that had another Chongqing activist in it already, and the two were later transferred to another vehicle by a different group of people in uniforms. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Kazakh Ethnic Group (China); Labour Group (China); Women (China)
NOTES: On 4 May 2018, a Kazakh businesswoman from Wusu city was placed in a tiger chair during an interrogation in Gongliu county (Ili, Xinjiang) after the police called her to the station regarding changes in household registration. She often traveled between Kazakhstan and China, and had been interrogated and encountered troubles with customs since November 2017. After her interrogation, she learnt of being on a list to be sent to an ''internment camp'', and sought asylum in Kazakhstan.

On 4 May 2018, a rights defender with lung cancer was denied warm clothes to wear and was kept freezing until 3 am by police after he was called in for questioning at Dingshan Police Station in Yixing, Wuxi, Jiangsu. The maltreatment could be related to the defender's earlier refusal to be interrogated by inspectors without the necessary qualifications for the discussed subject. The event led to the worsening of the man's condition, and he had to be hospitalized the same day.

On 5 May 2018, an Uyghur man was summoned to a police booth near his place of residence in Ghulja City (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang). He was then handcuffed by the police before being sent to a re-education camp. He was later sentenced to 17 years and transferred to a prison in May 2019. According to his wife, he was likely taken away by the police for having learned the Quran from an elderly man around his village when he was 14 years old.

On 6 May 2018, a Han Chinese person drove into Tibetan farmers after a string of quarrels and fights in Deqing village of Duilongdeqing district of Lhasa, resulting in several collisions and at least 3 hospitalised with severe injuries. Earlier, this man was caught maliciously over-irrigating sowing fields belonging to Tibetan farmers. The farmers also reported ethnic discrimination in the handling of this case, where village authorities did not hold the driver accountable for his attacks.

On 6 May 2018, a female labour rights activist visiting from Shanxi was beaten up by uniform-identified police troops at her room in Motai 168 Hotel near Beijing South station (Fengtai district). Although her visit was acknowledged by law enforcement officials from her hometown, they handcuffed her before taking her to You'anmen police station and hurt her violently. Hospital examination showed that she suffered from soft tissue damage. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 6 May 2018, a Uyghur woman from Moyu municipality (Hotan, Xinjiang) was detained and sent to either Qaraqash County No. 2 or No. 4 re-education camp. Her current status is unknown and no official reason has been given for her arrest, but the reasons stated on her record discovered in a leaked government file were: being a person who served a prison sentence and later labeled as a danger to public safety due to her role in the 2008 riots in Hotan, being a member of a pan-Islamist fundamentalist organisation, and having relatives who were detained before the 'strike hard' campaign. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 7 May 2018, a house in Baihutou Village (Yinhai District, Beihai, Guangxi) was forcibly demolished by the local law enforcement authority and some government employed ''ruffians''. The owner of the house was pepper-sprayed and arrested while he tried to stop the demolition. His elderly parents were also reportedly beaten and taken by a group of unknown ruffians.

On 7 May 2018, a Xi'an woman rights defender was forcible taken and attacked by 5-6 police officers from Beijing Public Security Fengtai Branch at a motel in Fengtai District, Beijing. The defender was forcibly taken to the police station in her pajamas, and she was interrogated and beaten for three hours. The reason for the attack is unknown. After three hours, the defender was returned to the motel. In the past, the defender had been sent to a labour camp. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 8 May 2018, two people in Wuhan (Hubei) reportedly became unreachable because their friend, a well-known political dissident in China, was about to be tried on the 11 May 2018 in Wuhan. There was no further report about their whereabouts at the time of reporting on 10 May 2018. It was reported that the authorities had illegally controlled a number of people concerned with the case, to prevent them from going to the Wuhan Intermediate People's Court to attend the court case.

On 8 May 2018, a group of public security officials raided the home of a Tibetan man in Chiduo Township (Nagqu, Tibet) and forcibly took away the Tibetan man to an undisclosed location where he had since been held incommunicado. During the raid, the officials found and confiscated a hidden statue of the Dalai Lama and CD with teachings from a venerable. It was reported that his two sons were previously arrested by the authorities over the last two years. He remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 21 May 2018.

Around 9 May 2018 (between 27 April - 21 May ), all the relatives of a prosecuted Muslim villager were taken away by the authorities in Shihezi Town (Shihezi City, Xinjiang) and detained in a re-education camp. This followed after the court decision to sentence the villager to nine years in prison, on the charges of donating money and ''supporting terrorist groups''. This was part of the ramped-up efforts to persecute Muslims in Xinjiang under the pretext of ''sinicization of religion''.

On 10 May 2018, a Muslim local living in Shawan county, Xinjiang (Tarbagatay prefecture) was sent to a ''transformation through education'' camp after officers showed up at his house, and lured him to the police station under false pretexts. His family had been denied visitation rights since his arrest.

SOURCE: Asia News International; Radio Free Asia; CRLW
NOTES: On 11 May 2018, a pastor and a preacher of the Early Rain Covenant protestant church were taken away by police in Chengdu, Sichuan for ''suspected provocations'', after posting online that he is planning to host a special prayer meeting in commemoration of the victims of Sichuan earthquake on the 10th anniversary of the earthquake.

On 11 May 2018, a Shanghai rights defender was beaten by private security forces at the Shanghai People's Government Office for Calls and Letters in Huangpu after he tried petitioning for rights protection. The defender was punched and kicked uninterruptedly while police officers present at the scene were indifferent to the beatings.

On 11 May 2018, a human rights activist and singer who had been detained in police custody for more than 7 months in at Nansha, Guangdong was sent to the hospital for emergency reasons. He is suspected to have been subjected to abuse and violence by the police during his detention.

On 12 May 2018, more than 100 members of the Early Rain Covenant protestant church in Qingyang District (Chengdu, Sichuan) were arrested by police while they were participating a commemorative event for the victims of Sichuan earthquake that took place on 12 May 2008. It was also reported that police had beaten people repeatedly in the process of arresting believers and two members of the church were slapped on their faces because they were singing prayers. On the day before, a pastor and a preacher of the church were also summoned and later arrested by police because they posted the notice of the commemoration event online.

On 12 May 2018, a petitioner from Wuhan was intercepted by government officials from Wuhan City while submitting an appeal in Beijing. He was then taken away and repatriated to Wuhan by private security personnel employed by the local government officials. While he was detained at a police station in Changfeng Residential District, Wuhan, a dozen unidentified persons arrived at the police station to transfer the petitioner to a ''black jail''. When the petitioner resisted, the unidentified persons stabbed his left wrist with a knife. Due to his injury, he was instead sent to the hospital where they found two ruptured tendons.

On 13 May 2018, a Kazakh man (a Kazakhstani green card holder) from Habahe County (Altay Prefecture, Xinjiang) was taken away by the authorities and sent to a re-education camp, reportedly for ''disloyalty to China''. He was still recovering from his surgical treatment for oral cancer at a hospital at the time when he was taken away. He was formally released in December 2018 and had since returned to Kazakhstan.

Around 13 May 2018, a government employee was transferred from his criminal detention at an unreported location in Shenzhen and held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL). He was arrested by the Shenzhen police on 13 April 2018, on the grounds of ''inciting subversion of state power''.

On 13 May 2018, two female members of the LGBT community were beaten by 7 to 8 security guards at the 798 Art Zone in Chaoyang District (Beijing), while they were out distributing rainbow badges and flyers to raise awareness about the upcoming International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia on 17 May 2018. The assault happened after a security guard refused to put on the rainbow badge, and got into an altercation with the female LGBT members. One of them were reportedly pushed to the ground during the assault. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 15 May 2018, a citizen was arrested at home at Lixia District (Jinan, Shandong Province) by local police and has been detained since then without a trial for over 11 months. He was working as a rights defender.

On 15 May 2018, a human rights activist was summoned to a police station in Baqiao Town, Dadukou District (Chongqing), for questioning related to her partner, who was reportedly held in custody by the police for his activism under the environmental group Green Leaf Action. It was reported that she was slapped by the police several times during the 20 hours of interrogation, when she repeatedly requested for the police to produce a written summons. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders][women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

Around 15 May 2018 (month of), a Kazakh journalist was arrested in Kuytun (Ili, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado, reportedly in a re-education camp. It was reported that her sister and brother were also detained. She was later sentenced to 19 years at Kunes prison and is likely undertaking forced labour. The reasons for her detention and subsequent sentence are unknown. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

Around 16 May 2018 (month of), a Uyghur woman was allegedly tortured by the authorities while detained in a re-education camp in Xinyuan County (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang). According to the victim, authorities allegedly pushed a stick into her genitals that produced electric shocks. The victim also said that on the same day, another female cellmate was taken to a separate room where she was raped. The detainee was reportedly first taken away by the authorities and sent to a re-education camp on 9 March 2018. The testimony by the victim has been highly controversial and the authorities dispute it.

Around 16 May 2018 (month of), several officers from the security bureau took a human rights defender away from his home in Guangzhou. He has not been heard from for more than half a year since then and is suspected to have been disappeared.

On 16 May 2018, at a hearing for the ''709 crackdown'' at the Beijing Lawyers Association Chaoyang Lawyer Service Center in Chaoyang District (Beijing), a photographer from the Hong Kong-based Now TV was violently pushed to the ground by three plainclothes police officers, and handcuffed by two uniformed officers. It was reported that he was beaten by ''between five to six'' police officers until he was bleeding. A human rights lawyer (the defendant) was also beaten by the police when he attempted to stop the assault of the journalist. Both of them were then forcibly dragged into a van. The lawyer was detained for 5-6 hours, while the journalist was released four hours later, reportedly after the State Council's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office had ''mediated'' at the request of the Hong Kong government.

Around 16 May 2018 (month of), a petitioner from Hubei Qianjiang was kidnapped by some unidentified people hired by the government in You'anmen Residential District in Fengtai District of Beijing. It was not clear the reason for the abduction.

Around 16 May 2018 (month of), a Christian woman was physically abused and sexually harassed by the police during her interrogation and month-long imprisonment in Jiujiang city, Jiangxi. During her interrogation, she was questioned without rest, sleep, food or water, and repeatedly hit on the face with leather shoes. In prison, she was forced to sit naked - from the torso upwards - in the main hall where surveillance cameras were in operation. Guards beat her with plastic objects and tied her up in a bathroom, such that she would bruise, go numb and couldn't walk. At night, they would put insects over her and arrange for prisoners to sleep next to her and pinch her to cause severe distress and insomnia. After her release in June 10, her left arm was left permanently damaged.

Around 16 May 2018 (month of), a Christian couple were arrested at their house in Xinjiang by two community workers and two policemen and sent to a ''transformation through education'' camps. The husband was released by August, but his wife was not and continued to be held at an unspecified camp.

Around 16 May 2018 (month of), a Uyghur business founder of a language and vocational school and a financial services company in Korla county (Bayingolin Mongol Autonomous, Xinjiang) was detained and sent to an ''internment camp'' in Hejing county. It was reported that although the language school only used state-approved teaching materials, it offered classes in Turkish in 2014-2015 due to growing interest among Uyghurs to visit Turkey, which was among the blacklisted countries for travel by Uyghurs.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); Farmers (China); Muslim Group (China)
NOTES: Around 16 May 2018 (month of), a Uyghur farmer from Bulaq village of Putao (Uzumchilik) town of Gaochang district (Turpan, Xinjiang) was sent to ''political vocational training centre'' for making a pilgrimage to Mecca in the past, which was seen as a violation of Articles 123 and 124 of the Penal Code. He was released in early 2019 with compromised health, and placed under house arrest. At least nine of her family members experienced being sent to camps or restricted from leaving their villages.

On 18 May 2018, a human rights lawyer residing in Shanghai was reportedly missing after issuing an appeal at 5am to netizens to change their profile picture on WeChat into the portrait of another human rights lawyer to express solidarity with the lawyer who had been illegally detained. The lawyer remained uncontactable at 11pm on the same day.

On 19 May 2018, a man was reportedly assaulted by the police after being taken away to the Jimazhuang Police Station in Xihu District (Nanchang City, Jiangxi Province). It was reported that he was dragged into the police car by three plainclothes officers, while he was visiting a prostitute. He was pronounced dead after being detained for one hour at the police station, leading his family members and netizens to believe that he had been abused during his short detention at the station. The police did not deny the death of the man, but did not provide reasons to the cause of the man's death.

On 23 May 2018, five people were intercepted by police officers in Guangdong Province while they were making on their way back from the home of a Guangzhou-based pro-democracy activist. All five of them were reportedly assaulted by the police officers, where one of them sustained injuries to his head, waist and legs. It was reported that the victim had frequently visited the pro-democracy activist and his father to care for the activist's father who suffered from schizophrenia. They were later taken to Baitang Police Station for interrogation.

On 23 May 2018, a female petitioner was tied to a bed and assaulted while detained at a 'black jail' in a four-storey building located in a valley of the 3303 military industrial district in Jiangxia district (Wuhan, Hubei). Her supervisors were allegedly government-hired farmers who spoke with a Honghu district accent, claiming to be sent by the 'Legal Education Base of the Six Central-Southern Provinces'. They pressed against her and scrubbed her face with a plastic slipper until she bled. She was repeatedly tortured while abducted between 7 Mar and 17 Oct 2018.

On 23 May 2018, a disabled female petitioner from Jiangsu Yancheng City was intercepted by government personnel in Beijing and detained in a hotel in Dahongmen Residential District. It was reported that she and her husband consistently submitted petitions in Beijing regarding the resettlement of their house.

On 24 May 2018, a petitioner and her husband from Tongde Village were intercepted in the suburbs of Beijing, and taken away by an interceptor from Yancheng City and local government officials from Tongde Village and Datong Town. They were subsequently detained in a ''black jail'' in Fengtai District. The petitioner had been petitioning for her rights for nearly six years, after she was left paralysed following an attack by triad members.

On 25 May 2018, two Christian men experienced severe physical torture during a police interrogation at their own church in Lanzhou, Gansu. One of them was arrested at the local market market without the other's knowledge, while the other was ambushed when he made his way back to their church. Both were interrogated in the church storage room, beaten severely and their hair and teeth were pulled out with pliers. On the same day, another Christian couple was detained and tortured in a similar manner. All were sent to a detention facility on May 28 and detained for at least 15 days.

On 25 May 2018, an activist was attacked by 3 national security officers in a hotel in Guiyang City, Guizhou Province, where he and his wife were being placed under house arrest ahead of the anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen movement. The officers stormed into their room, took him away and beat him during the scuffle. Given that he was suspected of publishing WeChat posts about June 4th event recently, the police searched his body for his phone at a national security office in Yunyan District and forced him to open his house for further search. He was eventually sent back to the hotel room after midnight. The couple was placed under house arrest for 18 days in total between 25 May and 11 June.

On 27 May 2018, six female Christians residing in a church in Lanzhou, Gansu were tied up and beaten by the police until severe injuries were sustained. Officers barged in while these women were still in their nightwear, and two babies were in the room during the incident. All were sent to a detention facility on May 28 and detained for at least 15 days.

On 28 May 2018, 12 Protestant Christians of the Early Rain Covenant Church were detained and attacked by the police at the Caojia Alley Police Station in Jinniu District (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province). It was reported that the founding pastor Wang Yi was handcuffed with his hands behind his back and forcibly dragged to a room by the police. His chest might have been hurt. Other people were pushed on the ground, stepped on by the police and handcuffed. They were all released on the next day around 1 am.

On 28 May 2018, a Uyghur man from Moyu municipality (Hotan, Xinjiang) was detained and sent to the Qaraqash No. 2 re-education camp. His current status is unknown and no official reason has been given for his arrest, but the reason stated on his record discovered in a leaked government file was for having served a full 'medium-level' sentence. It is reported that he was approved for release, but is still currently in camp.

On 28 May 2018, a female activist from Wuxi, Jiangsu was inspected by police when she was visiting a friend in Beijing and was forcibly detained in the Beijing Jiujingzhuang Jieji Service Centre (a black jail) in Fengtai, Beijing. She disappeared after being taken away from the Service Centre by people from the Beijing-based Wuxi Government Office. It is suspected that she has been sent back to Wuxi but her whereabouts were unknown.

On 29 May 2018, a Shandong woman who had just arrived at Beijing South Railway Station in Fengtai District (Beijing) for a hearing was forcibly taken away by 12 people, including the head of the Office of the Weifang City Government in Beijing, a member of Xiguan Residential District Office and some plain-clothed policemen. She was then detained incommunicado in a hotel in Weicheng District (Weifang City, Shandong Province). She was transferred to a rehabilitation hospital on 2 June 2018.

Around 29 May 2018 (as reported), 2 retired soldiers were beaten by a traffic police when they drove through a security checkpoint in Zhuzhou City of Hunan Province. The police also insulted them with ''humiliating language.''

On 29 May 2018, a disabled petitioner was held incommunicado and under 24 hours of surveillance by thugs hired by the police in a hotel in Beijing. It was part of a national campaign by the authorities to suppress dissidents ahead of the 30th anniversary of Tiananmen Square protests.

On 29 May 2018, a business woman was attacked by urban management officers and unidentified individuals in Gangzha District (Nantong City, Jiangsu Province), following a dispute between them over the location of a billboard. The urban management officers ordered 7 to 8 gangsters to drag the woman on the ground and pulled her on a stone. The officers confiscated her billboard.

Around 1 June 2018 (beginning of month), a female petitioner from Hunan Linxiang were intercepted by the police while petitioning in Beijing and were sent to Jiujingzhuang ''black jail''. She was detained in Jiujingzhuang and the Linxiang government office in Beijing for a few days before sending back to Linxiang.

Around 1 June 2018 (beginning of month), a member of The Church of Almighty God was arrested in Jiangsu province and secretly tortured and interrogated in a hotel. She was tied to an iron chair and subjected to sleep deprivation for three days and nights. As of 31 July 2018, she had been released but continued to be closely monitored.

Around 1 June 2018 (between 28 May-5 June), a man was administered psychotropic drugs at the Dingtao People's Hospital in Dingtao district (Heze, Shandong). He had been forcibly admitted incommunicado from 28 May to 5 Jun by the CPC Secretary and Chief of Yangdian village, Dutang town of Dingtao county. It was reported that he appealed on behalf of his father three times that year, resulting in three coerced psychiatric ward admissions.

Around 1 June 2018 (beginning of month), police raided the home of a dissident who had been preparing to commemorate the 29th anniversary of the June 4th massacre. The dissident was then forcibly admitted to a mental hospital in Rongchang District (Chongqing) by ''stability maintenance agents'' from the local government and held there for 3 months.

Around 1 June 2018 (beginning of month), state security forces took a prominent Uyghur philanthropist, his brother and two business partners into custody from their homes in Urumqi. The whereabouts, condition or reasons for arrest were unknown and not provided by authorities, but family members reportedly heard that the men were targeted for their perceived ties to a Uyghur education fund for study abroad, and had been transferred to a facility in Ghulja (Yining), Ili since their arrest.

On 2 June 2018, local law enforcement officers arrested over 40 Buddhist worshippers in Panlong district of Kunming, Yunnan after they were tipped about ''an illegal gathering'' - reading scripture in a tent on a mountain. A vehicle full of scripture and other household items was seized, and a detainee was injured when they were brought in for interrogations. At an unspecified date after their release, urban management personnel returned to the mountain and demolished two dwellings.

Around 3 June 2018 (between 31 May and 6 June), three dissidents and one female dissident-cum-journalist were ''taken on mandatory vacation'' by the police in Beijing due to the stability maintenance before the 29th anniversary of the Tiananmen demonstrations on 4 June 1989. One was taken to Huangshan City in Anhui and then placed under house arrest back in Beijing on 5 June. Another was taken to Harbin City in Heilongjiang and then transferred to Jilin Province. Another was taken to Guizhou Province, and last reported in Changsha, Hunan Province. It was reported that the extension of their ''vacation'' after 4 June might be due to the stability maintenance during the Shanghai Cooperation Organization Summit in Qingdao between 9 and 10 June.

On 3 June 2018, an activist from Suining county was ''taken on mandatory vacation'' by Suining county law enforcement and government officials - the police, the Party Secretary of the Political and Legal Commission and guobao state security officers - from his residence in Zhongxinxiaoqu of Changsha prefecture (Hunan) due to the stability maintenance before the 29th anniversary of the Tiananmen demonstrations on 4 June 1989. He was taken to Shaoshan City, Zhangshu Village of Xiangyin County, Changle Village of Miluo City and Changsha City before returning to Suining County on 8 June 2018. His phone was confiscated during the journey.

On 3 June 2018, a human rights defender was abused while in custody at the Xicheng detention centre in Beijing. Despite his medical history of high blood pressure and cardiovascular and neurological diseases, his arms and legs were chained with torture instruments that prevented him from standing upright. He suffered injuries and became ill after they confiscated all his medications, and denied him a blanket after adjusting the air-conditioner to freezing temperatures.

On 3 June 2018, 2 human rights defenders were held incommunicado and placed under house arrest in a hotel by the Liwan District (Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province) police. They were transferred to Guangzhou Liwan Detention House around 15 June. It was reported that their arrests were due to the stability maintenance before the anniversary of the Tiananmen demonstrations on 4 June 1989.

On 4 June 2018, a female petitioner was intercepted and attacked by around 9 stability maintenance officers at Chongqing North railway station in Yubei (Chongqing) prior her train ride to Jinan. She was dragged onto a car, beaten up and detained at Longshan Road Residents' Committee Centre for the night.

On 4 June 2018, an underground Protestant church, the Early Rain Covenant Church, in Qingyang District (Chengdu, Sichuan) was stormed by hundreds of police from Chengdu's Caoshijie police station and officials from the religious affairs bureau, before a planned evening service to commemorate the Tiananmen Square anniversary. When a preacher tried to stop the police, the police got hold of him, pinched his neck and body, pushed him against a glass, slapped him around the head and attacked his cheek and forehead. A few church members were also beaten by the police. A total of 17 church members, including 4 preachers, were arrested on the ground of ''illegal assembly'' and released on the next day.

On 5 June 2018, a Shanghai female human rights defender was intercepted by officials of the Shanghai Government Office in Beijing, then escorted back to Shanghai and detained in a ''black jail'' in Putuo District for a short detention. After that, she was sent to Jinyang Xincun Police Station and officially arrested. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 5 June 2018, a police officer from Zibo City, Shandong was attacked by six assailants outside the Shandong Provincial Public Security Bureau in Shinan District (Qingdao City, Shandong Province). It was reported that the assailants were thugs hired by the director of the Zhoucun District's Public Security Bureau, and the police officer sustained 17 scars on his body. The police officer had attempted to report the director on corruption, bribery and embezzlement of funds. This was the fifth time the police officer had been attacked for the same reason.

On 5 June 2018, a female former employee of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China was taken by the police in Beijing to Jiujingzhuang Petition Service Centre, then handed over to officers from the Hunan Liaison Office, and detained at a black jail in Beijing. It was reported that she had been protesting against the ''fraudulent'' employee buyout package offered by the bank since 2004.

On 7 June 2018, a female petitioner, who was placed under house arrest, was attacked by 3 security personnel appointed by the government in the Huang Ni Tou village in the Guangyi Residential District of the Chong'an District, Liangxi District (Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province) when she demanded to leave her house. She was seriously injured as a result of the attack.

On 7 June 2018, 1 Shanghai petitioner was detained in a black jail and held incommunicado by the Qingdao police in Qingdao. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the 2018 Shanghai Cooperation Organisation Summit in Qingdao on June 9-10.

On 7 June 2018, 11 Shanghai female petitioners were taken away from Qingdao by the Shanghai police and held incommunicado in Shanghai. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the 2018 Shanghai Cooperation Organisation Summit in Qingdao on June 9-10.

On 8 June 2018, a Kazakh woman was detained by the authorities in Shawan County (Tacheng Prefecture, Xinjiang) and taken to a re-education camp. It was later confirmed on 5 June 2019 that she was sentenced to 20 years in prison. An official incarceration notice was issued on 14 June 2019 stating that she was sentenced for ''using superstition to undermine law enforcement'' and ''gathering a crowd to disturb social order'', and had been transferred to a women's prison.

On 8 June 2018, more than 10 civilians from Shanghai, including one female rights defender from Changning district, travelled to Qingdao city (Shandong Province) and were subsequently held incommunicado by the Qingdao police at the Qingdao Youth Training Center ''black jail'' in Shinan District, Qingdao City. This was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the 2018 Shanghai Cooperation Organisation Summit in Qingdao on June 9-10. The group was allegedly travelling for leisure.

On 8 June 2018, after being forcibly sent back from Qingdao by the Qingdao police on 7 June, 2 petitioners, who were husband and wife, were interrogated at the Pudong District Police Station (Shanghai) and then detained in a black jail in the Shanghai Angle Bay Vacationland in Chongming District of Shanghai City. They were told that they would be released on 11 June 2018. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the 2018 Shanghai Cooperation Organisation Summit in Qingdao on June 9-10.

On 9 June 2018, a Uyghur woman from Kashgar prefecture (Xinjiang) (coded as Kashi City) died after being placed in police custody on 4 Jun, presumably for traveling to the United Arab Emirates, which was among the blacklisted countries for travel by Uyghurs. Her family was taken to Yuandong Hospital before doctors informed them of her death and that an autopsy would be performed. Authorities stated that she had a heart condition that prevented her from coping with the interrogation. The final burial was done in secrecy and supervised by officials. The family was offered a ''death payment,'' and the only time they saw the corpse was before the autopsy.

Around 9 June 2018, during the 2018 Shanghai Cooperation Organisation Summit in Qingdao, Shandong a human rights activist begging in the area was forcibly sent back to Shanghai by people from the Shanghai Government. He was first held at the Meiyuan police station in Shanghai, before being handed over to triad members who kept him in a ''black jail'' in Changxing Island, Shanghai. He was beaten violently during his three-day detention.

Around 9 June 2018 (between 7 - 11 June), a female human rights defender (who had reportedly petitioned before) was beaten up and had her right eye injured during the 5-day detention at a ''black jail'' in Shanghai. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 9 June 2018, more than 20 people led by the head of Yancheng City Dafeng District Public Security Bureau forcibly took away 2 petitioners at a hotel in Dahongmen Residential District of Fengtai District of Beijing, where the petitioners, also husband and wife, had been illegally detained since 23 May. The police wrapped the nude, disabled wife in a bedsheet and rejected her to be dressed up by a female officer. The wife was incontinent and almost lost her breath before she was sent to a hospital. The police took the husband to the police office, made him sit on the torture instrument known as the ''tiger bench'' and deprived him of food and drink. Ultimately, they were both released within days. The husband's left knee was injured severely and had to be treated in hospital.

On 11 June 2018, a 5th grade student and his mother were beaten up by school authorities at a primary school in Yilan county of Harbin city after students were questioned and forced to confess their religious beliefs. The school broadcasted their Catholic faith on campus, causing classmates and teachers to ostracise the boy. Internal reports state that this practice of interrogating students had become common since March 2018.

On 12 June 2018, a retired, disabled soldier was beaten up by 4 police officers at his house in Jiqing Township (Deyang City, Sichuan Province) for planning to attend a court hearing of another retired soldier in Ya'an City. After he was cuffed at his hands and feet, and sent to the Jiqing Township Police Station, police officers beat him again. His whole body was hurt, his face was sprayed with pepper water, and he was sent to the hospital after that. News of the assault spread in the veteran community, and sparked a subsequent protest at the station.

Around 15 June 2018 (month of), a Uyghur man was arrested in Yining City (Ili, Xinjiang) and taken to a re-education camp. It was reported by his childhood friend on 2 October 2019 that he was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

On 15 June 2018, a female petitioner died after stability maintenance personnel captured her in Wuyi Road Residential District of Qiaodong District (Xingtai City, Hebei Province) to prevent her from staging a planned petition in Beijing. After being intercepted, she demanded to take a breath because she felt chest discomfort. However, the stability maintenance personnel forcibly pushed her onto a car. It was reported that she had a heart attack and lost her consciousness, but the stability maintenance personnel did not perform CPR on her.

Around 15 June 2018 (month of), the local police called in eight believers of a Sola Fide church in Huaihua City, Hunan Province and forced them to participate in ''transformation through education'' classes.

Around 15 June 2018 (month of), an Uyghur man was taken away by the authorities, likely from his place of residence in Tianshan District (Urumqi, Xinjiang) and detained in a camp in Atush. He was later transferred to a prison in September 2018 and sentenced to 20 years, reportedly for fasting during Ramadan 2018. His relatives were known to have last visited him in December 2018.

On 15 June 2018, in the early hours of the morning, an officer of the Zhangjiakou City Wuyi Road Subdistrict, along with dozens of police officers, besieged a hotel in Beijing where 21 petitioners from Zhangjiakou City were spending the night before petitioning. The police dragged the villagers onto a truck to prevent them from petitioning, and a female petitioner died during the process. The direct cause of death was unknown.

On 18 June 2018, the police arrested a married Muslim couple while they were raising the national flag on their farm in Kumul (Hami city), Xinjiang, and sent them to separate camps in Yizhou district and Huangtian Farm respectively. The wife suffered from lupus and had relapsed before her arrest, unfortunately, her eldest daughter said that her requests to let her mother leave to see a doctor had been denied. The reason for their arrest was unknown - while the husband practiced daily worship, the wife did not know much about Islam. The wife's brothers and sisters had already been sent to camps.

Around 18 June 2018, during the Chinese Dragon Boat Festival, it was reported that there were Uyghurs in Aksu Region (Xinjiang) who were sent to ''deradicalization centres'' by the local authority for the reason that they refused to cooperate in the governmental campaigns to assimilate the Uyghurs into Han culture by forcing them to make and eat Zongzi, a traditional food from Han culture on the Chinese Dragon Boat Festival. Around 40 Uyghurs were sent to ''deradicalization centres'' in Hotan, Kashi, Aksu, and other regions for the same reason.

Around 18 June 2018, during the Chinese Dragon Boat Festival, it was reported that there were Uyghurs in Aksu Region (Xinjiang) who were sent to ''deradicalization centres'' by the local authority for the reason that they refused to cooperate in the governmental campaigns to assimilate the Uyghurs into Han culture by forcing them to make and eat Zongzi, a traditional food from Han culture on the Chinese Dragon Boat Festival. Around 40 Uyghurs were sent to ''deradicalization centres'' in Hotan, Kashi, Aksu, and other regions for the same reason.

Around 18 June 2018, during the Chinese Dragon Boat Festival, it was reported that there were Uyghurs in Aksu Region (Xinjiang) who were sent to ''deradicalization centres'' by the local authority for the reason that they refused to cooperate in the governmental campaigns to assimilate the Uyghurs into Han culture by forcing them to make and eat Zongzi, a traditional food from Han culture on the Chinese Dragon Boat Festival. Around 40 Uyghurs were sent to ''deradicalization centres'' in Hotan, Kashi, Aksu, and other regions for the same reason.

On 21 June 2018, more than 10 unidentified people hired by the local government kidnapped a woman and her son from their house in Yangjiabang of Xishan District (Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province). The woman and son were detained in a ''black jail' under the surveillance by 4 civilians hired by the government. 2 houses owned by the family were demolished immediately by the authorities after they were kidnapped.

On 25 June 2018, a total of 12 Fuzhou petitioners were intercepted separately by some fully-geared railway police and dozens of ''black security guards'' hired by Fuzhou government at the platform of Beijing West Railway Station in Fengtai District of Beijing. The police arrested 4 petitioners and sent 2 of them back to Fuzhou. 4 petitioners disappeared and lost contact. It was believed that 4 petitioners escaped successfully.

On 26 June 2018, about 40 officers from three police stations arrested a woman in Changzhou (Jiangsu) who worshipped The Church of Almighty God. They prohibited her husband from visiting her, and her whereabouts would remain unknown for at least two more months.

On 27 June 2018, a Shanghaiese woman was beaten up by a local policemen at the entrance of the Shanghai Municipal Public Security Bureau in Xuhui district after shouting her grievances of their delay and refusal to process her legalised hukou assignment transfer since 2009. She was taken into custody for eight hours, and sustained injuries to her head, chest and broke two ribs.

On 27 June 2018, a female rights defender-cum-forced evictee was cuffed and tied to a tiger bench at the Guanggang Police Station at Liangxi district (Wuxi, Jiangsu) after police officers arrested from her home and charged with ''picking quarrels and provoking trouble'' without any evidence. She and her husband had been targeted by local authorities since petitioning against forced eviction and medical negligence for over a decade. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 27 June 2018, a human rights defender was beaten up by a police officer in front of the Shanghai Police Station in Huangpu District (Shanghai) while she was crying out her grievances. She sustained four fractures in her left ribs. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 27 June 2018, a policeman beat up of a female Shanghaiese rights activist after she shouted outside the Municipal Public Security Bureau in Shanghai (Jing'an district), airing her grievances about the processing delay of her hukou migration documents. She was hurt so hard that her ribs broke, and she had wounds on her forehead and arms. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 27 June 2018, a Shanghai female human rights defender, who was also a petitioner-cum-forced evictee, was attacked by a Public Security Bureau police officer in front of the Shanghai Municipal Public Security Bureau in Jing'an district (Jingan, Shanghai), causing her to suffer from rib fractures. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 27 June 2018, police forces arrested a Shanghai petitioner who had submitted a petition near State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng District of Beijing and sent him to Jiujingzhuang ''black jail''. On the next day, the petitioner was sent back to Shanghai and became incommunicado after being under control by the Wujiaochang Police office.

Around 30 June 2018 (between 15 June - 14 July), a member of the Church of Almighty God, who was arrested in Xuzhou City (Jiangsu) on 15 June 2018 and interrogated by police, was reportedly abused by the police. According to accounts of those who saw her at the police station, she was not able to walk steadily and the corners of her mouth were black and blue--clear evidence that she had been abused by the police.

Around 30 June 2018 (between 22 June 2018 - 8 July 2018), local police arrested a female Christian believer in Gongyi City (Zhengzhou, Henan). During her 20-day detention, she was repeatedly beaten up and tortured by the police to force the believer to reveal information. After she was released on 8 July 2018, she remained under surveillance of the authorities.

On 1 July 2018, a Uyghur man from Moyu municipality (Hotan, Xinjiang) was detained and sent to a re-education camp. His current status is unknown and no official reason has been given for his arrest, but the reasons stated on his record discovered in a leaked government file were: applying for a passport and having 3 children more than allowed by family planning policy. It is reported that he was approved for release in early 2019 due to family difficulties, but is currently still in camp.

Around 1 July 2018 (beginning of month), local officials raided an ancestral shrine (ancestral shrines are associated with China's folk religions) located in Changlong village, Duchang County (Jiujiang, Jiangxi), beating up several villagers and demolished the shrine. 4 villagers were hospitalised as a result of the assault, with one villager sustaining four broken ribs.

Around 1 July 2018, a Kazakh man (a government-approved imam) was arrested by the authorities in Ashili County (Changji, Xinjiang) and taken to a re-education camp. According to his brother in law, he was detained in the re-education camp for 20 days, which left him severely injured and in need of medical attention, although the reason for his injuries were not known. Following 10 days of treatment and spending 3 days at home, he was called back to the camp by the authorities. During this period, his wife reportedly committed suicide in an attempt to stop the authorities from sending him back to the camp. The case was recorded by the authorities as murder, and he was later declared guilty of murder on 5 March 2019 and sentenced to 30 years in prison according to his relatives.

Around 1 July 2018 (beginning of month), a businessman from Changyi, Shandong went missing after travelling to Beijing to submit a petition about the Changyi police's reluctance to open a case on the fraud committed by his business partner. It is not the first time authorities had intervene, monitored or a forcibly removed him from protest activities, and as of 22 July 2018, this time, he had gone incommunicado for weeks.

On 2 July 2018, a man from Beihai, Guangxi, his mother and brother, were arrested by the police in Changle Town, Hepu County (Beihai City, Guangxi Province) for ''picking quarrels and provoking trouble''. His mother and brother were then held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL), before they were released on 10 August 2018. The man was subsequently tried in secret on 26 November 2018 and sentenced to two years in prison.

On 2 July 2018, two rights defenders from Xingtai City, Hebei were taken by the local national security agents on a ''mandatory vacation'' to a rural farmhouse and detained there for the reason that they were planning to hold their wedding on the anniversary of the 709 crackdown. Several people who were related to 709 crackdown had been ''taken on mandatory vacation'' due to the upcoming anniversary of the incident.

On 3 July 2018, a female civil rights activist was attacked and injured by several people in Runzhou District (Zhenjiang City, Jiangsu Province) when she demanded to see the doctors. She was also monitored by interceptors while in hospital. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

SOURCE: CRLW; The Stand News; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 4 July 2018, a woman splashed ink onto a government poster with President Xi Jinping's face at HNA Tower in Lujiazui of Pudong district, Shanghai. She livestreamed the event online as a protest against the authoritarianism of China's ruling leadership, setting off copycat protest events across social media nationwide. She disappeared later on the same day and lost communication after police showed up at her apartment door.
Around 5 July 2018 (between 2 - 9 July), local police beat up and tortured a civil rights activist during his detention in the police station in Hepu (Beihai, Guangxi).

Around 7 July 2018 (as reported), a renowned Hunanese media commentator was being held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) by Chenzhou city (Hunan) police in an undisclosed location. Chen disappeared and lost contact several days after his 25 June 2018 reporting on the professional negligence and malfeasance of the Shaoyang Commission for Discipline Inspection Secretary. His wife and two brothers were also arrested.

On 13 July 2018, believers of the Seventh-Day Adventist church - which was affiliated with the Three-Self Movement - tried to block more than 20 police officers from entering their church in Caigou township, Biyang county (Zhumadian, Henan). The police did not succeed in taking down religious signage, but three elderly Christians were injured and hospitalised as a result of confrontations between the two parties.

On 13 July 2018, a Chinese artist was abducted by the police in Shangri-La City (Dequen, Yunnan) and placed under incommunicado house arrest in a village on the border between Yunnan and Tibet. The police might have abducted him due to his advocacy for a protester.

Around 16 July 2018 (month of), a member of the Church of Almighty God was arrested by the police at her place of residence in Jilin Province. It was reported that the police violently punched her in the face at the scene of the arrest, and detained her at a local education centre. While in custody, he was interrogated about other members of the church, and beaten by the police (including using bamboo rods) when she did not provide any information about other members. She was released after ten days, but remained under residential surveillance.

On 16 July 2018, a woman who had been critical of President Xi Jinping on Twitter was forcibly sent to her hometown in Zhuzhou by Shanghai police. She was then admitted to the Zhuzhou No. 3 People's Hospital, a mental hospital in Zhuzhou City (Hunan) and was not allowed visitors on the basis that she was a ''political prisoner''. She has been kept there for at least 6 months.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); Kazakh Ethnic Group (China); CPC: Communist Party of China; Labour Group (China)
NOTES: Around 16 July 2018 (month of), a Uyghur-Kazakh man (who served as the director and Communist Party deputy secretary of the Xinjiang People's Publishing House from 2005-2015) was arrested by the authorities, likely in Xinjiang Region. He has since been held incommunicado with his whereabouts and the status of his case unknown. The official reason for his arrest was not known, although according to a staff member from the Xinjiang Youth Publishing House, he was ''implicated in separatism and religious extremism activities'' while working at the publishing house.

Around 16 July 2018 (month of), a Kazakh man from Tacheng City (Ili Kazak Autonomous, Xinjiang) was taken away by the authorities and sent to a re-education camp. The reason for his detention was not known. On 12 June 2019, he was sentenced to 2.5 years in prison for publishing 2-3 books, although it was reported that these books were formally approved. Some sources allege that he was transferred to a re-education camp in Wusu to serve out his 'prison' sentence.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); Women (China); Labour Group (China)
NOTES: Around 16 July 2018 (month of), a Uyghur woman (a well-known poet and chief editor at the Kashgar Publishing House) was arrested by the police in Kashgar City, Xinjiang (coded as Kashi City) and sent to a re-education camp. It was reported that she had been arrested for her involvement in editing a 2015 novel by a well-known Uyghur writer. She was reportedly released in December 2020.

On 16 July 2018, a union organiser working for a private technology company Jiashi (Shenzhen Jasic Technology Co. Ltd) was beaten up at work by an unidentified group of men who seemed to be affiliated with the company. When he reported the incident to the Shenzhen Pingshan police, he was detained and released only when fellow workers came asking for his whereabouts. Back in Mid-May, Jiashi workers had been approved by the government-backed Pingshan district union to setup their own union due to the company's history of illegal and abusive management. By 12 July, the union-to-be received 89 member applications.

On 17 July 2018, a prosecutor at Yiwu (Jinhua city, Zhejiang Province) was severely beaten by his colleagues and superior in his office because he reported on a local unauthorised construction project. He was later sent to hospital and forced to leave his job.

On 18 July 2018, a victim of ''electronic harassment/mind control'' was forcibly admitted to a mental hospital in Nanchang City (Jiangxi) by police after petitioning in Beijing. His family was not allowed to visit him. He had previously participated in a mass gathering to file a complaint against ''electronic harassment''.

On 18 July 2018, a rights activist and organiser was taken away from a police station in Nanchang prefecture (Jiangxi) (coded to Honggutan) and forcibly admitted by ten police officers to the Jiangxi Province Mental Hospital. He was targeted after taking part in a collective petition in Beijing from 25-30 Jun with nearly 100 psychological torture victims.

On 18 July 2018, a female Church of Almighty God member, who had worked in Japan for the past three years, was taken away by a male airport officer who came onboard as soon as her flight landed at the Pudong International Airport in Shanghai. She is being held incommunicado at a jail in Shandong, situation unknown.

On 18 July 2018, a petitioner and his mother were beaten up by 6-7 triad members hired by Yueyang Liaison Office in Beijing and Xiangyin county government in a hotel in Beijing. They were forcibly taken back to Xiangyin and kept in an apartment, where they were guarded by 4-5 people.

Around 19 July 2018 (as reported), Mongolian Chinese herders and rights activists clashed with private security forces in Jalaid Banner, Inner Mongolia. The security forces were hired by a Chinese-owned company (name unknown) accused of polluting local grasslands through mining activities. Mining activities had been banned, but remained active due to public-private collusion between the company and corrupt officials at lower levels of government.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Labour Group (China); Police Forces of China (2012-)
NOTES: On 20 July 2018, in the morning, six workers and union organisers arriving for work at Jiashi (Shenzhen Jasic Technology Co. Ltd) were violently thrown out of the factory by private security forces. When police forces arrived, they were beaten up by them and illegally detained at Yanziling police station.

On 21 July 2018, three Kazakhs were taken by the police in Dushanzi District (Karamay, Xinjiang) and sent to a ''political education camp'', on the grounds of having phone contact with a Kazakhstani national. Previously, their passports were confiscated by the local authority in April 2017, and they pleaded for help from the foreign ministry and the embassy in China of Kazakhstan. Three people were the wife, the brother, and the friend of a Kazakh who was born in Dushanzi District, and he had been able to contact his wife and brother until 20 July 2018.

Around 24 July 2018 (as reported), one of the organisers who initiated a rights-defending group for Changsheng vaccine victims in Chongqing was incommunicado, possibly in relation to another organiser who was detained by the police for 4 hours on 23 July for her plan to petition at the local public health bureau that same day.

On 25 July 2018, a rights activist cum parent was taken away by the police at Zhanjiang West Railway Station in Mazhang District (Zhanjiang, Guangdong) as he was about to petition in Beijing regarding the Changchun Changsheng vaccine scandal. He was forcibly detained at Royal International Hotel in Suixi county.

Around 25 July 2018, a Shanghaiese human rights defender residing in Pudong New District (Shanghai) was suspected to be missing after his friends found that he had not been online. They also failed to reach him at his residence in Pudong New District, Shanghai. The rights defender had been involved in the ''Toilet Revolution'', and was suspected to have been kidnapped around 25 July 2018 and had been incommunicado for at least 17 days at the time of reporting on 11 August.
On 27 July 2018, a Shanghaiese veteran was taken away by the police from Xujiaohui station in Xuhui district (Shanghai). He was detained incommunicado for over 24 hours as of the reporting.

On 27 July 2018, a Shanghaiese veteran was taken away by the police from Tilanqiao station in Hongkou district (Shanghai). He resisted and was beaten up by the police as a result, and was detained incommunicado for over 24 hours as of the reporting.

On 27 July 2018, many people, including Liu's wife, disappeared incommunicado after gathering at Yanziling police station in Shenzhen to demanding the release of Liu Penghua and other union organisers.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2012-); Private Security Forces (China)
NOTES: On 28 July 2018, in the evening, a few days before the People's Liberation Army Establishment Day, multiple veteran activists were abducted from their hotel in Xuzhou, Jiangsu by public security, government officials and ''black security guards.''

On 30 July 2018, a female human rights activist was attacked by an unidentified laser weapon while attending a court hearing in Fuzhou city (Cangshan district), Fujian as a member of the public. After experiencing immediate symptoms included pain in her head, chest, neck and spine, as well as nausea and inability to speak, she was hospitalized and underwent cranial surgery. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

Around 1 August 2018 (from 29 July - 5 August), medical workers and triad members repeatedly assaulted a petitioner, under government instruction, while he was forcibly admitted at the pyschiatric hospital in Zhushan county (Shiyan, Hubei), hitting him in the body, head and face. The victim was intercepted in Beijing on 29 Jul by officials from Chengguan village of Zhushan county, escorted to his hometown, then locked up at the village's police station prior to the hospital. The victim was a repeated target of local authorities.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Ming Pao; The Stand News; DW
NOTES: On 1 August 2018, a Chinese professor of emeritus in physics at the University of Shandong was taken away by 6-8 public security officers at his home in Jinan (Shandong province) during a phone interview with the radio network Voice of America, where he was speaking out against foreign aid and investment on the eve of Xi Jinping's presidential trip to Africa. He was held incommunicado despite efforts to confirm his safety via phone or home visits - guobao state security and private security guards took away all his personal communication devices, and he was moved between 4 different locations within the state during his 12-day detention. He returned home on 13 Aug and continued to be placed under house arrest.

On 1 August 2018, 10 civilians were taken by the police to ''Yaren Hotel'' - a ''black jail'' that in reality functions as the detention centre for the Dongshan police station - right after they got off the train in Beidaihe, Qinhuangdao city. These civilians had participated in petitions before, but this time, the purpose of their trip was simply leisure. The police claimed that petitioners were prohibited from visiting Beidaihe at the moment, and denied their requests for food and accommodation. The next day, a dozen triad members violently took their phones and IDs away, and escorted them back to their hometowns in Fuzhou. Five of them were released immediately, but another five were detained at Gaishan and Linjiang police stations until 4 August. They were denied food, water and proper explanation about why they were detained.

On 1 August 2018, a Uyghur man was transferred from a re-education camp in Urumqi, Xinjiang (coded as Shuimogou) to another re-education camp in Moyu municipality (Hotan, Xinjiang). Prior to this, he had been detained during the July 5 incident in 2009. His current status is unknown and no official reason has been given for his arrest, but the reasons stated on his record discovered in a leaked government file were: applying for a passport and having 1 or 2 children more than allowed by family planning policy. It is reported that he was approved for release in early 2019, but is still currently in camp.

Around 1 August 2018 (between 27 July and 7 August 2018), at least two male and one female Jiashi worker activist experienced physical assault and sexual harassment during their detention at Baoshan police station in Pingshan, Shenzhen. When they did not cooperate during interrogations, they took beatings to their head and face; guards would kneel on their neck and press them to the ground while cuffing their hands up high and pulling on the chains. Guards would enter the women's bathroom and peer at the detainees when they used the toilet. Along with the other worker activists detained, they were also only allowed one meal per day.

On 1 August 2018, a civilian was summoned and detained by the police of Yaoguan Town police station (Wujin District, Changzhou, Jiangsu) in Changzhou economic development zone and was forcibly admitted and held in mental hospitals later in Changzhou De'an city hospital in Tianning district, Changzhou for 65 days. He was forced to take medicine while locked up in hospitals. He was accused of leaving anti-government comments online, and his home was searched while his video surveillance recorder and laptop were confiscated. He was released on 16 October.

On 2 August 2018, a legal rights activist was beaten in the face, chest and abdomen by a police officer and four young thugs at Zhoujiaqiao police station in Changning district, Shanghai before being sent to the ''black jail'' at Huangshadao Recreational Fishing Centre for 20 days. They refused to give him access to medical treatment, basic necessities, and placed him under 24-hour surveillance.

On 2 August 2018, a couple - both political dissidents - were beaten by the police while they were planning to catch a train at Xining station, Qinghai (Chengdong district) with their child. Originally planning to travel for leisure, the couple were instead kidnapped and detained at Golmud police station until their release on 4 August.

Around 2 August 2018 (between 28 July and 7 August), at least one male and one female a few Jasic worker activists experienced sexual harassment and abusive conditions during their detention. The labour rights activists were first transferred from the Kengzi Residential District Police Station to the Longgang detention centre in Pingshan (Shenzhen) on 28 July 2018 and held there till 7 August 2018. They were only allowed 4 hours of sleep a night and had to finish eating very hot meals within 3 minutes.

On 3 August 2018, the police transferred a female petitioner to a group of unidentified personnel who took her to a ''black jail'' at Room 8503 of Hanting Hotel on Zhoujiazui Road, Shanghai. She was one of 18 petitioners sent back to Shanghai from Beijing by train that day, and was kept under 24-hour surveillance of two female guards.

On 3 August 2018, a retired polytechnic teacher and artist activist was kept in a cage at Zhoujiaqiao police station in Changning district (Shanghai) without any explanation the day before, before he was kidnapped and beaten in a police car on 3 Aug by four unidentifiable men. They detained him at a ''black jail'' in Songming Huangshadao recreational fishing centre for 17 days. His face was swollen from the beatings, and he sustained soft tissue injuries.

On 5 August 2018, a person was taken from the street by several employess of a property acquisition company to the community office at Chongchuan District (Nantong, Jiangsu Province) and severely beaten. He was held in the Xiaohai Subdistrict Office for more than 30 hours and was forced to sign an agreement for the demolishment of his house by an officer from the Urban Construction Management Office.

On 8 August 2018, a female villager was beaten by police officers when she visited the village party secretary of Longgang town (Wenzhou, Zhejiang) to argue against farmland seizure for a natural gas infrastructure project. She died shortly after returning home, and her family was forced to report her death as an accident after she drowned in a river. More than 20 elderly women were beaten by the police on the same day for opposing the land seizures.

Around 8 August 2018 (between 6 to 10 August), the pastor of Guiyang Huoshi Church and his family was taken by the Guiyang national security agents in Chengdu (Sichuan) to Kunming, Yunnan to be ''taken on mandatory vacation''. The pastor was criminally charged and sentenced to jail for two years and a half on 6 January 2017. After he was released, he continued to be placed under surveillance at home. He returned to Guiyang on 10 August to go to the hospital for medical treatment (for diabetes and hyperglycemia).

On 9 August 2018, a female petitioner kept at a ''black jail'' at Room 8503 of Hanting Hotel on Zhoujiazui Road, Shanghai was brutally kicked and punched on the floor by three guards. She was attacked after a police patrol came by to check on the situation, and the three guards realized that she had thrown a paper slip down her window to call for help. Later, they transferred her to Hanting Hotel on Gaoyang Road in Hongkou.

On 9 August 2018, a petitioner was detained in a 'black jail' at Shanghai Pattaya Holiday Inn in Yangpu district (Yangpu, Shanghai) for appealing against the forced demolition of her house. During this period, she was violently beaten twice by a security guard, which caused deafness in her left ear. Her elder sister was also beaten. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 10 August 2018, a man was severely beaten by the police while he was being taken back to custody from Beidaihe District, Hebei to Zhenjiang, Jiangsu. The man was beaten up and smeared with his own excrement for taking too long during a washroom stop. He was restrained to the floor for the remainder of the journey. Twelve days later, the crippled man was seen crawling on all fours during his lawyer's visitation.

On 10 August 2018, a female petitioner kept at a ''black jail'' at Room 8230 of Hanting Hotel on Gaoyang Road, Hongkou, Shanghai was severely beaten by security personnel. She was transferred from a different ''black jail'' the night before, and was kept under 24-hour surveillance of three female guards. She was released on 15 August.

On 10 August 2018, a woman human rights activist who was being detained in her home in Kunshan, Jiangsu by stability maintenance agents was violently prevented from leaving her home when she attempted to leave and seek medical treatment in Beijing for her chronic illness. When she tried to call the police, the stability maintenance agents snatched away her phone and violently pushed her back inside her home and continued to detain her. She had been detained since 2 Aug after the agents forcibly took her back to Kunshan while she was on vacation in Beidaihe, Beijing. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 11 August 2018, a Maoist union activist, who supported the Jiashi workers campaign to set up an independent workers' union in Pingshan, Guangdong, had been ''kidnapped'' by three unidentifiable individuals during a dinner with her father, and taken into an unmarked vehicle. She has been incommunicado since at an unknown location. An officer at the Yanziling police station reportedly did not know about the situation.

On 13 August 2018, a journalist and his assistant from the Chinese department of news outlet Voice of America were taken away by the police and held incommunicado when they were interviewing a retired scholar at his home in Shangdong province. During the interview, people standing guard outside the scholar's home were trying to interrupt the interview multiple times. They were forced into a police car afterwards and driven away to an unknown location.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); CPC: Communist Party of China; Labour Group (China)
NOTES: Around 16 August 2018 (month of), an Uyghur linguist (who was also a member of the CPC) was taken away from Beijing municipality while he was on a work trip. He was detained in an internment camp in Urumqi since then, as reported on 23 September 2021. The reason for his detention was suspected related to his work on Uyghur language because all of the 11 other linguists in his work unit had also been detained at different times.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); CPC: Communist Party of China
NOTES: Around 16 August 2018 (month of), an Uyghur linguist (who was also a member of the CPC) was taken away from Beijing municipality while attending meetings related to his career. He was detained in an internment camp in Urumqi since then, as reported on 23 September 2021. The reason for his detention was suspected related to his work on Uyghur language because all of the 11 other linguists in his work unit had also been detained at different times.

Around 16 August 2018 (month of), a member of Demosisto was taken by a group of Chinese National Security Officers when he was returning to Hong Kong and detained in Liuhua Hotel in Guangzhou (Guangdong) for around 5 hours. The officers demanded the Demosisto member to confess his role in the Occupy Movement, and if he participated in other Demosisto movements, as well as verbally threatened him.

On 17 August 2018, a female housing rights activist in Wuxi, Jiangsu was sent to a monitored temporary residence by the police, a day after 200-300 government personnel demolished the house belonging to her and a fellow housing rights activist, and had them subsequently arrested and detained at Chaqiao police station. The other housing rights activist was also sent away, and his location remained unknown.

On 17 August 2018, a female vaccine scandal victim was kidnapped and carried out of her rented apartment in Beijing by four law enforcement personnel from her home province, Ningxia Autonomous Region. She disappeared incommunicado for seven days, before succeeding in returning to her apartment in Beijing. She realized that all her belongings were taken and the room was empty.

On 18 August 2018, a village election candidate and four instructed triad members beat up his fellow contender in Wen village, Wuji township of Wu'an city, Handan municipal, Hebei. After beating him twice at their respective election offices, they took the contender to Ou'dun Night Club in Wu'an city and beat up both him and a fellow supporter. Both victims were admitted to a hospital for a forensic medical assessment of the attack.

Around 20 August 2018 (between 15 - 26 Aug), local police tortured a female leader of the Church of Almighty God in a hotel in Xuzhou, Jiangsu. She was forcibly abducted by police on 15 Aug and handcuffed to a ''tiger bench'' during interrogation, with the temperatures of the air-conditioner turned down and aimed at her until she was shivering. She was then taken to a hostel the next day, where she was again tied to a ''tiger bench''. She continued to be tortured for the next ten days in order for her to divulge personal information. It was reported that she was beaten with a bamboo rod, leaving her legs severely bruised. She later escaped from the hotel on 26 August 2018.

On 21 August 2018, two veterans from Weifang were severely beaten at Beihai, Weifang by interceptors from the Changyi local government, who caught them after they had submitted forms at the Ministry of Veterans Affairs in Beijing. The two veterans were then admitted to Renmin Hospital at Changyi, Weifang, where they were denied visitations and heavily guarded, effectively being detained in a ''black jail'' incommunicado.

On 21 August 2018, a villager was assaulted by a plainclothes policeman from the Hushan Police Station while visiting the working location of the Zhejiang Provincial Party Committee Inspection Team to lodge a complaint (coded to Wuyi county (Jinhua, Zhejiang), where the police officer was stationed). He was pulled into a car and beaten up, then detained for nine days while suffering from internal bleeding. Two directors from the Xinzhai Town Judicial Office had deliberately arranged for the villager to appear at Tangfeng Hot Spring (also in Wuyi and assumed to be near the Inspection Team's working location) that day.

On 22 August 2018, the aunt of a human rights activist was being ''taken on mandatory vacation'' by public security personnels while visiting her nieces on Dongshan street, Liwan district of Guangdong. Her nieces are human rights activists under house arrest. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 22 August 2018, approximately 100 officials from 17 villages and the town government came to a church in Wolong Town (Yongcheng City, Henan Province). When believers already inside the church attempted to guard the church's property, government personnel swarmed the church, and started punching and kicking the believers. It was reported that the gates to the church were later locked, and the Christian couplets pasted on the entrance and the Chinese characters for ''Christian Church'' were smeared over with cement. CCP propaganda slogans were displayed on either side of the gate instead.

On 23 August 2018, around 100 private security forces hired by the government attacked residents in Xiayang village, Chengmen town (Cangshan, Fuzhou, Fujian) during an unannounced forced demolition. Elderly and women were among those resisting the demolition, many villagers were injured, including two women who bled and became unconscious.

On 23 August 2018, an online social activist was captured by the police on the staircase outside his home and detained at Bao'an police station in Shenzhen. It was reported that the specific reason for his arrest is unclear.

On 24 August 2018, more than 20 Guangdong police forces arrested at least eight editors and staff of Red Reference and Epoch Pioneer at their offices in Suzhuang, Fangshan district of Beijing, after both Maoist website organisations were involved in the Jiashi workers unionization labour movement. Their whereabouts are unknown. During the search, the police confiscated books, computers and broke furniture, and sealed off the premise.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: Around 26 August 2018 (between 24-28 August 2018), the Jiashi Workers' Support Group released a statement saying that some of their arrested members were beaten in a nearby primary school in Huizhong, Guangdong, before being released and sent home. This followed the arrest of 50 student activists, Maoist labour activists and 5 Jiashi workers on 24 August, after riot police raided a rented apartment they were sharing in Huizhou. At least three of the arrested were incommunicado.
On 27 August 2018, police took away an elder at a Christian church in Tanghe county of Nanyang city, Henan and his whereabouts remain unknown.

On 27 August 2018, a female vaccine scandal victim was kidnapped in Beijing by law enforcement officials and incommunicado once again. She was in town to arrange a press release on 23-24 Aug with other parents affected by the vaccine scandal, some of whom experienced being detained, intimidated or sent back home by law enforcement.

On 28 August 2018, an arrested democracy rights activist was placed under ''Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location'' by the police at the Pudong district station of the Shanghai Municipal Public Security Bureau. Days prior, the police had informed his family that he would be released from criminal detention within the week.

Around 29 August 2018 (as reported), a rights activist was made to leave Beijing a few days ahead of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation to be ''taken on mandatory vacation.'' A few weeks ago, government officials accompanied his travels to Yunnan, then monitored and restricted him after he returned to Beijing.

On 29 August 2018, a female petitioner from Suzhou was beaten up by local stability maintenance personnel in Suzhou City, Jiangsu Province, while she was preparing to go to Beijing to make petitions during the China-Africa Summit. She suffered severe injuries. She was then detained in the hospital afterwards, until she escaped on 13 September 2018.

On 30 August 2018, the houses of more than ten families in Daizhuang Village (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) were forcibly demolished by the authorities. During the demolition, more than 1,000 people from the district's Demolition and Relocation Office, Urban Management Office and other departments armed with iron bars and long wooden sticks were present at the scene to seal off all intersections. Several villagers were beaten by demolition personnel, including two women when they attempted to record the demolition. Several people sustained injuries, including 1 elderly man who sustained a dislocated joint, bruises, with layers of skin tore off his arms. His granddaughter received 13 stitches after being hit in the head with a stick.

On 30 August 2018, a petitioner from Hechuan, Chongqing was given an injection before being released after being detained in the Sanmiao Mental Hospital in Hechuan District (Chongqing) for 1 year and 8 months. On 11 Oct 2016, she had been forcibly admitted to the psychiatric ward of Houfengyan General Hospital in Beibei District before being transferred to Hechuan District. She was forced to take pills and receive daily injections that she reacted to badly.

On 31 August 2018, the local govenrment hired more than 20 thugs to raid the Great Praise house church meeting venue in Nanyang city (Henan) after the leader refused to join the government-controlled Three-Self Church. Believers guarding the church were beaten up while trying to protect their place of worship. The thugs retreated after more believers showed up.

On 31 August 2018, police forces stopped 14 Shanghaiese human rights activists at Ping'anli metro station (Xicheng district of Beijing), and sent them to Jiujingzhuang ''black jail'' once they were identified as petitioners. They were on their way to the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection office to report a complaint about the Shanghai local government. The petitioners reportedly learnt that they will be sent back to their hometown the next day, and continue to be detained or in a ''black jail'' due to an upcoming international expo.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: CPC: Communist Party of China; Women (China)
NOTES: On 1 September 2018, a female CPC member was intercepted by 20 stability maintenance officials from the Yanji Sub-district Office and National Health Commission at Xizhimen Station in Xicheng district (Beijing) during a medical visit, then escorted back to Shanghai and held at Haunghao Hotel ''black jail'' in Changxing Island of Changxing town (Chongming, Shanghai) (coded as Shanghai-Chongming) for 448 days. During this period, she faced repeated beatings by government-hired private security guards. She was targeted for petitioning about neurological injuries resulted from rabies vaccines sold by the NHC of Yangpu district.

On 2 September 2018, more than 20 plain-clothed policemen broke into the rental apartment of a rights activist in Fengtai district (Beijing), and without showing their ID, cuffed the activist's hands, used a tanktop to cover his head, and drove him to Changlin county for interrogations.

On 2 September 2018, a female church worker was attacked by the police while she was trying to film during a raid at church in Luohe (Henan). Another female believer was attacked by five police officers while she was trying to take photos of police brutality.

On 3 September 2018, a civil rights activist was forcibly taken away in Beijing and back to Shanghai by the authorities. As of the reporting on 17 September 2018, the activist's whereabouts remained unknown .

On 3 September 2018, a female petitioner was severely beaten up by 5 to 6 people hired by stability maintenance forces of Suzhou in Suzhou, Jiangsu, while she was on her way to petition in Beijing. She was severely injured and sent to a hospital.

On 3 September 2018, community police officers kept a female petitioner in the village secretary's office in Shenxi village, Lingang sub-district of Jiangyin county, Wuxi, Jiangsu after she was kidnapped for petitioning in Beijing then sent back to her hometown.
