A officer confiscated her bag and forced her to give up on her petition. She refused and was subsequently placed under house arrest.

Around 4 September 2018 (between 3-5 September 2018), a member of the Church of Almighty God in Chongqing was beaten by the police several times during her custody, for refusing to provide information during interrogations about the church or its members. This followed her arrest on 3 September 2018, after five police officers barged into her home without a warrant, and seized various items including a laptop computer and two MP5 players. She was then taken into custody at a ''legal education centre'' for mandatory indoctrination, and released on 5 September 2018.
On 8 September 2018, the wife of the priest was attacked by the police in Pingdingshan (Henan) for trying to get into a newly-built church after it was demolished.

On 8 September 2018, more than 100 officials and a demolition team forcefully evicted and sabotaged the home of the sister of an election activist seeking to become an independent candidate of the district People's Congress at Shunde District (Foshan, Guangdong). During the eviction, officials beat up the activist and her brother who stood in their way. The activist sustained injuries, including a broken bone in her right hand.

On 10 September 2018, mayor of the Yujing Town of Qianshan City (Anqing, Anhui), along with a well-known member of a local triad group, beat up villagers of Huangling Village who spoke and petitioned against the election fraud and the disqualification of two Villager's Committee candidates in the upcoming election.

On 10 September 2018, a female petitioner was subjected to suffocation while detained at a 'black jail' in a four-storey building located in a valley of the 3303 military industrial district in Jiangxia district (Wuhan, Hubei). Her supervisors were government-hired farmers who spoke with a Honghu district accent, claiming to be sent by the 'Legal Education Base of the Six Central-Southern Provinces'. They burnt fuel outside while using an exhaust fan to direct fumes into her compartment, sealing off all doors and windows with blankets. She was repeatedly tortured while abducted between 7 Mar and 17 Oct 2018.

On 11 September 2018, a Uyghur woman (a retired medical doctor) who had been residing in Tianshan District (Urumqi, Xinjiang) disappeared and had since remained uncontactable. According to her daughter, she was most likely detained in a re-education camp by the authorities. Her disappearance came six days after her sister spoke publicly about the conditions inside the camps in Xinjiang, and was believed to be the key reason for her disappearance. Another testimony stated that her apartment was found to be sealed by the public security bureau in mid-September 2019.

On 12 September 2018, a female petitioner was kidnapped by the officials from the Jiangsu representative office in Beijing and three gangsters at Yongdingmen West No. 20 bus station in Dongcheng district (Beijing) while she was in the process of petitioning at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls. Leaving all her belongings behind, she was illegally detained at Room 102 of Jinghua Hotel in Fengtai district (Bejing). She was subsequently repatriated to Jiangyi City, Jiangsu where she was placed under house arrest.

On 12 September 2018, a female human rights activist was taken away from a bus station on Yongdingmen West, Dongcheng District (Beijing) by a staff member from the Jiangyin City representative office in Beijing and three thugs. While arriving in a hotel in Fengtai District where she would be detained, she was violently dragged out of the car, causing her to collapse onto the ground due to her pre-existing injuries. She began to feel tightness in her chest and stomach cramps, and repeatedly vomited. She was repatriated to Jiangyin City later in the evening on the same day. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 14 September 2018, a female member of The Church of Almighty God died during an arrest by the local Public Security Bureau in Dunhua city (Yanbian Korean Autonomous, Jilin). She was already admitted to the intensive care unit of a hospital when her family was informed, and they believed that the death was the direct result of torture because of large areas of contusions and purple bruises on her left arm.

On 14 September 2018, a veteran was blockaded by ''interceptors'' outside his home in Xukou Town, Wuzhong District (Suzhou, Jiangsu) and was beaten. Later, he was forcibly taken to the local police station and remained incommunicado.

Around 15 September 2018 (middle of month), local authorities transferred a female believer of the Church of Almighty God from a detention centre in Taiyuan City, Shanxi Province, and put her into a legal education centre in Changzhi City. She was first detained by the authorities in July 2018, on suspicion of the crime of ''using a xie jiao [cult] organisation to undermine law enforcement''.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), a female Church of the Almighty God member was arrested in Jiangsu province (coded to Xuanwu) and tortured during police interrogation. She was subject to sleep deprivation for seven nights, then handcuffed to a rope that barely allowed her toes to touch the floor. The officers also held her head under water three times.

On 17 September 2018, a petitioner was forcibly abducted by local police and authorities when she was about to get on a train at the railway station in Wuxi, Jiangsu. Her whereabouts remained unknown as of 18 September 2018.

On 17 September 2018, a person was beaten up by more than a dozen government officials, while seeking for help from the local authorities in Gangkou Town (Huizhou, Guangdong), after his hotel suffered significant damages due to a typhoon.

On 18 September 2018, a petitioner and his partner were arrested by local police when petitioning at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng District (Beijing). They were then detained in Jiujingzhuang ''black jail'' in Fengtai District (Beijing). They were subsequently taken away by officials from the Sichuan representative office in Beijing, where the petitioner got into an altercation with the officials and was beaten. He was refused medical attention for his injuries and instead taken for further detention in another ''black jail'' in Chaoyang District.

On 18 September 2018, the mother of a petitioner cum victim of a defective rabies vaccine was suspected to have been kidnapped in Yangpu, about two weeks after her daughter's disappearance. She was being followed and surveiled around the clock before her disappearance. As of 19 February 2019, she has been disappeared for 154 days. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 20 September 2018, a female lawyer was reportedly beaten by the police at Hualin Police Station in Liwan District (Guangzhou, Guangdong) while she was trying to meet a client. She was held for six hours in the police station and was reportedly searched naked before being released before midnight. She was also elbowed in her throat by a plainclothes officer, and pushed up against the wall.

On 20 September 2018, a couple was beaten by the local police at the police station in Liwan District (Guangzhou, Guangdong) when they asked the police to investigate further into a suspected insurance fraud case.

Around 20 September 2018 (between 17 - 22 September), a Uyghur man was taken away in Moyu County (Hotan, Xinjiang) and sent to either the Qaraqash No. 1 or No. 4 camp, less than a week after he had been released from prison around 15 September. Despite being approved for release from the re-education camp in early 2019, he was presumably sentenced at some point in 2019.

On 23 September 2018, an official from the village committee attacked a believer with a knife in Wucheng Village (Nanyang, Henan) and severely injured the believer after both parties had a quarrel over the village official locking the door of the church's gathering venue and cutting off the power and water without any notice. The believer sustained several cuts on his head and was sent to the hospital for treatment. The gathering venue was rented to the church by the village official 20 years ago, and due to the government campaign to crack down house churches in Henan, the village official decided stop renting the venue.

On 25 September 2018, an ethnic Kazakh imam from Xinjiang was detained in a transformation through education camp in Xinjiang. He was later released on 21 December 2018, but was warned again soon after his release that the Public Security would detain him again.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 25 September 2018, 1000 government personnel, including special and armed police, demolition personnel, and medical staff, were dispatched around midnight to tear down a Buddhist temple being guarded by 200 villagers in Zhuangyuan town, Longwan District (Wenzhou, Zhejiang). About 300 baton-wielding police officers smashed windows to enter the temple, and a villager was hospitalised after being beaten up for trying to reason with them. All the Buddha statues were removed and the temple was completely razed to the ground two days later.

On 27 September 2018, an activist was forcibly admitted to a mental hospital by the Prosecutor General's Office in Jiaocheng County (Luliang, Shanxi) for being critical and vocal on social media. Less than a month later, the hospital requested that the authorities revoke his forced admission as he did not have Schizophrenia, as originally alleged, but authorities insisted that he continue receiving treatment as he ''posed a danger to society''. The activist was eventually released from the hospital to care for his mother, who had medical complications.

On 28 September 2018, a Kazakh man (originally from Emin County, and now a Kazakhstan citizen) was taken away by two national security bureau officers in Emin County (Tacheng Prefecture, Xinjiang) to the basement of a prison facility for interrogation for six days. During this period, he was locked up in a cage that was too small for him to lie down, and also questioned in a separate for three hours on a ''tiger bench''. After being released, he remained under house arrest until he was returned his confiscated resident card and returned to Kazakhstan on 2 February 2019.

On 29 September 2018, a member of the Guizhou Human Rights Commission was taken away by the authorities, likely from Guizhou Province, and ''taken on mandatory vacation'' to an agritainment resort around Guiyang City (Guizhou). He was guarded by four people at the resort until 7 October. Before the Chinese National Day on 1 October, more than ten members of the Guizhou Human Rights Commission were ''taken on mandatory vacation'' or placed under ''soft detention'' to prevent them from participating in the ''National Day Take to the Street Together'' activity, which was intended to protest against the Chinese Communist Party.

On 30 September 2018, before the Chinese National Day on 1 October, at least two members of the Guizhou Human Rights Commission were taken away by the authorities, likely from Guizhou Province, and ''taken on mandatory vacation'' or placed under ''soft detention'' in hotels in Guiyang City. It was reported that more than ten members of the Guizhou Human Rights Commission had been ''taken on mandatory vacation'' or placed under ''soft detention'' in hotels in Guiyang City before 1 October. This was to prevent them from participating in the '' National Day Take to the Street Together'' activity, which intended to protest against the Chinese Communist Party.

On 30 September 2018, a civilian in Beijing went to the Mao Zhe Dong Memorial Hall (Beijing) to protest against illegal demolition of his house and was denied entry by the stability maintenance police, since then his lawyer lost contact with him.

Around 30 September 2018 (end of month), a Bitter Winter contributor was arrested in Xinjiang after he reported on ''transformation through education camps,'' including their internal construction. His whereabouts remained unknown as of 27 Dec.
On 1 October 2018, local authorities took away a civil rights activist in Shunyi, Beijing and put him in illegal custody in a hotel where he was placed under 24-hour surveillance.

On 4 October 2018, 38 petitioners-cum-veterans from Pindu (Qingdao, Shandong) were assaulted by the chief police officer and his team in Dongying prefecture (Shandong) while on their way to petition in Beijing. At least three of them sustained injuries to their leg, shoulder and head respectively. Seventeen veterans were taken away on the day, and one was taken away on 8 Oct. Two months later, it was made known that four of them were detained at a gardening farm in Pingdu, and others were separately detained at Xiguan Primary School and Olympic Sports Centre. Details about their situation unknown.

On 7 October 2018, a female petitioner was abducted by the policemen from the Shenggang police office and officials from Shengxi village government while she was eating at the Kentucky Fried Chicken store in Jintan district (Changzhou, Jiangsu). She was illegally detained at Shenggang Xinpudong Hotel for over 20 days.

On 7 October 2018, a petitioner was taken away by police officers and officials from the village committee and detained in a ''black jail'' in a hotel in Shengang Town, Jiangyin City (Wuxi, Jiangsu). She managed to escape after more than 20 days, but was re-detained on the same day after she lodged a police report. She was finally released on 19 Jan 2019 after being held for 105 days.

On 9 October 2018, a villager-cum-petitioner was killed near Sanmiaoqian town in Poyang county (Shangrao, Jiangxi), after he visited the village committee members of Wan'an village, Sanmiaoqian town who occupied his family's farmlands, armed with a knife. His body was found later the same day in the river under Hucheng bridge near Sanmiaoqiao. While the authorities claimed that he committed suicide, bloody wounds were found all over when his body was retrieved. The victim was denied a post-mortem, and his body was forcibly taken away and cremated under the orders of the Sanmiaoqian town police.
Around 15 October 2018 (month of), a Uyghur tradeswoman from Kashi (Xinjiang) (coded as Kashi City) was sent to a re-education camp for religious extremism.

On 15 October 2018, officers from Hushan Village Police Department together with a group of unidentified people broke into the house of a female petitioner, her sister and her mother in Hushan village of Guangshan county (Xingyang, Henan). They used cooking knives and sticks to attack three women and sprayed a drug potion on them, took them away, and confiscated some of their properties. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons][women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 15 October 2018, a homeowner was beaten up by 20 to 30 members of a demolition team (hired by the government) when he tried to stop them from demolishing his house in Hangji Town (Yangzhou, Jiangsu). Later in the day, in retaliation, the homeowner would drive his car into the demolition team members, causing 3 deaths and 7 injuries.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), law enforcement officers beat up a student for about five minutes using bricks and stools in Heze City, Shandong Province, after the student attempted to protest against the officers for dragging his uncle out of his car. The uncle was using his cellphone to record the demolition of a building, where over 50 law enforcements officers were present to secure the site. The student was forced to sign a statement not to reveal the incident to others. The student suffered three fractures to his ribs, and fractures to the transverse process of his lumbar vertebrae.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a farmer, who was forced to evict, was kidnapped and held incommunicado in a black jail by local authorities from Jiangyin county (Wuxi, Jiangsu). As of 25 Nov, he had been missing for more than a month.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Han Ethnic Group (China); Government of China (2012-); CPC: Communist Party of China
NOTES: Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a Han CPC Chief of Shache (Yarkand) county (Kashi, Xinjiang) disappeared from the public and was reportedly held by the Xinjiang Discipline Inspection Commission at an unknown location. He was described as an official who ''failed to tow the party line during the round-up of Uyghurs in Shache county''. He ordered a release of 7,000 people from ''internment camps'', and held the opinion that holding Uyghurs up in detention facilities or camps would not improve ethnic relations, and the lack of working-class men would cause his county to miss production targets.

Around 17 October 2018 (between 14-20 October 2018), a woman who was arrested by the police in Liwan District (Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province), was interrogated continuously and not allowed to sleep or use the toilet during the interrogation. This resulted in some inflammation in her body. She was first arrested on 14 October 2018 under the charge of the 'crime of picking quarrels and provoking troubles'.

On 18 October 2018, a villager was abducted by a group of unidentified people in Lilou village in Luolong district (Luoyang) and was teken to Mengjing detention center. He was among villagers from Liufu village who were abducted due to their protest over the land use right transfer agreement in Liufu village.

On 18 October 2018, a civil rights activist from Yanshou County, Heilongjiang was taken away by the police at a metro station in Fangshan, Beijing and forcibly repatriated to Yanshou County. He had since been uncontactable. At the time of reporting on 19 October 2018, it was reported that he was likely detained in a ''black jail''.

On 20 October 2018, an disabled former soldier, who petitioned in 2006 due to the demolition of his apartment by the Zhuhai city Jinwan District urban management office, was abducted in Wushi village of Chini town in Guangzhou Huadu district (Guangzhou, Guangdong) and held incommunicado by the police from Jinwan distrcit in Zhuhai city. More than ten people came to the residence of the former soldier in the morning and were taking him by force to the two police cars while they were locking his wife into the room.

On 23 October 2018, a human rights defender was arrested at the Jingxi Hotel in Haidian District (Beijing) while she was submitting a proposal to the NPC standing Committee. She was first brought to the Yangfangdian police station before being transferred to a black jail housed in the Relief Administration Service Center in Dongcheng District. The next day, she was sent back to Shanghai by train, after which she was detained in another black jail. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 25 October 2018, a petitioner who petitioned for the verdict of her divorce case was sent to black jail in Chongming Panlong Shengtaiyuan hotel 2688 in Chongming district (Shanghai) during the mass arrest of petitioners and human rights defenders when China International Import Expo was held in Shanghai.

On 25 October 2018, a human rights defender who had been held in a black jail in Beijing two days ago was sent back to Shanghai and taken from the Shanghai railway station in Jing'an District (Shanghai) to be held in black jail at 500 Fucun road in Putuo District. She was and later taken away by the police and sub-district officers from Changning District and has been missing since. She had gone to Beijing to submit a proposal to the NPC standing Committee on 23 October 2018. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 25 October 2018, a Uyghur man (who was a publisher and the CEO of a publishing company) from Tianshan District (Urumqi, Xinjiang) was taken away by the authorities. He had since been held incommunicado and his son believed that he is detained in a re-education camp. His son claimed that his dad's impact on the Uyghur publishing industry made him a target of the Chinese government.

On 25 October 2018, a farmer from Wuzhou, Jiangxi disappeared after being released from the Ganjiang Prison in Xinjian District (Nanchang, Jiangxi) and his family suspects that he has been put into black jail by the Le'an county government in Anle County. The farmer was sentenced to jail due to his petition over the local government levying his land and was going to be released on 25 October 2018, but the family didn't see him when they went to pick him up, and the jail administration said that the Le'an county law enforcement has took him out of jail 3 days ago.

On 26 October 2018, a petitioner from Wuxi, Jiangsu was kidnapped by 15 men while visiting relatives in Beijing, and one of the kidnappers was identified as a worker from his subdistrict's administrative agency. After being sent back to Wuxi prefecture, he was incommunicado following a single phone call, and continued to be for four months as of 1 Mar 2019.

On 28 October 2018, a Uyghur prisoner was forcibly transferred to a 'concentration camp' from a prison in Hotan city (Hotan, Xinjiang) on the day that his prison sentence expired instead of being released. It is reported that he was subjected to forced labour until May 2019 and released in June 2019 due to illness. He was re-arrested in September 2019 and transferred back to Hoten city, but his current status is unclear.

On 28 October 2018, a woman petitioner was abducted by a policeman from Pudong police department Hangtou office and 2 gangsters to Hangtou police office in Pudong district (Shanghai) and detained during the massive arrest of petitioners and human rights defenders when China International Import Expo was held in Shanghai.

On 29 October 2018, 10 petitioners and other 3 people staying in the same hotel were abducted in two hotels around Beijing Yongdingmen Coach Station and Beijing South Railway Station in Dongcheng district (Beijing) by 14 unidentified thugs who claim to work in Beijing security force. 14 thugs broke into their rooms and foced them into a van, and 13 people were beaten and got their phones, ID, and money confiscated by 14 thugs before they were thrown out in the area next to Xingyu bus station.

Around 31 October 2018 (end of month), a Kyrgyz historian who worked at the Academy of Social Sciences was taken away from Beijing Road Residential district, Xinshi District (Urumqi, Xinjiang) by the authorities. He had since been held incommunicado and his whereabouts and circumstances were not verified. It was reported by his brother through state media in January 2019 that he was held in a 'training centre'. According to his nephew in September 2020, he was later sentenced to 11 years in prison.

Around 31 October 2018 (end of month), a former female employee with the Home Affairs Bureau's Child Welfare Department was taken away in front of a psychiatric hospital in Xiangyang prefecture (Hubei) by two stability maintenance officers and two nurses and forcibly admitted for three months. She was planning to petition earlier that day. During her admission, she was forcibly medicated and underwent electroconvulsive therapy, resulting in noticeable changes to her physical and mental health, including weak limbs, loss of appetite, involuntarily trembling and difficulties with walking.

On 1 November 2018, a petitioner was taken to the black jail in Zhongxin road 1039, Jitai hotel room 226 by the officers from Zhijiang west road sub-district office when she was petitioning at the petition reception office in Jing'an district (Shanghai) during the massive arrest of petitioners and human rights defenders when China International Import Expo was held in Shanghai. The black jail was guarded by gangsters for 24 hours.

On 1 November 2018, a petitioner was beaten by a security guard when he went to petition in Hubei civil administration in Hongshan district (Wuhan, Hubei) and he was treated violently by a security guard again at the petition reception office of Wuhan Hongshan district police department in Hongshan district (Wuhan, Hubei) when he went there to report the attack. In the past thirteen years, the petitioner and his wife have been subjected to detention, criminal sentence, and black jail due to their reporting on the criminal-organization involvement of the brother-in-law of Majia Town Secretary of Political and Legal Commission, which led to the loss of subsistence allowance of the petitioner.

Around 1 November 2018 (as reported), a Uyghur woman from Yizhou (Iwirghol) District (Hami, Xinjiang) became unreachable and was likely taken away by the authorities to a re-education camp. This claim was reported by her daughters who were told by their father during a phone call that she had been detained. In late March 2019, she became reachable again, after her daughter's publicizing of her detention. It was reported that she remained in some form of soft detention since then.

On 2 November 2018, a woman petitioner was taken to the black jail in Changxin Island by the officers from Hudong street sub-district office in Pudong district (Shanghai) during the massive arrest of petitioners and human rights defenders when China International Import Expo was held in Shanghai.

On 2 November 2018, Xi'an Gaoxing district ubran management committee deployed thousands of policemen and thugs to demolish the buildings in Xi'an Yuhuazhai village in Yanta district (Xi'an, Shanxi) in the name of forced eviction. During the process, the police and thugs attacked many villagers who came to stop them and also some by-standers.

On 2 November 2018, five human rights defenders disappeared in Shanghai (Shanghai) during the massive arrest of petitioners and human rights defenders when China International Import Expo was held in Shanghai.

Around 3 November 2018, a prominent photojournalist was taken away by the Ministry of State Security while on a field assignment in Kashgar (Xinjiang). Police notified his family about his detention more than a month later, but did not provide any reason for his arrest.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Farmers (China); Hui Ethnic Group (China); Muslim Group (China)
NOTES: Around 3 November 2018, 40 Hui men, most of whom were farmers, were arrested and detained at Wusu NO. 2 Middle School in Wusu (Tarbagatay, Xinjiang), which was converted into a ''transformation through education'' camp for Hui people and guarded by SWAT police. Detainees were not allowed to get intouch with their families.

On 3 November 2018, a university student and Christian believer of The Church of Almighty God was abducted by National Security Brigade in Fangshan district (Beijing) and held in a secret location for a few days. The believers of The Church of Almighty God have been targeted by the Chinese authorities to suppress this new religious movement.

On 3 November 2018, a woman petitioner was taken to the black jail by a group led by the police officer from Shimen second road police office of Jing'an police department in Jing'an district (Shanghai) during the massive arrest of petitioners and human rights defenders when China International Import Expo was held in Shanghai.

On 4 November 2018, while a Taoist temple in Shaogang Town (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) was being repainted under the orders of local officials, government personnel ran into strong opposition from villagers. It was reported that a woman was pinned to the ground by government personnel, causing her to sustain injuries. A pregnant woman was also pushed to the ground and later taken to the hospital for treatment. Two days before, the temple was sealed off with barricade tape by the government.

On 4 November 2018, a couple who were petitioner were taken into a car after they were stopped and questioned by police when they were walking in Lujiazui in Pudong district (Shanghai), and have been missing since. This incident is part of the the mass arrests of petitioners and human rights defenders around the time when the China International Import Expo was held in Shanghai.

On 5 November 2018, the mother of an Uyghur journalist, living in exile in Sweden, was taken away by police while her father was taken away almost 2 weeks later. Both of them returned to their home in Yizhou District (Hami, XUAR) around 28 March 2019 after being held incommunicado for up to 4 months in a political ''re-education camp'' in Xinjiang; no reason for their detention was ever provided.

On 8 November 2018, two human rights defenders went to the black jail in Zhongxin road 1039 in Jing'an district (Shanghai) to visit their friend who was prisioned there. During the visit, they were attacked by the head of guards of the black jail and a young man.

On 9 November 2018, seven social workers and two student-cum-founders of Shenzhen community organisation ''Qingying Social Workers Centre'' were placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) after being arrested in Shenzhen (Guangdong). A total of 18 university students and social workers were arrested that day across Beijing, Guangzhou, Shanghai, Wuhan and Shenzhen for their solidarity and involvement in the Jiashi workers' union movement.

On 9 November 2018, a petitioner was arrested in Chongqing and subsequently tortured in detention by the police. He was arrested while he was caring for his wife in a hospital in Chongqing, but no specific location mentioned in the report. The family that he stayed with in Chongqing was also arrested and their house was demolished on the same day.

On 9 November 2018, officials from the Jiulongpo District Government of Chongqing City and unidentified public security personnel used smoke bombs to break into the home of an activist opposing forced demolitions in the same district (coded as Chongqing-Jiulongpo). The officials proceeded to violently beat up the activist and his three relatives and friends inside before bringing them to the Jiulongpo Police Station for a 3-day-long interrogation. All of them suffered injuries. The activist's brother and nephew suffered from multiple fractures to their face and limbs.

On 9 November 2018, a couple of students from Beijing University who supported the Jasic workers' movement were attacked by unidentified people dressed in black in the campus in Haidian district (Beijing), and one of the students were kidnapped and held incommunicado.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Bitter Winter; China Aid
NOTES: On 9 November 2018, the bishop of Wenzhou Catholic Diocese was taken by the police in Wenzhou (Zhejiang) and ''taken on mandatory vacation'' for ten days or two weeks, for the reason that he refused to join state-controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association. The abduction was allegedly related to large mass and prayers gathering organised by the cardinal on 4 Nov to commemorate a late cardinal of the church. In the past two years, the bishop had been taken into custody by the police for five times. This was the first time that he was ''taken on mandatory vacation'' since he returned to the diocese in January 2018.

On 10 November 2018, a petitioner was struck on the head by a triad member during his visit to the Wuyi County Petitioning Bureau (Jinhua, Zhejiang). The Bureau Chief threatened to prosecute the petitioner and warned him against taking his grievances to higher-ups in Beijing.

On 12 November 2018, two daughters of a deceased workers' rights activist were forced into a police car by Shenyang government representatives in Beijing (Beijing) while on their way from Qianmen Dazhong Hostel in Xicheng district to China Mobile's Beijing office. They were taken to Liujiaoyao Liyuan Hotel, where the representative office of Shenyang government in Bejing was located. Their phones were confiscated when they tried to call the police. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), a member of the Church of Almighty God was arrested at her home in Liaoning Province. After being taken to the local police station, she was placed in a chair-shaped iron cage (a torture device measuring 1 metre tall, about 30 centimetres wide, and about 60 centimetres long) for more than 20 hours, to force her to divulge information about the church. She was subsequently sentenced to 10 days of detention following the interrogation.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), a Uyghur woman (a famous singer in the 1980s and 1990s, and part of the Xinjiang Arts & Culture Bureau), presumably from Urumqi City, Xinjiang Province (coded as Shuimogou), was detained and held incommunicado by the authorities. While her relatives claimed that she was reportedly released in May 2019, other sources stated that she was sentenced to 15 years in a secret trial in late 2019. Her niece-in-law stated that her detention was due to her being a traditional artist singing Uyghur folk songs, while an anonymous source claimed that she was sentenced for ''separatism''.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), a petitioner from Weibin District who had signed a joint letter calling on the Shaanxi government to step up anti-corruption measures was kidnapped in Beijing and sent to Baoji City (Shaanxi). He has been incommunicado since for at least 4 months.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), a security guard working for Peking University went incommunicado in Beijing after he published a video - filmed on Peking University campus - to demand for freedom of speech, as well as for the Chinese government to release victims of forced disappearance. In the video, he also criticised Xi Jinping over offering financial aids to African countries. He was later reported to be in police custody sometime within the month, and in April 2020, it was reported that they were sentenced to jail for ''picking quarrels and provoking trouble.''

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), a Uyghur writer in Hotan prefecture (Xinjiang) (coded as Hotan city) was taken away and detained in a re-education camp for illegal religious activities. he was reportedly released in March 2019. He later died on 31 May 2019, with the authorities claiming that he had a heart attack and died on the way to the hospital. It was reported that he had heart problems and diabetes before going to the camp and was not provided with necessary medicine.

On 18 November 2018, an Uyghur man from Yizhou (Iwirghol) District (Hami, Xinjiang) was taken away by the authorities and held under incommunicado detention, likely in a re-education camp. At the end of March 2019, he became reachable again and was presumed to have been released from detention. It was reported that he remained under some form of soft detention, as contact had been sporadic.

SOURCE: Xinjiang Victims Database; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 22 November 2018, a Kazakh shop assistant from Dahongliuxia township of Barkol Autonomous region (Hami, Xinjiang) was detained incommunicado. He was later sentenced to 15 years in prison on 20 October 2019 for propagating extremism, though some sources allege that his sharing of a patriotic poem on his WeChat platform may have also been an influencing factor.

On 22 November 2018, a Kazakh shop assistant from Dahongliuxia village, Dahongliuxia township, Barkol County (Hami, Xinjiang) was detained incommunicado. On 20 October 2019, he was allegedly imprisoned in Fangcaohu prison for propagating extremism.

On 24 November 2018, a female rights defender in Beijing was kidnapped by the police officers from the Haidian District police station and held incommunicado for 31 hours. She had intended to participate in a protest over the construction of Haidian Baoshan waste processing plant, but was taken by the police in the Haidian district to ''a place where there were more than 20 police cars''. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 24 November 2018, a land rights defender was beaten up by a dozen thugs hired by the local eviction department authorities in Jiangyin county (Wuxi, Jiangsu) after more than 20 of them kidnapped him near Yangjian Town Langxia vegetable market in Xishan district (Wuxi). They forced him to sign an eviction agreement, and when he was released later that night, he had to be treated in Jiangying People's Hospital for brain concussion.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of China (2012-); Han Ethnic Group (China)
NOTES: Around 26 November 2018 (as reported), a Han official in Gongliu county (Ili, Xinjiang) was sent to a re-education camp because he didn't reach the quota of arresting Muslims in the Aga'ersen Town.

Around 27 November 2018 (as reported), a petitioner recently went missing and is suspected to have been abducted and held incommunicado by the authorities in Liangji village (Jinzhong, Shanxi). The petitioner from Liangji village went to Beijing to report the corruption and bribery cases of the village direct of Liangji Village on 18 November 2018.

On 27 November 2018, a Hui poet living in Jinan (Shandong) was taken by the police and held incommunicado. He posted a short message on Twitter while the police was taking him, and it was suspected that he was abducted due to his posts related to re-education camps on Twitter.

On 28 November 2018, the previously imprisoned university professor and New Democracy Party of China founder was summoned by the Hanzhongmen police station in Gulou district (Nanjing) and held incommunicado. It is suspected that he was detained because he shared his political opinions through Wechat.

Around 28 November 2018 (as reported), a Chinese scientist and associate professor, who made the first genome-edited human babies, was incommunicado after he returned to Shenzhen (Guangdong) from the Human Genome Editing Summit in Hong Kong. He was seen living on the fourth floor of a hotel for visiting scholars and teachers at the Southern University of Science and Technology in Nanshan district (Shenzhen), where his balcony was wrapped with barbed wire and guarded by more than ten unidentifiable security guards . Lawyers suspected that he was placed under house arrest by state authorities due to the controversial ethical implications of his work.

On 29 November 2018, a petitioner was arrested and taken to the Tiananmen police station after he was stopped for a security check while passing by Tiananmen in Dongcheng district (Beijing). His wife suspected that he was held in Majialou Detention Centre.

On 29 November 2018, a petitioner from Hubei was captured by the police while sending a letter to government leadership in Zhongnanhai, Xicheng District (Beijing), then sent to the Majialou Detention Centre and held in black jail. The police stopped him and scanned his ID, revealing that he was a petitioner.

On 30 November 2018, a petitioner was captured and detained at Liaocheng University in Dongchangfu district (Liaocheng, Shandong) under residential surveillance for inciting subversion of state power. During his detention, his hands and legs were cuffed and attached to a metal chair. He was finally transferred to a Liaocheng city detention center on 29 June 2019.

Around 1 December 2018 (beginning of month), the elderly mother of a prominent human rights defender and founder of 64 Tianwang, a website documenting human rights abuses in China, was taken away by personnel from the Sichuan government while she was at Beijing West Railway Station in Fengtai District (Beijing) and has been incommunicado for over a month since. She has been actively advocating for her son's release since his arrest 2 years ago. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 4 December 2018, two petitioners, who attended the study group organized by petitioners on rule of law on the Chinese Constitution Day, in Taoranting Park in Xicheng district (Beijing) were taken away by the police to Majialou Detention Centre, which is a black jail for petitioners. They were later released by the Majialou Detention Centre together with other petitioners, and they also saw three buses filled up with petitioners while they arrived at Majialou Detention Centre.

On 4 December 2018, some petitioners were taken to Jingjiuzhuang Detention Centre, a black jail, by the police and stability maintenance personnel while they were approaching Tiananmen Square in Dongcheng district (Beijing) to campaign on Constitution Day.

On 7 December 2018, the mother of a rights defender and her female companion were taken away by police officers and national stability maintenance officers in the Beijing West Railway Station in Fengtai district (Beijing). The two women were not able to be contacted thereafter and are suspected to have been held at the Sichuan government in Beijing. They were followed in Beijing while visiting to attend a civil pretrial conference of the rights defender. The mother was pushed and fell on the floor before they were taken away. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

SOURCE: Weiquanwang; The News Lens; Bitter Winter
NOTES: On 9 December 2018, the Early Rain Covenant Church was forcibly shut down, and over 100 of its members were arrested for illegal assembly across various districts in Chengdu City (Sichuan). Church leaders, workers, students, and believers were taken from their residences or dorms, and at least nine of church members were held incommunicado. During the arrests, at least 2 Christians were violently beaten up by police for resisting orders, and one had some of her hair ripped out.

On 9 December 2018, at night, police broke into the dormitories of 25 students of the Western China Academy of Humanities in Jinniu District, Chenghua District, and Qingyang District (Chengdu, Sichuan) to arrest them. 2 of the students were subjected to violence for not cooperating with an ''illegal'' investigation. At least a dozen more students were arrested over the next two days.

On 9 December 2018, the pastor of a church in Chengdu and his wife were taken away from their church by police, along with many other church members. As of 17 February 2019, the police have rejected all requests to meet with the pastor and his wife.

On 9 December 2018, a female Early Rain Covenant Church believer suffered from a miscarriage when she was arrested and interrogated at her home by the police and state security officers of Qingyang District and Caojiaxiang Residential District (Chengdu, Sichuan). She was grabbed by the hair and dragged outdoors at one point, where she was interrogated in the cold.

Around 10 December 2018 (week of), the local government took several Kazakh students in Burqin County (Ili, Xinjiang), loaded them into a lorry used to deliver pork and detained them in a walk-in freezer after the students refused to eat pork which is forbidden in the Kazakh culture. It was reported that the government in Altay Region had been forcing students to eat pork and punishing those who refused to eat it.

On 10 December 2018, Human Rights Day, a young Tibetan Buddhist monk from the Kirti Gompa Monastry was taken by the police officers while he was chanting ''Tibet needs freedom'' along the road in Ngawa County (Sichuan). He was beaten by the police during the process and held incommunicado.

On 12 December 2018, about 30 government personnel rushed to a church in West Li (Xili) Village (Sanmenxia City, Henan Province), where about 60 to 70 elderly believers held a secret gathering. While forcibly carrying the believers out of the building, an unreported number of believers suffered injuries or had their clothes torn.
On 12 December 2018, a human rights defender and disabled Vietnam war veteran from Baoji City (Shaanxi) disappeared after calling his family and has been incommunicado for at least 3.5 months.

Around 16 December 2018 (month of), a Uyghur poet from Ili prefecture (Xinjiang) (coded as Yining City) was detained and taken to a re-education camp in Urumqi. He was reportedly still detained as of mid-2019 according to his relatives. He was detained and released many times since 2002 for reading poetry interpreted as advocating for separatism. It was also alleged that his current detention was due to allowing his daughter to marry a foreign Turkish national. On 14 September 2020, he was allegedly tried in a court in relation to a 2002 poem and sentenced for inciting separatism.

On 16 December 2018, several Early Rain Covenant church members and a former teacher at the Sichuan Jiaotong University were arrested in Chengdu (Sichuan) and detained incommunicado by police for 32 hours for participating in an outdoor Sunday worship. Adherents were forced to sign statements saying they won't participate in church activities in order to be released. 3 adherents who refused were tortured and severely beaten up by police.

Around 16 December 2018 (month of), a member of the Church of Almighty God was arrested by police officers at her home in Heilongjiang Province. After being taken to the police station for interrogation. She was electrocuted for more than 20 minutes to force her to divulge information about the church. The next day, she was tortured with electric shocks on an iron chair for 40 minutes. She was subsequently taken to a detention house and detained for a month, before being released on bail.

On 18 December 2018, 300 government personnel, including those from the Luyi county government, law enforcement brigade, and the Land and Resources Bureau demolished a Three-Self church in Luyi County (Zhoukou, Henan). More than 20 vehicles were dispatched to seal off intersections nearby and to keep civillians away. A believer who tried to stop the demolition was beaten and kicked by police officers while her companion was restrained.

Around 19 December 2018 (as reported), since the mass arrest of Early Rain Covenant church in Chengdu (Sichuan) members on 9 December 2018, 6 church members have been disappeared, 18 elders are in detention, about 100 members have been monitored and followed, and 50 theology students have been sent back to their hometowns and interrogated.

On 19 December 2018, a member of the Church of Almighty God was arrested from her home in Xinyang City (Henan) by local police, who also seized electronic devices from her home. Surveillance footage showed her being restrained on a torture instrument known as a ''tiger bench'' before she collapsed in a bathroom. Her family was notified of her death the following morning.

Around 21 December 2018, not long after a Kazakh Akhoond (Islamic cleric) was released from a re-education camp in Xinjiang, he received a notice from police that they would be placing him in a ''re-education and transformation camp'' for a second time. His wife's phone was confiscated after state authorities learnt that she had notified overseas relatives about his impending arrest.

On 24 December 2018, when a Three-Self Church in Xinxiang City, Henan Province was cordoned off by the police to block believers from entering the church to celebrate Christmas, a passer-by was replying to a message on his phone and mistaken by the police for taking pictures of the scene. Six or seven police officers violently beat him for five minutes. The passer-by was reportedly bleeding from the head. 1 man injured.

SOURCE: Wen Wei Po; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 25 December 2018, a petitioner against forced demolitions killed two government officials with a knife in Xinluo, Longyan before hijacking a bus and driving it into a crowd of people, killing eight others and injuring 25.

On 26 December 2018, a Uyghur businessman was arrested in Yining city (Ili, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado. He was reportedly transferred to a re-education camp after his arrest. He had previously had difficulties with Chinese authorities in 2017. The motive for his detention is unclear.

On 26 December 2018, a Uyghur blacksmith with an iron trading business in Kazakhstan was taken by authorities from Yining City (Ili Kazak Autonomous, Xinjiang), then sent off to an ''internment camp''. It was confirmed that he had been moved among three camps within the county - Yengiyer, Boz and Yamachang - and retrained as a cook. No report of release was made known as of 4 Jan 2021.

On 26 December 2018, a previous petitioner was taken from a hotel near Guanyinsi police station in Huangcun town (Daxing, Beijing) by the police to the Majialou detention centre. When he was having a rest in the hotel after arranging the cremation of his deceased son and dealing with related issues, police officers searched his room and took him to the detention centre for unclear reasons since he had not petitioned in the past two years.

On 28 December 2018, a female Chongqing petitioner was collecting her medicine at Peking Renmin Hospital in Xicheng district (Beijing) when the police took her to a police station to register her ID, then took her to Majialou ''black jail.'' She was latered transferred back to Chongqing, where Fengdu county and Sanhe subdistrict officials took her to Chengxi police station. Two policemen handcuffed her, then forged documents in order to charge her with ''picking quarrels and provoking trouble.'' They forcibly took her to the Chongqing Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital for a body checkup.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 29 December 2018, more than 100 riot police and People's Armed Police forcibly evicted Hui Muslims from three mosques in Yongjianzhen, Weishan Yi and Hui Autonomous County, Dali Bai Autonomous Prefecture. During the raid, police dragged, shoved, and beat up civilians. Five to six rioters also pinned down and beat up a woman who was filming the incident.

On 29 December 2018, a female petitioner was beaten up by the police while on the way to Fengdu County Detention Centre (Chongqing) in a police car. They were leaving after drawing too much attention during her forced body checkup at the Chongqing Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital. She sustained multiple bruises. The Detention Centre initially refused to admit her without proof of a checkup, but ultimately, she was admitted that night and detained for three days.

On 30 December 2018, a dissident from Wuhan City was violently beaten up outside a restaurant in Hanyang District (Wuhan, Hubei) by an official from the Dongxihu District Domestic Security Protection Bureau and a high-ranking local police officer. As a heart disease patient, he suffered chest pain after being struck and was kept in police custody overnight after a visit to the hospital.

On 2 Jan 2019, a Peking University student activist involved with the Jasic Workers Solidarity Group was taken away by police in Changsha City (Hunan) and was held incommunicado for at least 8 days. His detention comes after his participation in an event commemorating Mao Zedong, during which he expressed solidarity for the Jasic workers' union.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 4 Jan 2019, the deputy governor of Zhecheng county led a team of more than 100 local officials including plainclothes and anti-riot police to shut down the True Jesus Church in Anping Town, Zhecheng County (Shangqiu, Henan) on the basis that it was illegal. Authorities forced their way into the church and took away thousands of RMB from the building. More than 60 believers tried to prevent authorities from entering and several of them were severely beaten up and sustained fractured ribs.

On 13 January 2019, a human rights defender being detained at the Hunnan District Police Station in Shenyang (Liaoning) since 29 Oct 2018 was rushed to the hospital but did not survive. His son, who was monitored by almost 20 government officials during his meeting with the doctor, was told that his father died from a heart attack.

On 13 January 2019, a petitioner was abducted from Beijing Western Train Station (Fengtai District) by 7-8 unknown people and taken to the police station at Lufeng county (Shanwei city, Guangdong Province). She was later taken to be detained in a local hotel.

On 14 January 2019, the founder of a human rights website 64tianwang.com was said to put to court in Mianyang, Sichuan. Four petitioners from Sichuan, who were on their way to show support for the founder of 64tianwang.com were abducted by more than 20 police officers on Chengdu-Mianyang Highway in Mianyang (Sichuan). They were sent back to their respective cities by government deputies. Three petitioners from Chongqing were also abducted by police on their way to Mianyang. Some were still missing by the time of reporting on 14 Jan.

On 14 January, the son of a petitioner who died in police custody was forcibly disappeared in Shenyang, Liaoning after putting up a public notice about his father's 'abnormal' death. He was unable to be contacted or located for at least 14 days and is suspected to have been kidnapped.

Around 15 January 2019 (month of), a Uyghur man (one of the former leaders of the 1988 Uyghur student movement) was arrested in Urumqi, Xinjiang (coded as Shuimogou) and sent to a 'concentration camp' for reasons unknown. He was later released in November 2019 and died one week later of a sudden heart attack on 14 November 2019.

On 15 Jan 2019, the son of a petitioner who recently died in police custody disappeared after being called in for a chat at the police station in Hunnan District (Shenyang, Liaoning). He was incommunicado for at least 55 hours thereafter and is suspected to have been kidnapped.

Around 16 January 2019 (month of), nine Kazakh women from Ghulja (Yining) county (Ili Kazak Autonomous, Xinjiang) were sent back to an 'internment' camp by the authorities after they refused to sign a labor contract with a monthly salary of 600 yuan, which was around 40 percent of a typical wage for a manual worker. Originally, they had been sent to work in the Jiafang Garments Industrial Park (in Yidong Industrial District) after being released from an internment camp, where they would work 12-hour shifts sewing gloves and undergo an hour's 'political education' every day for the money.

Around 16 January 2019 (month of) a well-known Uyghur linguist and Turkologist was detained by the authorities in Urumqi, Xinjiang and had since been held incommunicado. According to his son, it was believed that he had been sent for ''training'', though it had not been verified.

Around 16 January 2019 (month of), a Uyghur man residing in Tianshan District (Urumqi, Xinjiang) disappeared and remained incommunicado until March 2020, when his sister reported that he appeared to be released into house/town arrest and was under heavy surveillance. He had previously been arrested in September 2018 and held in a detention centre before he was released. He was a senior translator and chair of the terminology office at the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region Ethnic Language Committee, and was detained with six of his colleagues for working on a Uyghur dictionary for names for places in Xinjiang.

SOURCE: Peninsula Morning News (Liaoning); South China Morning Post
NOTES: On 16 January 2019, two archaeologists were beaten by more than 10 urban management personnel at an excavation site in Sangshujiao, Hanjiang District (Yangzhou, Jiangsu). It was reported that the assault was prompted by grievances around the illegal construction of the archaeologists. The municipal government had reported that the officers involved had been detained and given a serious warning.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Kazakh Ethnic Group (China); Muslim Group (China); Prisoners (China); Women (China)
NOTES: Around 16 January 2019 (month of), police officers tortured a Kazakh Muslim woman and her daughter during detention in the basement of a police station in Xinjiang province, with electric shock, impaling nails into their hands, tying them by their hair, and putting needles under their nails. They were detained after the woman's husband in Kazakhstan complained to rights organisations about her condition (after she had been sent to a re-education camp for 15 months after returning to China in 2017, with her passport withheld.) [women targeted: girls][women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Epoch Times; Weiquanwang
NOTES: On 17 January 2019, around 400 police and government-employed demolition personnel gathered in Qianjincun, Tangzhen, Pudong New Area (Shanghai) to forcibly evict a family of 10 and demolish their home. Government personnel forced their way into the building, set off tear gas canisters inside, and beat up five family members before arresting them. The five other family members climbed onto the roof and remained there till the next day in protest of the eviction. One of them suffered from bone fractures.

Around 17 January 2019 (from 4 to 29 January 2019), a female petitioner being detained at the Fengdu County Detention Centre (Chongqing) was beaten up by prisoners multiple times. She sustained broken ribs and multiple injuries. She was originally supposed to be released on 4 Jan, but the police extended her detention period until 29 January 2019.

On 17 Jan 2019, a petitioner was forcibly taken away by two police officers when she was in Wuchang District. She was then brought to Jiangxia District (Wuhan, Hubei) and kept there through the night by 7 'stability maintenance agents' from the Guandong Street Sub-district Office. She reportedly got sick after drinking water they offered her.

Around 18 January 2019 (week of), a Kazakh man from Kokchem village (Kuokeshimu), Jeminay County (Ili Kazakh Autonomous, Xinjiang) was taken away by the authorities to a re-education camp. His detention came three weeks after he had been released from his previous detention at a re-education camp, where he was detained for 20 months starting May 2017. The reason for his detention was not known.

SOURCE: Tibet.net; Radio Free Asia; China Aid; PEN
NOTES: On 19 January 2019, a China-born Australian author who has been critical of the Chinese government was seized from Guangzhou Airport in Baiyun District (Guangzhou, Guangdong) and taken to Beijing by state security police to be interrogated with his wife. His wife was released after the interrogation, but the author was placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) in Beijing. His RSDL term was due to expire on 19 July, but on 17 July, he was formally arrested on charges of endangering national security and transferred to a detention centre in Beijing.

On 22 Jan 2019, seven students and ex-students who are members of the Maoist Jasic Workers' Solidarity Group were allegedly abducted by state security forces in Beijing as part of a nationwide crackdown on supporters of the campaign for a union at the Jasic Technology factory in Shenzhen. The activists were unable to be contacted or located for at least 24 hours.

On 27 January 2019, a woman was beaten up by a hired thug after three stability maintenance personnel showed up at her apartment in Xixianxin district (in between Xi'an and Xianyang cities, Shaanxi). The stability maintenance officers were sent by representatives of the Weicheng subdistrict (Xianyang) office, who forbade her from leaving as she was about to head out for a morning exercise. She sustained injuries to her left eye, as well as a migraine, broken spectacles and bruises over her body.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 29 January 2019, 50 armed law enforcement officers were sent by the Commission of Housing and Urban-Rural Layout Construction to tear down a house under construction in Gangcheng Town (Guigang City, Guangxi Province). The officers attacked one of the workers who tried to protest against the demoliton. When other workers and some residents tried to intervene, the officers attacked them as well. It was also reported that at least 11 other passers-by were violently beaten.

On 30 Jan 2019, a human rights defender was kidnapped in Beijing while submitting documents related to her activism. Her family did not receive any official notice about her suspected detention. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 1 February 2019, more than 40 people (including a government official and armed police officers) came to a government-controlled Three-Self Church in Wangxinlan Village (Xinxiang City, Henan Province) to erect the Chinese national flag at the church. During the demolition of the church's walls, a number of church members stepped forward in attempt to block the demolition, and were knocked down by the government personnel. One believer was punched and kicked by more than a dozen government workers, and was subsequently taken to the hospital. He suffered two broken ribs.

On 1 February, the initiator of a joint statement calling on the Chinese government to cease all unlawful conduct was taken away by officers from the public security bureau in Beijing. He was unable to be contacted or located for at least two days and is suspected to have been kidnapped.

On 2 February 2019, a petitioner disappeared after a trip to the market in Jiading district (Shanghai) and became incommunicado. Witnesses from Huifengkaiyuan residential area on Hongshi Road saw two men in police uniform take her into a cross-country police vehicle. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions.

On 3 February 2019, a man ('founder' of un-recognised political party Zhongguo Minfudang) was cornered and assaulted by the police when he got ready to leave his residence in Jiangpu subdistrict of Pukou district (Nanjing, Jiangsu) for a haircut and bath ahead of the Spring Festival.

On 5 February 2019, on the first day of Chinese New Year, a petitioner from Zhangjiagang, Suzhou was stopped by the police while walking along West Chang'an Avenue in Xicheng District (Beijing) and taken away to the police station for interrogation. Following the interrogation, she was transferred to Majialou 'black jail' in Beijing and detained until the third day of Chinese New Year when she escaped.

SOURCE: China Political Prisoner Concern; HKFP; Made In China Journal
NOTES: On 6 February 2019, a detained labour rights activist-cum editor of Xinshengdai - a migrants' rights monitoring website - was placed under residential surveillance at a designated location (RSDL) after being caught by the Shenzhen police in Guangzhou on 8 Jan and detained at Shenzhen No.2 Detention Centre in Futian District (Shenzhen). His disappearance was part of a crackdown on students and activists advocating for workers' rights.

On 12 February 2019, a female petitioner from Zhou village, Huancheng town (Weishan, Jining, Shandong) was abducted from her home by people employed by the government and held in a nursing house in Weishan county. She was released on the 26 March 2019. It was part of a campaign by the local police to silence dissent during the annual meetings of Two Sessions.

As reported on 12 February, one of the people arrested as part of the 'Jasic Factory Labour Incident' is suspected to have been disappeared after two of his sister's requests to visit him at the No. 2 Police Station in Futian, where he was believed to be detained, were rejected on the basis that he was not there.

On 12 February 2019, an unreported number of human rights defenders were intercepted and summoned to a police station in Zaoyang City (Xiangyang City, Hubei Province) when they attended a dinner banquet organised by another human rights defender. 1 human rights defender was reportedly brutally beaten by the police at the police station during the detention the same day.

On 14 February 2019, police stormed into the home of the mother of an activist in Chengdu (Sichuan) and took away her three friends and her lawyer with force, hours after she had a meeting with ambassadors from five foreign embassies in Chengdu. She could not be contacted and was placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) since. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

In February 2019, a Born-Again house church in Zhengyang County (Zhumadian City, Henan Province) was raided by four police officers. When one of the believers tried to reason with the officers, he was beaten. The preacher and one believer were taken away by the police to the local station. It was reported that the preacher continued to remain under surveillance after his release.

On 15 Feb 2019, a human rights defender was detained in a room in the Qingchun Hotel at Nanmatou Road, Pudong New Area (Shanghai) by 2 men from the Pudong Sub-district Office and 2 men hired by a security company in Pudong. The human rights defender had had her home demolished by the government in 2005 and has yet to be compensated. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 15 Feb 2019, someone from the Gong County Government sent a human rights defender in Beijing back to Gongxian by plane. The human rights defender was not able to be contacted or located after returning to Gongxian County (Yibin, Sichuan).

On 16 February, two students who had previously been involved with the Jasic Workers Solidarity Group were suspected to have been disappeared by police in Wuhan. They were unable to be contacted or located for at least two days.

On 17 Feb 2019, a human rights defender was kidnapped in Changning District (Shanghai) by 2 unidentified plainclothes police officers. She was held incommunicado at the Huayang Police Station for at least 10 days. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 19 February, a human rights defender was beaten up by several security personnel at the Shanghai No.2 Intermediate People's Court in Jinag'an (Shanghai). He was then detained for 17 hours by the police after they framed him for beating up the security personnel.

On 20 February 2019, a human rights defender and former university lecturer from Shanghai was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' from the sub-district office after petitioning in Beijing. The officials held him in a black jail in Hengsha Island, Chongming District (Shanghai) until 15 March 2019, during which they beat him up and broke 4 of his ribs.

On 20 Feb 2019, local government officials forcibly brought a petitioner to a psychiatric hospital in Chongqing to be evaluated. The petitioner was then beaten up by a police officer when the results said she was fine.

On 20 February, a human rights defender was was kidnapped in Shanghai while en route to Beijing to carry out his activism. He was held incommunicado for at least one week. The previous day, police had framed him and detained him for 17 hours.

On 20 February 2019, a human rights activist was beaten by five people (including a police officer, district security officers, and security personnel) for not complying with their demands, causing serious pain in his right chest, when they were taking him from a train station in Shanghai to a 'black jail' on Hengsha Island. The man was stopped by the police and sent back on the train to Shanghai while he was petitioning in Beijing on 18 February 2018. He was released after being held for 23 days, where he went to the hospital for a body check-up and found fractures in his ribs.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 21 Feb 2019, the Yuanyang County government dispatched two cranes and up to 200 personnel from the United Front Work Department, the religious bureau, the riot police, and demolitions personnel, to break into the Central Church of Yuanyang in Yuanyang County (Xinxiang, Henan) and remove its cross. They beat up and clashed with a crowd of adherents who blocked their entry at the church gates and eventually managed to remove the cross and replace it with the flag of China. No injuries were reported.

On 21 February 2019, a petitioner from Wuhan City was intercepted and abducted into a black car by a government official from Wuhan City at the Xidan Post Office in Xicheng District (Beijing). His whereabouts since being taken away were unknown.

On 22 February 2019, a petitioner was escorted by personnel from the Shanghai Municipal Government to a 'black jail' on 500 Fu Cun Street in Putuo District, Shanghai upon her arrival in Shanghai. Two days ago, the petitioner was forcibly detained by the Beijing police at the State Letters and Calls Bureau, and escorted to board the train back from Beijing to Shanghai on 21 February 2019. It was reported that she had lost contact for more than 10 hours at the time of reporting.

On 22 February 2019, a female human rights defender from Shanghai was 'taken on mandatory vacation' by ten stability maintenance officers, and brought to a farm villa in the Shanghai suburbs. She escaped on 26 Feb in an attempt to catch the train to Beijing from Hongqiao Train Station, but was intercepted by national security officers and police officers who presented no identification. She was placed under criminal detention afterwards. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 22 Feb 2019, a former state television talk show host who was unable to be contacted and had not posted any social media updates was suspected to be kidnapped by state forces for at least a week before reappearing at the Communication University of China in Chaoyang (Beijing). The talk show host had been involved in a whistleblowing case regarding documents being stolen from a Supreme Court judge's office for a 100 billion yuan mineral ownership case. There was no official statement about his whereabouts during his 'disappearance'.

On 23 Feb 2019, a government official was stabbed to death by a villager in Linquan County (Fuyang, Anhui) while he was leading a team to demolish illegal buildings in the area. The assailant also attempted to attack the other officials but was restrained.

On 23 February 2019, a human rights defender was kidnapped by government personnel and thugs from the Tianning District government while she was petitioning in Beijing Municipality. She was severely beaten up before being transferred to a 'black jail' in Tianning, where she was forbidden from eating or sleeping until she was released 21 days later. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 24 February 2019, a human rights defender was kidnapped by 10 unidentified people at a bus stop in Qingyundianzhen, Daxing (Beijing) while on her way to seek medical treatment in Beijing. The assailants forced the human rights defender into a car without a license plate and drove to Hejia Hotel Yangqiao branch in Fengtai district (Beijing) (coded as Beijing-Fengtai) where they beat her up. The following day, they drove her back to Kunshan, Suzhou in another vehicle. She was detained for more than 20 days, during which she was also beaten up by officials and sustained head injuries. Upon her release, she sought medical consultation and was diagnosed with sensorineural hearing loss in her left ear and headache disorders. Previously, she had been monitoring the case of a disappeared person and had a court case scheduled for 4 March. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 24 Feb 2019, a human rights defender and Christian was detained in a guarded hospital room in Shuncheng District (Fushun, Liaoning) by 'interceptors' (people involved in intercepting petitioners or preventing them from petitioning) from the Fushun City Government after she filed a report about a lost phone at the Tianning Temple Police Station in Xicheng, Beijing. Police first detained her at the police station on the basis that she was a 'Class A controlled person' before interceptors took her away. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 24 February, the elderly mother of a pastor who was disappeared as part of a crackdown on the Early Rain Covenant Church was beaten up by an officer from the Wangjiaguai Residential District Police Station in Chengdu (Sichuan) while withdrawing money from an ATM. The police officer pulled out some of her hair and beat and kick her to the ground after she prevented him from looking at her ATM pin. The victim sustained serious injuries and was arrested by police from her home later the same day. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 24 February 2019, a Protestant church in Yuanyang (Xinxiang, Henan) was raided by police and government deputies. Dozens of Christians sang hymns and blocked the gate to prevent the truck from getting in. Many of them were beaten up and taken away by police. The cross in the church was forcibly removed.

On 24 Feb 2019, a human rights defender was picked up from his home in Jing'an District and detained in a 'black jail' housed at the the Dongtan Migratory Bird Resort in Chongming District (Shanghai).

On 24 Feb 2019, a human rights defender from Chenzhou, Hunan was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' from the Chenshou government while he was not far from the Beijing Institute of Technology in Haidian (Beijing).

On 24 February 2019, 44 members of the Early Rain Covenant Church, including women, children, and the elderly, were arrested by police while having Sunday church service in their homes in Chengdu (Sichuan). A couple was slapped by the police at the detention centre. 11 remained in detention, one of whom was beaten up the same day, another couldn't be located or contacted, and the others were released the same day.

On 25 February 2019, after a protest outside the National Health Commission in Beijing, the convener of the protest (who is also a rights defender-cum-parent affected by the Henan vaccine scandal) was taken away by stability maintenance personnel and disappeared thereafter.

On 26 February 2019, a human rights defender from Zhenjiang, Jiangsu was dragged, beaten and cuffed up by public security officers from his hometown during a lunch engagement with his wife and friends in Beijing. The couple was taken back to Zhenjiang prefecture. The rights defender was arrested and detained at the Zhenjiang police station, and his wife had some personal freedoms taken away from her. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions.

On 26 February 2019, two Shanghaiese human rights activists were intercepted by liaison officers while they were petitioning at Beijing public security office. After they boarded train G169 back to Shanghai, they continued to be incommunicado as of 3 Mar. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions.

On 26 Feb 2019, a human rights defender from Zhenjiang, Jiangsu was kidnapped by people allegedly from the Zhenjiang Police Department while having lunch near Beijing Normal University in Haidian (Beijing). He was held incommunicado for at least one day, and while being roughly carried away, his head hit the concrete floor heavily. No injuries were reported.

On 26 February 2019, the mother of a Sichuanese human rights defender was dragged and beaten by a group of stability maintenance agents in her residential district in Sichuan province. They were stalking her after she visited various government authorities with another human rights defender, and followed her home after attacking her. They attempted to enter her house and she resisted. However, a couple days later, it was said that stability maintenance agents had moved in to conduct residential surveillance on the eve of the annual Lianghui conventions. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 26 February 2019, a petitioner from Wuxi who had his home demolished was petitioning at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng when personnel from the Wuxi City government threw a hood over his head and kidnapped him back to Wuxi. He was beaten up and detained in an unknown location in Wuxi City (Jiangsu) until 2 March 2019.

On 27 Feb 2019, two human rights defenders went to discuss matters at the Ministry of Public Security in Beijing and were subsequently sent to a 'black jail' in Qingpu District (Shanghai) and a 'black jail' housed at the the Dongtan Migratory Bird Resort in Chongming District (Shanghai) respectively.

On 27 Feb 2019, two human rights defenders went to discuss matters at the Ministry of Public Security in Beijing and were subsequently sent to a 'black jail' in Qingpu District (Shanghai) and a 'black jail' housed at the the Dongtan Migratory Bird Resort in Chongming District (Shanghai) respectively.

On 27 Feb 2019, a human rights defender who had been under 24-hour house arrest in Huishan District (Wuxi, Jiangsu) since 27 Feb 2018 was severely beaten up by officers from the Security Bureau when he tried to leave home to go to the temple. He was bedridden the next day.
On 27 Feb 2019, a petitioner was pushed into a car by two men in police uniforms and driven away in Jiading District (Shanghai) while out buying vegetables. She was incommunicado after the incident.

On 27 February 2019, two petitioners from Shanghai were intercepted by liaison officers in Beijing. They were sent to 'black jails' in Zhujiajiao, Qingpu district (Shanghai) and Dongtan Migratory Bird Resort respectively. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions.

Around 27 February 2019 (week of), ten petitioners from Qiaokou district, Wuhan were intercepted by police in Beijing. They were sent to Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai district, then handed over to the Liason Office and sent back to Wuhan. Five of them were held in a detention centre for 10 days. Their abductions were reportedly related to the up-coming 13th annual Lianghui conventions, which was scheduled to begin on 3 March 2019.
On 27 February 2019, two petitioners from Wuxi became incommunicado for at least eight days - as of 6 Mar - after petitioning in Beijing. They are suspected to have been abducted.

On 27 February 2019, the father and sister of a detained human rights lawyer were picked up by 3 officers from the Domestic Security Protection Bureau in Xingyang (Henan) and were held incommunicado at a hotel until 1 March 2019. The human rights lawyer had been detained for defending lawyers who were arrested as part of the '709 crackdown' and was scheduled to be released the following day; his father and sister were en route to receive him when they were picked up.

On 27 Feb 2019, a petitioner who had been beaten up by a police officer on 20 Feb 2019 was illegally detained in the village committee 'black jail' in Fengdu County (Chongqing) by personnel from the Sanhe Subdistrict Office. She was locked in and guarded around the clock by multiple people.

On 27 Feb 2019, a human rights defender from the Liyuan Neighborhood in Xincheng, Hohhot, Inner Mongolia was kidnapped by police officers and personnel from the neighbourhood committee of the Liyuan Neighbourhood. She was kidnapped from the Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai (Beijing) and arrived home on 29 Feb 2019, reporting that she had not slept for 3 days. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 28 Feb 2019, a laid off private teacher from Hunan was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' from the Hunan government in Beijing Municipality while he was on his way to petition. He was sent home the following day.

SOURCE: The Stand News; Radio Free Asia; DW
NOTES: Around 28 February 2019 (end of month), a former student leader of the Peking University Marxist Society was detained for 5 days and attacked by the police in Beijing City.
