He was stripped for a full body search, slapped in the face, forced to listen to the 19th National Congress report for 3 hours at high volume and write a letter of guarantee to withdraw all study opportunities. His attack was believed to be related to his support for Shenzhen Jasic workers' labour struggles.

On 28 February 2019, police officers broke into the respective homes of two petitioners - one female - in Caoba town of Yucheng district (Ya'an, Sichuan) in the middle of the night. The male petitioner was taken away without being given any reason for arrest, the female petitioner was incommunicado since the incident.

Around 28 February 2019 (a month before 31 March 2019), a dissident from Rongchang District (Rongchang, Chongqing) was taken away by the local police and detained in a mental hospital for about a month. He was released on 31 March 2019 and warned by the authorities not to post online again. This was one of many times that the dissident had been sent to a mental hospital for actively speaking out against the government.

On 28 February 2019, six men hired by the Huanggang Subdistrict Office and the Comprehensive Management Commission broke in and beat up a petitioner at his house in Huanggang Subdistrict, Liangxi district (Wuxi, Jiangsu) . Police officers who arrived on scene after an emergency call left after seeing stability maintenance officers in the apartment.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; China Aid; Weiquanwang
NOTES: On 28 February 2019, a detained human rights lawyer who was scheduled to be released on 28 Feb was said to have been 'taken away' by the Domestic Security Protection Bureau when his supporters went to receive him at the Henan's Xinxiang No. 2 Prison in Xinxiang City (Henan). He was held incommunicado at a hotel near Zhengzhou City until 2 March 2019 and returned to his parents' home in Xinyang (Henan) after he started a hunger strike. His father and sister, who were among the four people to receive him at the prison, were also held incommunicado since then.

On 28 Feb 2019, a human rights defender from Huanggu District, Shenyang City, Liaoning Province was tricked and kidnapped by personnel from the Shenyang City government in Beijing. He was forcibly sent back to Shenyang City.

On 28 Feb 2019, a petitioner from Beihe Village, Gansu Province and her daughter were taken from their home in Bejing to the Huangcun Police Station in Daxing District (Beijing) by police officers and government personnel. They were incommunicado thereafter and are suspected to have been kidnapped. [women targeted: girls][women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 28 Feb 2019, police detained a human rights defender at the Beijing Majialou Relief Service Center in Fengtai (Beijing), which is known as a 'black jail' used for detaining petitioners. The human rights defender was switching trains at the Wangjing Station in Chaoyang when police approached her, and was detained for several hours before being sent back to Qianjiang City, where she is from, by government officials. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 1 March 2019, a human rights defender from Liaoning was taken away from his rented home in Fangshan District, Beijing by police officers from Fushun, Liaoning. He was then held incommunicado at a 'black jail' housed on the third floor of the Fushun Xinfu No.3 Hospital in Xinfu District (Fushun, Liaoning) for at least 22 days.

On 1 March 2019, a human rights defender from Dazhi, Hubei was intercepted by stability maintenance officers at Wuhan train station prior to his train ride to Beijing. They detained him at a hotel, and confiscated his phone, ID card and personal possessions. He was transferred to a detention centre for another fifteen days on 4 Mar.

Around 1 March 2019 (beginning of month), a petitioner was 'taken on mandatory vacation' by stability maintenance personnel from Zhanjiang prefecture (Hubei). He tried to escape and buy a train ticket to Beijing, but he was intercepted and 'taken on vacation' again until the end of the Lianghui conventions.

On 1 March 2019, a petitioner from Dongfanghong Village, Yongshun, Hunan was kidnapped by police officers, village committee members, and the mayor of her village when the train she was on stopped at the Baoding railway station in Baoding City (Hebei). She was then sent in the direction of Hubei.

On 1 March 2019, the superintendent of Huaihe subdistrict police station locked up the wife of a human rights defender at Jinxiu Hotel in the farmers market in Xi county (Xinyang, Henan). [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 1 March 2019, a human rights defender in Qiaokou District (Wuhan, Hubei) was incommunicado after leaving her home and is suspected to have been kidnapped. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 1 March 2019, a female petitioner was forcibly taken away from her temporary residence in Fangshan (Beijing) and brought to Majialou 'black jail'. She was sent back to Shanghai the next morning and admitted to a mental hospital in Changning District (Shanghai) by personnel and police from the Changning District Xianxia Sub-district Office and Police Station. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching Lianghui annual sessions.
On 1 March 2019, a petitioner was incommunicado after being intercepted by the police at a Beijing metro station. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions.

Around 1 March 2019 (beginning of month), two petitioners from Zhanjiang, Hubei were arrested in Beijing and sent to Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai district after the police checked their IDs. After being escorted home, they were detained at a hotel, transferred to a police station then ultimately placed under house arrest. They continued to be incommunicado after the Lianghui conventions had concluded as of 20 Mar.

On 1 March 2019, a man who regularly participated in activism activities prepared to be forcibly admitted to a mental institution after a one-day notice from the Fengtai district (Beijing) security forces. The incident is allegedly in relation to the apporaching annual Lianghui conventions.

On 1 March 2019, a human rights defender and retired doctor was taken to the Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai (Beijing) by personnel from the Beijing office of the Shanghai Municipal People's Government in the middle of the night.

On 2 March 2019, a mother affected by the Wuhan vaccine scandal and her friend were stopped by her village secretary and other unknown men while bringing their children for a hospital visit in Beijing. They were taken to a hotel and monitored there until she called the police for help, who did not acknowledge the abduction, but allowed her to visit the hospital as long as she was monitored and accompanied. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions.

On 2 March 2019, two petitioners from Tangshan, Hebei were raided by the police at their home in Beijing, then locked at Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai district (Beijing). The police made arrangements with other interceptors to send them back to Tangshan, and prevent them from returning to petition in Beijing. The incident was allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

On 2 March 2019, an elderly woman from Hefei was intercepted by stability maintenance officers while petitioning in Beijing. They drove her back to Hefei and detained her at Gelinhaotai Hotel until 20 Mar. The incident was allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

On 2 March 2019, 6 petitioners from Changzhou, Jiangsu were taken away from their rented accommodation in Beijing by 'interceptors' from the Changzhou Municipal Government. The petitioners were brought to Yongdingmen Hotel in Dongcheng (Beijing) and were incommunicado thereafter.

On 2 March 2019, a human rights lawyer was taken away by two police officers and an officer from the Shijiazhuang Justice Bureau in Shijiazhaung City (Hebei) to undergo 'training' and was incommunicado for at least 6 days. A few days ago, he had started a petition to propose ammendments to the constitution that would stregthen civil rights that garnered almost 1000 signatures, and he had planned to submit it during the annual meeting of the CPPCC and NPC on 5 March 2019.

On 2 March 2019, a couple from the Early Rain Covenant Church were taken away by police officers to the Taisheng Road Police Station in Qingyang District (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province). They were reportedly having a gathering with other fellow believers from the same church. During their detention, the husband was beaten by 7 to 8 police officers in his limbs, head, chest and back. They were both detained for nearly 12 hours, and the husband sustained a visible bruise to his forehead.
On 2 March 2019, a prominent human rights defender in Shanghai was not able to be contacted or located for at least one week and is suspected to have been kidnapped.

On 2 March 2019, a human rights defender was taken from his home in Beijing by police officers from Yiyang County, Luoyang, Henan and was brought first to the Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai before being detained in the Taoran Gardan Hotel in Xicheng. Police officers threatened to send him back to his registered address in Henan and he was incommunicado thereafter for at least 10 hours.

On 3 March 2019, a female human rights defender was detained at the Sheshan Forest Hotel in Sheshan National Forest Park in Shanghai. She was taken away by stability maintenance officers and policemen from Huaihai road in Shanghai just after she boarded high speed rail 108 earlier that day. She was held incommunicado for at least 15 days. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 3 March 2019, a human rights defender from Shanghai went to the Great Hall of the People in Xicheng (Beijing), the venue of the liang hui, to submit a letter of complaint and was apprehended by officers from Beijing's Xicheng Public Security Bureau. He was incommunicado thereafter for at least one week.

On 3 March 2019, more than 20 police officers from Beijing's Fangshan District government broke into the homes of petitioners in Beijing. Some petitioners were chased out of their houses, others were handed over to 'interceptors', and one was imprisioned inside one of the houses by police for at least a day.

On 4 March 2019, the 'police' arrested a rights-defender-cum-parent while she was fundraising in Beijing for disabled children. They did not produce official identification before arresting her, and the documents later produced were not stamped. She was then locked up in Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai district for a day, and sent back to Hui county (Henan). Her husband disappeared after convening a protest with her on 25 Feb. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 4 March 2019, a man was taken by the police in Weibin district, Baoji (Shaanxi) and placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location for his online criticisms of Chinese political leaders. While being detained, He was restrained on a torture instrument known as a 'tiger bench' for seven days before he fainted during lengthy interrogations. He was held incommunicado until 15 May 2019 and then placed under criminal detention on the ground of 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble.'

On 4 March 2019, a human rights defender was picked up by 'interceptor thugs' from the Xiangtan and Xiangxiang city governments at the Wuchang Railway Station in Wuchang District (Wuhan, Hubei). He was first held at a hotel room near the railway station before being transferred to another hotel room in Xiangtan City.
Since 4 March 2019, two human rights defenders from Baoshan District (Shanghai) have been incommunicado for at least 13 days and are suspected to have been kidnapped.

On 4 March 2019, four human rights defenders were forcibly detained within one of their homes in Huangxiang subdistrict of Liangxi district (Wuxi, Jiangsu) by thugs hired by the local government. While being detained, 7 thugs beat up at least 3 of them while police stood by without intervening. The victims sustained minor injuries, and were released afterwards.

On 4 March 2019, a supermarket worker and Early Rain Covenant Church member disappeared in Chengdu after public security officers took him away. He received intimidation visits at his house numerous times prior to his forced disappearance.

On 5 March 2019, a petitioner was kidnapped by officers from the Public Security Bureau after attempting to petition at the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection in Xicheng. They picked him up from the Huilongguan Station in Changping and held him at a 'black jail' housed in Maopu Hotel in Fengtai District (Beijing), before sending him back to Changsha the next day.

On 5 March 2019, a pastor from a Protestant church in Guiyang (Guizhou) was forced to ''go on mandatory holiday'' in Haikou, Hainan to treat his illness. He was accompanied by a few stability maintenance officers. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions.
Since 5 March 2019, a human rights defender from Xishan District (Wuxi, Jiangsu) has been incommunicado for at least 12 days and is suspected to have been kidnapped.

On 5 March 2019, two human rights defenders who had had their homes demolished by the government shouted slogans at the Zhongnanhai in Xicheng (Beijing) in protest of the govenrment's actions. They were abducted and incommunicado thereafter.
On 5 March 2019, two human rights defenders in Beijing were forced to return to Shanghai and were disappeared thereafter for at least 5 days.
On 5 March 2019, a human rights defender was disappeared after being forced to return to Shanghai while en route to petition in Bejing.

On 5 March 2019, a criminal justice rights defender from Hubei was locked up at Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai district (Beijing). The incident is allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

Around 5 March 2019 (within a month from 20 February 2019), a Tibetan from Tingri County (Shigatse, Tibet) was subjected to dozens of days of interrogation, beatings and re-education during a month-long detention. He was first taken away at a police checkpoint in Lazi (Lhatse) County and transferred to the Public Security Bureau on 20 Feb. Chinese officials claimed that he had contacted foreigners and discussed about the importance of teaching Tibetan language to Tibetan chidlren.

On 5 March 2019, two petitioners-cum-forced evictees from Beizhan subdistrict of Jing'an district, Shanghai were intercepted by liaison officers in Beijing while they were visiting to petition. They were then made to board train 1461 back to Shanghai and were incommunicado at least until 8 Mar. The incident is allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

On 5 March 2019, the police intercepted two female petitioners-cum-forced-evictees from Pudong New Area, Shanghai once they got off a bus in Beijing and had their identity documents checked. After they were sent back to Shanghai, one of them was detained at the Pudong New Area police station, while the other forcibly disappeared. The incident is allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

On 5 March 2019, a human rights activist was intercepted by staff members from the Jiangsu Office in Beijing. She was then escorted to Jinjiang Inn 'black jail' in Baoshan District, Shanghai, where she was illegally detained. She escaped from the 'black jail' on 8 March 2019 and returned to Beijing by train on 12 March 2019 to further defend her rights. At Beijing South Railway Station, she was once again stopped by staff members of the Beijing Office and sent back to Shanghai on the same day by train. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 5 March 2019, a human rights defender who had just been released from prison after serving a 4-year sentence was kidnapped by more than 10 men beside the bus stop at Jiangshan Road and Sanquan Road in Huiji district (Zhengzhou, Henan). It was reported that authorities arrived in 3 to 4 private cars and pushed her inside. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 5 March 2019, a petitioner from Chenzhuang Village, Hewu Town, Henan and her daughter were kidnapped by officials from the Hewu Township Government while they were in Songzhuangzhen Town in Tongzhou District (Beijing). They were brought to the Hewu Town Police Station and were incommunicado thereafter. [women targeted: girls][women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 5 March 2019, a human rights defender from Pudong New Area, Shanghai was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' backed by the Shanhai government while she was in Beijing Municipality. She was sent back to Shanghai and detained at a 'black jail' in Hengsha Island. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 6 March 2019, a human rights defender from Zoucheng, Shandong was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' backed by the Zoucheng government while he was in Beijing Municipality. He was sent in the direction of Shandong.

On 6 March 2019, a human rights defender from Dasheng Village, Douhudi, Hubei was kidnapped by 7-8 'stability maintenance agents' from the Douhudi government while he was at the Beijing Xinfadi Market in Fengtai (Beijing). He was pushed into a car and sent in the direction of Hubei.
On 6 March 2019, a petitioner was intercepted at the Hongqiao Railway Station in Minhang District (Shanghai). He was incommunicado thereafter and is suspected to have been kidnapped.

On 6 March 2019, a female petitioner from Liangxi district, Wuxi was carried away from her rental accommodation in Beijing, and thrown into a car by four thugs hired by liaison officers. They stomped on her and took her phone away. She was not allowed to seek medical help.

On 6 March 2019, a petitioner from a herder community in New Barag Right Banner, Hulun Buir was petitioning in Beijing when she was detained by two police officers from the banner government. She was incommunicado thereafter and is suspected to have been kidnapped.

On 6 March 2019, a petitioner from Hejian, Hebei was kidnapped and sent back to her hometown by 'interceptors' from the Hejian government while she was petitioning at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng (Beijing). No further report.

On 6 March 2019, a former police officer from Hezhuang Township, Cangzhou, Hebei, his mother, and brother, went to petition at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng (Beijing) when they were detained in the reception department of the Bureau by security personnel and police. Their identification documents were taken away from them while they were held there.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 6 March 2019, officers claiming to work for the State Bureau for Letters and Calls intercepted and kidnapped two female petitioners from Chengjiang subdistrict of Jiangyin, Jiangsu while they were lining up at the State Bureau in Chaoyang district (Beijing). They took their identity cards and cell devices. On 7 Mar, liaison public security officers took them back the Jiangyin, where one of them fled upon arrival at Changzhou North train station. The other was forced onto the next train, and was later seen taken away by a dozen special police from the petitioning bureau. She continued to be incommunicado as of 11 Mar.

On 7 March 2019, two human rights defenders were kidnapped by unidentified persons in Beijing and were incommunicado thereafter. This was reportedly related to the stability maintenance around and during the Lianghui sessions.

On 7 March 2019, a human rights defender was forced to return to Shanghai by train after being apprehended by personnel from the Shanghai government while carrying out his activism in Beijing. He was disappeared thereafter for at least 5 days.

On 7 March 2019, a rights defender from Shanghai was forced to board train 1461 from Beijing back to Shanghai and disappeared for at least two days thereafter. He had first been intercepted on 5 March 2019 by liaison officers in Beijing. The incident is allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.
On 7 March 2019, a female petitioner was incommunicado after being taken away by some people in Beijing. The incident is allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

On 7 March 2019, the husband of a petitioner from Pingdu, Shandong was kidnapped by a Pingdu City judge after petitioning at the Supreme People's Court in Chaoyang (Beijing). He was sent in the direction of Shandong.

On 7 March 2019, a former police officer and his brother, who had been held at the reception department of the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng (Beijing) the previous day, were kidnapped, beaten up, and kicked by officials from the Hezhuang Township while leaving the Bureau. Their faces became swollen as a result.

As reported on 8 March 2019, a petitioner was detained in a hotel after being intercepted in Beijing and sent back to Hubei. He had previously signed an online petition to propose amendments to the constitution that would strengthen civil rights, but the reason for his visit to Beijing and subsequent arrest is unclear.

As reported around 8 March 2019, a Tibetan man was arrested and detained from Shigatse (also known as Rikaze Prefecture City, Tibet Autonomous Region) by the police on his way home from a business trip to Lhasa. He was held incommunicado since. There was no information about his charges or whereabouts by the time of report on 12 November 2019. It was reported that his arrest may be linked with his sharing of Tibetan books on WeChat, a popular Chinese social media platform.

On 8 March 2019, a human rights defender in Beijing being monitored by Shanghai government officials was handed over to 'stability maintenance agents' from the Pudong New Area government and sent to Shanghai. He was incommunicado thereafter and is suspected to have been kidnapped.
On 8 March 2019, a human rights defender from Pudong New Area, Shanghai was intercepted by liaison officers in Beijing. He was incommunicado ever since he boarded a train back to Shanghai on 10 Mar.

On 8 March 2019, 4 human rights defenders were picked up from their rented home in Beijing Municipality by police officers from the Fangshan District Public Security Bureau. They were incommunicado for at least 48 hours thereafter.

On 8 March 2019, a human rights defender from Shenyang was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' from the Shenyang City government from her home in Beijing and sent to Shenyang. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 8 March 2019, a human rights defender from Heilongjiang was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' from the Heilongjiang government near her home in Beijing. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 8 March 2019, a female human rights defender was kidnapped at Wangzhuang of Fengtai district (Beijing) by the court police from her hometown. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 8 March 2019, a human rights defender from Liaoning was kidnapped by personnel from the Liaoning Court while she was in Fengtai (Beijing). [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 8 March 2019, two people from Shuangliu district, Chengdu were delivering mail at Lixue Hutong in Xicheng district (Beijing) when they were stopped by the local police and taken to Fuyou Street police station. Three hours later, several unidentified men drove away one of the detainees by car, and the situation of the other detainee remained unknown.

As reported on 8 March 2019, two petitioners-cum-forced evictees from the same family in Huangpu, Shanghai were incommunicado after being intercepted at the Beijing High Court in Zhongnanhai, Xicheng district (Beijing) by government authorities from their hometown. Another family member was arrested on 6 Mar and sentenced to a one-month detention for a separate petition on the same issue.

On 8 March 2019, a woman from Linjiang, Baishan, Jilin was kidnapped at Xidan commercial area in Xicheng district (Beijing) by unidentified persons and became incommunicado for at least six days since. Her friend witnessed the incident but was not arrested. The incident was allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

On 8 March 2019, a petitioner who had had her home demolished was picked up by 2 'stability maintenance' police officers in Xicheng (Beijing) and detained at the Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai before being sent back to Zhenjiang, Jiangsu by a police officer from Runzhou District, Zhenjiang and someone from the Zhenjiang Transportation Industry Group. She did not return home for more than 24 hours thereafter and is suspected to have been detained.
On 9 March 2019, a human rights defender from Shanghai Municipality was intercepted by police officers and was incommunicado thereafter for at least 9 days.

On 9 March 2019, a rights defender from Shanghai was intercepted by liaison officers in Beijing and locked in a 'black jail' after returning to Shanghai. It was his fourth time being locked in a 'black jail,' and the incident is allegedly related to the approaching annual Lianghui conventions.

On 9 March 2019, a human rights defender from Huahuang Village, Liangzihu, Hubei was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' backed by the Huahuang Village government at the Shijiazhuang Railway Station in Qiaoxi District (Shijiazhuang, Hebei) while en route to Beijing. He was forced to get on the train to Hankou, Wuhan.

On 9 March 2019, a Shaanxi petitioner went incommunicado after he last informed a friend about being chased near his factory in Yanjiao town (Sanhe, Hebei) by the village chief and stability maintenance chief-of-staff of Ximing village, Chisha town, Chencang district of Baoji city. He was incommunicado for at least 11 days as of 20 Mar.

On 9 March 2019, a petitioner from Chongqing was intercepted and placed under 'house arrest' on the 17th floor of Tianhe Hotel in Jinshui district (Zhengzhou, Henan). He had bought a train ticket to Hebi prefecture and was planning to visit Beijing. The incident was allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

On 9 March 2019, a female human rights defender from Shanghai was intercepted by liaison officers on Chang'an Avenue, Beijing and has been incommunicado since. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

Around 10 March 2019 (between 5 - 15 March), during the annual Lianghui conventions, a female petitioner and her mother living in Changning district (Shanghai) were invaded at their residence by district government-hired thugs, and injured. Leading up to the incident, she had been in discussion with the Huayang Rd Sub-district's Head of Petitions, who wanted to convince her to cancel her planned visit to the People's Supreme Court in Beijing. At the time of the attack, she already agreed - in good faith - to cancel her visit to the People's Supreme Court in Beijing, where she had planned to report unlawful procedures and forgery of documents by local officials during a house expropriation case in 2016. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 10 March 2019, 6 petitioners travelling from Hong Kong to Beijing were held in a restricted area within the Beijing West Railway Station in Haidian District (Beijing) by border police for 3 days before being sent back to their homes. Another petitioner in the same group was held in a 'black jail' housed in a hotel in a suburban area.

On 10 March 2019, policemen from Shandong broke into the rental apartment of a woman from Hunan who was in search of a missing child after seeing an online post. She has been incommunicado since they took her away.

On 10 March 2019, a human rights defender from Jiamusi, Heilongjiang was kidnapped while petitioning in Beijing Municipality and was incommunicado thereafter. Officials said that he had been sent home.

On 11 March 2019, a writer and well-known dissident from Hunan who was being detained at a hotel in Liuze Town (Shaoyang City, Hunan Province) was slapped and violently dragged through the elevator from the first to fifth floor by the Party Committee Deputy Secretary of Liuze Town. The deputy secretary hit the writer's head with a remote control and kicked his head. The writer retaliated by kicking the deputy secretary. The writer had originally been intercepted at Shaodong Railway Station, Shaoyang on 28 February 2019 and was taken away by four stability maintenance personnel led by a Liuze Town official.

On 11 March 2019, a female activist from Wuxi, Jiangsu was abducted in Xicheng, Beijing by nine suspected stability maintenance officials from Wuxi and was since then held incommunicado. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 11 March 2019, a female human rights defender from Luwan district, Shanghai was intercepted at Hongqiao train station in Minhang district as she was boarding a train to Beijing. Unknown men and a policemen from Zhunhai police station locked her up at Yirenyuan elderly apartment in Qingpu district, then transferred her to Taohua village in Nanhui district in Pudong New Area. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 11 March 2019, a human rights defender, who was also a petitioner-cum-forced evictee, from Changzhou, Jiangsu was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' from the Changzhou City Qinglong Subdistrict Office while he was at McDonald's in Guang'anmen, Xicheng District (Beijing). He was incommunicado thereafter for at least 11 days and was suspected to have been held in a 'black jail' in Tianning District, Changzhou. Police officers reportedly said that he would not be released until 'matters were settled' regarding the cremation of his wife, whose body remained unburied after she drank pesticide in protest of forced demolitions and died in Oct 2015.

On 11 March 2019, a human rights defender was forcibly sent back to Shanghai by 'stability maintenance agents' from the Shanghai Government Office in Beijing after he petitioned at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng. He was then detained at a 'black jail' housed in a rural tourism centre at Changxing Island in Chongming District (Shanghai).

On 11 March 2019, a female petitioner from Wuxi, Jiangsu was intercepted by liaison officers at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Chaoyang district (Beijing), then detained at Room 511 of Jinghua Hotel. She was sent back to Wuxi the following day, and guarded in Room 101 of 61 Jinguiyuan residential estate. The incident was allegedly related to the Lianghui annual sessions.

On 11 March 2019, four female petitioners from Wuxi, Jiangsu were interepted by the police in Beijing and detained in Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai district. By 12 Mar, three of them received detention periods back in Wuxi, but one of them remained incommunicado. The incident was allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions.

Around 11 March 2019 (for 28 days starting 25 February), an online democracy activist was held and forcibly medicated in a psychiatric hospital. He was sent to the hospital on 25 Feb, shortly after being released for his 18 Jan arrest, where ten plainclothes and special police officers ambushed him at Guanyinqiao Guangchang (Plaza) in Jiangbei district (Chongqing) and detained him at a nearby police station for 37 days. He was detained while making a public appearance advocating for democracy in China, which he had publicised in a WeChat group earlier the same day. At the psychiatric ward, he was forced to take hospital-administered pills three times a day (suspected sedatives and stimulants), and experienced side effects including nausea, vomiting (with blood), and deterioration in liver and kidney function. After 28 days, he signed an agreement to stop all advocacy efforts, and was approved for release.

On 12 March 2019, a dozen people from the subdistrict office broke into the home of a female human rights defender in Dianjiang county (Chongqing), and took her forcefully to a mental hospital for a determination of mental illness. The incident was allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 12 March 2019, a female human rights defender from Pudong New Area, Shanghai was arrested at Meilia Hotel in Fengxian district (Shanghai) then locked up in Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai district, Beijing. Her situation remained unknown. The incident was allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 12 March 2019, a female human rights defender was taken from her apartment in Shanghai by the superintendent of Zhijiang West Road police station and his men. They brought her to a 'black jail' in Suzhou. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 12 March 2019, a human rights defender from Shanghai was picked up from her home and detained at a 'black jail' in Suzhou City (Jiangsu) by police officers from Shanghai's Jing'an District Public Security Bureau. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 12 March 2019, a human rights defender from Daqing, Heiliongjiang was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents from the Dawing government while he was petitioning at the Ministry of Agriculture in Chaoyang (Beijing). He was then forced to board a train headed to Daqing.

On 13 March 2019, a man from Yunting subdistrict of Jiangyin, Jiangsu was petitioning at the Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng district (Beijing) when thugs from his subdistrict kidnapped him and drove him to the liaison office. He was incommunicado since.

On 13 March 2019, the police checked a woman's ID, then took her to the Xi'anmen police station in Xicheng district (Beijing) and locked her up at Majialou 'black jail.' Four policemen from her hometown - Zhanqian district of Yingkou city, Liaoning - drove her back in a special police car.

On 13 March 2019, a human rights defender from Putuo District, Shanghai was kidnapped by 'stability maintenance agents' backed by the Putuo District government while he was petitioning at the Ministry of Public Security in Dongcheng District (Beijing). He was taken into a car by more than 10 people and sent in the direction of Nantong, Jiangsu.

On 13 March 2019, a human rights defender was picked up by more than 20 people including police officers, personnel from the Putuo District Bureau for Letters and Calls, and private security personnel while he was at the Shanghai Hongqiao railway station in Minhang. He was then detained at a 'black jail' in Qingpu District (Shanghai).

On 13 March 2019, a human rights activist was assaulted by a group of several police and government employees while he was visiting and having lunch with a political dissident who was detained at his home in Xiangtang village (Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province). The security personnel had been stationed at the residence of the dissident for surveillance. It was reported that the human right activist suffered bruises to his face and severe pain in his waist and legs, while the dissident sustained some minor injuries.

On 13 March 2019, a human rights defender from Shanghai was kidnapped from the Shanghai Railway Station in Jing'an District (Shanghai) by 7-8 'stability manintenance agents' backed by the Shanghai government while he was en route to Beijing. He was incommunicado thereafter.

On 13 March 2019, 3 police officers broke into the home of a petitioner in Xuetian Village/Xuetiancun (Jingang Town, Zhangjiagang, Suzhou, Jiangsu), broke her things, and beat and pushed her until she wasn't able to get up from the floor or bend her waist. After the attack, hospital and police personnel refused to see to her and her assailants continued to monitor her.
On 13 March 2019, a female villager at Zhangjiagang (Suzhou City, Jiangsu Province) was beaten by government employees when they tried to confiscate her family's contracted farm land.

On 13 March 2019, a petitioner from Yongchuan District was beaten by police officers while he was detained under re-education through labour in a prison in Yongchuan District (Chongqing). The petitioner was forcibly dragged into an office and handcuffed, before the police officer started beating and kicking him. The petition had previously been detained several times since 1995 for refusing to pay an arbitrary agriculture tax imposed on him by the township government.

On 13 March 2019, five female Shanghaiese human rights defenders were detained at Youwai police station in Fengtai district (Beijing) after being intercepted by the police as they were boarding the 102 bus at Beijing South station in Fengtai District. They were then sent back to Shanghai by train, one of them was locked up in a 'black jail' in Qingpu district by five police men and more than 20 'black security guards.' Three others experienced forced disappearance, and the remaining rights defender was sent home with a 'black security guard' guarding at her door. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 13 March 2019, a female Shanghaiese human rights defender was intercepted by the police while traveling on the bus down 102 Road in Beijing. They confiscated her ID card and sent her back to Shanghai the same night. She had been incommunicado since for at least two days as of 15 Mar. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 13 March 2019, 3 women human rights defenders were detained by police at the You'anmen District Police Station in Fengtai while en route to petition. They were then forced to board a train back to Shanghai Municipality by a police officer and are suspected to have been kidnapped thereafter. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 13 March 2019, a human rights defender from Shanghai was forced to board a train back to Shanghai by police officers after petitioning at the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng (Beijing). She was suspected to have been kidnapped for at least 2 days after arriving in Shanghai Municipality. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 14 March 2019, a human rights defender from Guangzhou was visiting a friend - 'founder' of un-recognised political party Zhongguo Minfudang, who was under illegal house arrest - in Jiangpu subdistrict of Pukou district (Nanjing, Jiangsu) when he was caught from behind by a few undercover police officers. They twisted his arm, and he expressed pain. The rights defender was driven to Zhujiang police station, and shut in a small, black room for eight hours without food or water. When he fainted from hunger, they called the ambulence for him, then took him to the train station and forced him to leave Nanjing.

On 14 March 2019, a human rights defender from Yangjian Township, Wuxi was detained by police at the Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai District (Beijing) after submitting a letter to CPC Central Committee leaders. He was then forcibly sent back to Wuxi.

On 14 March 2019, two Shanghaiese human rights defenders were stopped on the streets in Beijing when the police pulled up records showing that they had 'picked quarrels and provoked trouble' in the past. They disappeared when multiple policemen kidnapped them to 'an illegal concentration camp' at Dongrongxian Hutong.

On 14 March 2019, 2 human rights defenders from Shanghai were walking about in Beijing when police officers sent them to an 'illegal concentration camp' located in Dongrongxian Hutong in Xicheng District (Beijing). They are suspected to have been forcibly disappeared for at least two days.
On 14 March 2019, a human rights defender petitioned at the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development in Haidian District (Beijing) and is suspected to have been kidnapped then.

On 14 March 2019, a woman from Shenbei New Area of Shenyang, Liaoning was waiting for the train at a station in Beijing when a police officer from Dongcheng District took her away. She went incommunicado for at least fourteen days, and there were reportedly no records of her arrest at the police station.

On 14 March 2019, a female petitioner from Wuxi, Jiangsu, was kidnapped by local community personnel in Beijing Municipality and forcibly sent back to Nanquan police station in Binhu, Wuxi. Two days later, she was put under RSDL in a room in a community with no access to food or water, and attempted to jump off the building from the window but failed. She was relocated to another room on the same day and was under surveillance of seven people.

On 14 March 2019, a female Chongqing human rights defender was transferred to Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai district from the Fuyoujie police station in Xicheng district (Beijing), where she had been held since 12 Mar after the police stopped her near Xi'anmen to checked her identity. She was later transferred to 602 Wangjingyuan in Chaoyang district. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 14 March 2019, a man wielding two cleavers attacked 17 students outside a primary school in Tangshan City (Hebei) while they were waiting to be let in. The assailant, who was arrested at the scene, claimed that he had been 'forced to do so' by the former chief of the public security bureau. All the victims were hospitalised but none sustained life-threathening injuries.
On 14 March 2019, a female petitioner was stopped at Lixue Hutong in Xicheng District, Beijing by the police and taken away. Her whereabouts were unknown.

On 14 March 2019, a woman from Yangpu District, Shanghai was forcibly abducted by police officers (including plainclothes officers) on orders of the Yangpu District Letters and Calls Bureau when she was submitting a complaint at the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development in Haidian District, Beijing. It was reported that six police officers and plainclothes police beat her up, slapped her and sat on her. She was later sent back on the train to Shanghai. Details of her injuries were not confirmed.

On 15 March 2019, a petitioner was intercepted by Wuxi city government officials in Beijing after petitioning. She was subsequently held incommunicado in an apartment in Wuxi, Jiangsu for 5 days before being placed under home arrest.

On 15 March 2019, a petitioner from Nonglian village, Huazhuang town of Wuxi, Jiangsu was intercepted by liaison officers in Beijing for petitioning about his local government. He was escorted back to Wuxi, and went incommunicado after reaching Wuxi East station.

Around 15 March 2019 (between 14-16 March), a female petitioner was intercepted by local 'thugs' after she came out of a police station in Beijing and put in a 'black jail' in Shenxi Village in Jiangyin, Jiangsu.

On 15 March 2019, a pig farmer and Early Rain Covenant Church member from Chengdu disappeared in Hangzhou after the police were seen visiting his rental apartment. His clothes and belongings were left behind, but his phone, laptop and the landlord's computer were missing.

On 15 March 2019, a human rights defender and former chief of the district petitioning bureau from Qingyang district of Chengdu, Sichuan was stripped naked, had unknown items forced into his mouth, and allegedly poisoned at the Qingyang Public Security Case Handling Centre (Chengdu, Sichuan) after being arrested by public security personnel and police forces.

On 15 March 2019, a petitioner from Matoupu town of Li county (Changde, Hunan) went incommunicado. His house was robbed by the deputy chief of the town and emptied after all of his possessions were taken.

On 15 March 2019, a worshipper of the Protestant Early Rain Covenant Church went incommunicado in Chengdu (Sichuan), and was reportedly last seen at Hangzhou East Station with undercover officers, his head shaved and his hands cuffed. His location remained unknown as of 23 Apr, and the arrest was reportedly in connection with the Early Rain Covenant Church shutdown in Chengdu on 9 December 2018.

On 15 March 2019, a man was arrested by Chengdu police (Sichuan Province) and was held incommunicado until 5 July. He was released on 24 October 2019. His arrest was reportedly in connection with the shut down of Early Rain Covenant Church in Chengdu on 9 December 2018. He has worked extensively with American and Hong Kong organizations to collect information in relation to the treatment of prisoners and the death penalty in China.
On 15 March 2019, a Shanghaiese petitioner went incommunicado after petitioning at the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development in Haidian district (Beijing).

Around 16 March 2019 (month of), a female Church of Almighty God member from Xinjiang province (coded to Shuimogou) was arrested and tortured during a unified police operation against her Church. She was cuffed to a tiger bench in the interrogation room. When she resisted identifying Uyghur and Han Chinese CAG members, she was slapped, punched in the stomach and hit with a shovel handle in a bathroom. She was then sent to a vocational skills training centre ''political camp'' at an unreported time.

On 17 March 2019, a female petitioner was beaten by her community office director and other employees when she was waiting to meet people from the Luyang District government offices (Hefei City, Anhui Province). She was forcibly taken back to her community. She reported the case to the Hefei police but the police refused to assist with the case. It was reported that the petitioner had appealed several times against the demolition of her house, where she was not resettled as promised.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: ACFTU: All-China Federation of Trade Unions; Labour Group (China); Teachers (China); Women (China)
NOTES: On 19 March 2019, a female teacher from Haimen, Jiangsu was intercepted and beaten by many unidentified thugs while she was boarding a bus at Taoranqiao North Bus Station in Xicheng District (Beijing). She was carrying documents on behalf of the Ministry of Education and All-China Federation of Trade Unions, and on her way to submit her appeal to the National Letters and Calls Bureau. While they were driving her to the police station in Yuelai town (Jiangsu), she was coerced into urinating in front of all the men. She was interrogated for more than two hours by more than 10 people (including the chief of the police station and the secretary of the local government). At Taoranqiao North Bus Station, a fellow petitioner tried calling the police, but was also beaten up by five to six unidentified persons. The female teacher reportedly sustained bruises to her arms and right calf.

On 19 March 2019, a farmer-turned-human rights defender from Shanghai was secretly taken away by Shanghai police from her home. It is not known why she was taken away. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 20 March 2019, a female human rights defender was arrested from her home in Shanghai by the police together with her husband. While her husband was released on probation in April, she had been held incommunicado for more than 6 months until the authority announced that she was charged with 'subversion of state power' in October 2019. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

SOURCE: Weiquanwang; Radio Free Asia; Made In China Journal; HKFP
NOTES: On 20 March 2019, the labour rights activist-cum-editor of Xinshengdai - a migrants' rights monitoring website - was incommunicado for at least 24 hours, and suspected to have been kidnapped by police officers from Guangdong Province, as his co-editor had been arrested in Guangzhou city (Guangdong) the same day. On 26 March, it was made known that the editor was detained by the Shenzhen Pingshan Public Security Office at No. 2 Detention Centre for 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble'. Their disappearances were part of a crackdown on students and activists advocating for workers' rights. On 19 April, the activist and his colleague were placed under residential surveillance at a designated location (RSDL).

Around 20 March 2019 (in the week before 27 March 2019), almost a thousand family members of the deceased and the missing were sent to hotels in outlying counties and cities of Yancheng prefecture (Jiangsu) ahead of the government-organised memorial on the seventh day of an industrial explosion accident involving a chemical factory in Yancheng. It was an effort to 'maintain stability' and 'prevent them from congregating' after some family members had partaken in protests at county governments. At least one family was reported to have been arranged to stay in a hotel in Binhai district.

On 21 March 2019, the former editor of Maoist website Red Reference - and now editor at a cultural organisation - was charged with 'inciting subservion of state power' by the Nanjing Ministry of State Security (Jiangsu), and placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL). The organisation was involved in the Jiashi workers unionization labour movement, and the Ministry was allegedly concerned with domestic non-government organisations that received funding from overseas. The editor usually worked in Nanjing, but also lived in Shanghai.

On 22 March 2019, a Uyghur man (a literature and calligraphy instructor at the Kumul Normal Institute) was detained by the authorities in Hami City, Xinjiang and had since been held incommunicado. The reason for his detention was not known.

On 22 March 2019, three people were kicked and beaten during a forced eviction operation led by dozens of Tiefeng District urban management officials and dozens of private security personnel on Chun Hong St, Tiefeng district (Qiqihar, Heilongjiang). They were later hospitalised. Four shops were destroyed. It was also reported that two out of the four were briefly held at a ''temporary office'' of the Urban Management Bureau, where they were physically threatened and assaulted again.

As reported on 26 March 2019, a woman petitioner from Yaohai district, Hefei, who was being held in administrative detention in Hefei city (Anhui), was transferred to a hotel and held there for 7 more days before being allowed to go home. Her niece was also detained at the hotel for seven days. The incident was allegedly related to the annual Lianghui conventions. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 26 March 2019, two human rights defenders from Tianning district, Changzhou, Jiangsu were abducted by liaison officers once their train reached the platform in Beijing. They were detained Yongdingmen Hotel for the night, then at another hotel until 15 Mar after they were driven back to Changzhou by hired thugs, subdistrict officers and policemen from Qinglong station.

During the last week of March 2019, an Uyghur businessman died at a local hospital in Xinjiang after being brought in from a re-education camp for medical treatment. The official cause of death was 'myocardial arrest,' but authorities refused to release his remains, and prepared his burial without allowing the involvement of family members.

On 27 March 2019, a human rights defender from Shenbei New Area, Shenyang was taken away by Dongcheng District police while she was waiting for her train home at Beijing railway station in Dongcheng District (Beijing). The Dongcheng police said that they were going to hand her over to local police in Shenyang and the human rights defender has been incommunicado for at least 14 days. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

As reported on 27 March 2019, two petitioners from Horqin Right Middle Banner, Inner Mongolia were intercepted in Beijing by local authorities for paying a visit to Zhongnanhai, and sent to the Majialou Relief Service Centre 'black jail.'

On 28 March 2019, after the annual Lianghui conventions, a female petitioner was attacked in Beijing municipality by an unidentified party who had been following her. Her main purpose of travel to Beijing was to visit the People's Supreme Court, where she had planned to report unlawful procedures and forgery of documents by local officials during a house expropriation case in 2016. Leading up to the incident, the Head of Petitions of her hometown - Huayang Rd Subdistrict of Changning district, Shanghai - had been convincing her out of her petition plans.

Around 1 April 2019 (beginning of month), a Tibetan master's degree student was forcefully taken from Northwest Minzu University in Chengguan district (Lanzhou, Gansu) by the Tibet Education Bureau after he wrote an essay for his civil service entrance exam criticising the falling number of government job opportunities for Tibetans. On social media platforms such as WeChat, his essay was circulated and went viral. As of 1 May 2019, his location and condition of his arrest remain unknown.

On 2 April 2019, 2 Christian women were detained by the police in Chaoyang district in Beijing presumably for the religious gathering they joined the day before. After the detention, one woman escaped to the US, while the other woman lost contact for at least 3 months since and her whereabouts remain unknown.

On 4 April 2019, a Uyghur blacksmith with an iron trading business in Kazakhstan was taken by authorities from Yining City (Ili Kazak Autonomous, Xinjiang), then sent off to an ''internment camp''. It was confirmed that he had been moved among three camps within the county - Yengiyer, Boz and Yamachang - and retrained as a cook. No report of release was made known as of 4 Jan 2021.

On 4 April 2019, a Uyghur tradesman was arrested in Yining city (Ili, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado. He was reportedly transferred to a re-education camp after his arrest. He had previously had difficulties with Chinese authorities in 2017. The motive for his detention is unclear.

On 9 April 2019, a petitioner was taken away by Ya'an city government officials in Beijing for leading a group of people to petition in Beijing. He was subsequently detained in a police station in Ya'an city before being forcibly admitted into a mental hospital by authorities.

On 12 April 2019, a female petitioner from Zhou village, Huancheng town (Weishan, Jining, Shandong) was abducted from her home by people employed by the government and held in a nursing house in Weishan county (Jining City, Shandong Province). She was released on the 1 May 2019. This is the second time she's been abducted since 12 February. It was part of a campaign by the local police to silence dissent before and during the second Belt and Road Forum on International Cooperation which held in Beijing on April 25-27.

Around 14 April 2019 (between 13-16 April 2019), a female rights activist was beaten up once by 'stability maintenance' officials from the neighbourhood committee in her village in Chongqing and held under house arrest for four days. She was among several hundred civilians - petitioners, rights defenders and dissidents - held incommunicado or subjected to house confinement due to President Xi's visit to Chongqing on 15 Apr. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]
In April 2019, more than 20 young Muslim Kazakhs in Wusu (Tarbagatay, Xinjiang) were forcibly sent to other Chinese provinces by the police. Their whereabouts have been unknown thereafter.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Uyghur Ethnic Group (China); Teachers (China); CPC: Communist Party of China
NOTES: Around 15 April 2019 (month of), a Uyghur high school teacher (also reportedly a CPC member) from Dongcheng subdistrict, Kuqa County (Aksu, Xinjiang) was taken away by the police and detained incommunicado, reportedly in a re-education camp. The reason for his detention was not known.

Around 15 April 2019 (month of), a woman was violently treated by demolition officials during the forced demolition (government operation) of a garage in Mingjing village of Panyu district (Guangdong, Guangzhou).

On 15 April 2019, a petitioner was beaten up in a car at the public security bureau in Gu'an county of Langfang city, Hebei after interceptors escorted him back from his petitioning activities in Beijing, and arrested him. His family called the emergency hotline for help, but officials said emergency rooms were full and refused. Doctors at the Gu'an Renmin Hospital also refused to prescribe him painkillers when he was sent there the next day.

On 15 April 2019, a netizen was incommunicado after being detained by the Nantong prefecture police (Jiangsu). Officials searched his house the next day, but did not explain their allegations or reason for detention. The detainee was an online activist who often published articles, and petitioned for the list of victims in the '3.21' Xiangshui County Industrial Park explosion to be released.

In April 2019, an Uyghur high school teacher from Kuqa County, Xinjiang was sent to a re-education camp in Kuqa County (Aksu, Xinjiang). It was reported that an unidentified official had confirmed that the teacher was detained in the re-education camp in the county, but did not specify the reasons for his detention.

As reported on 17 April 2019, a Chinese military doctor and whistleblower, who had exposed the SARS epidemic in China in 2003, was incommunicado after being admitted to the high-risk ward at the respiratory department of No.301 Hospital in Beijing on 8 April 2018. It is reported that he was prevented from leaving the hospital and is believed to be under house arrest at an unknown location after he wrote to President Xi Jinping during the annual parliamentary sessions in Beijing the previous month.

Around 17 April 2019 (between 16 and 18 April 2019), Shandong police began hunting The Churches of Almighty God in Dezhou, Tai'an and Liaocheng (Shandong). More than 50 Christians had been arrested. The whereabouts of several church leaders were unknown thereafter, at least until 10 May 2019. The police confiscated cash, computers, books, and other faith-related belongings. This is part of the campaign to crack down on The Churches of Almighty God in Shandong.

On 17 April 2019, an independent writer was taken away by police at the Taining Buddhist Association in Fujian and his whereabouts were unknown thereafter. He had published a regular article on Taining Buddhism that accidentally linked to a personal blog on justice for the politically-sensitive death of his son.

On 19 April 2019, three petitioners from Yunxi County, Hubei Province were beaten up by private security personnel (who were reportedly paid by officials from the Letters and Calls Bureau in Yunxi County) at a deserted site dozens of miles away from Yunxi County. 2 female petitioners were reportedly covered in injuries. The petitioners were first taken away on 18 April 2019 by more than 20 private security personnel near the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng District (Beijing). After having their identity cards and mobile phones taken away, they were forcibly driven back to Yunxi County.

On 20 April 2019, an editor of the labour rights website 'New Generation' was placed under Residential Surveillance in a Designated Location by the police in Shenzhen. He was first arrested on 20 March 2019 and was being held in criminal detention for 'provoking troubles'.

On 22 April 2019, a human rights defender-cum-retired teacher from Shanghai was taken away near Panjiayuan Tower in Chaoyang district (Beijing) by undercover police officers from the Shanghai Liaison Office and Beijing police officers. He was sent to a Relief Service Centre 'black jail' near Beijing South Station in Fengtai and Dongcheng districts. He arrived in Beijing with several Shanghaiese petitioners, but was caught on his way to purchase cigarettes near his hotel accommodation. He was detained as of 24 April.

On 22 April 2019, seven petitioners were intercepted by police officers who broke into their accommodation in Fangshan district (Beijing). They were transferred to the Shanghai Liaison Office, then sent to a Relief Service Centre 'black jail' near Beijing South Station in Fengtai and Dongcheng districts. They were escorted back to Shanghai sometime in between 22-24 April.

On 22 April 2019, a pro-democracy activist was forced to go on ''mandatory holiday'' from Beijing to Jiangsu and was only allowed to return to Beijing on or after 29 April when the Belt and Road Forum had concluded.

On 22 April 2019, a female Liaoning human rights defender was detained by public security officers at a hotel in Shenyang (Liaoning), following a series of investigations for a case of 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble.' She had first been released on 17 Apr after a month-long detention, then immediately brought to Beijing for further identification at the crime scene. After the investigation team escorted her back to Shenyang on 22 Apr, she was detained at the hotel for the night before being allowed to return home on 23 Apr. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

SOURCE: RTHK; CRLW; Radio Free Asia; DW
NOTES: On 23 April 2019, female journalist and political dissident was 'taken on mandatory vacation' by national security officers from her apartment in Beijing, and could not reveal her location. It was last reported that morning that she received formal documents signifying the end of her house arrest. She had been sentenced in April 2015, accused of leaking state secrets to foreign media. She served her sentence in jail, then at home when released on medical parole.

On 23 April 2019, a female petitioner was kidnapped by a group of unidentified people outside the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development in Haidian District of Beijing after she submitted a petition. She was held incommunicado as of reported on 29 April 2019. It was part of a campaign by the local police to silence dissent before and during the second Belt and Road Forum on International Cooperation which held in Beijing on April 25-27.

On 24 April 2019, a Sichuan pro-democracy activist was taken away by police from his workplace in Chengdu, Sichuan province and had been held incommunicado since then. He was still out of reach at the time of reporting on 8 May 2019.

On 24 April 2019, a Shanghai human rights defender was taken away by the government officials of the Shanghai Municipal People's Government Beijing Office in a railway station in Shanghai, and consequently held incommunicado. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the second Belt and Road Forum on International Cooperation which held in Beijing on April 25-27.

On 24 April 2019, two human rights defenders, a mother and her daughter, were taken away by government officials at the Chongqing Jiangbei International Airport in Yubei city (Chongqing) before they boarded their flight to Beijing, where they planned to petitioned. One of them was beaten while being taken away and also had her mobile phone confiscated. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders][women targeted: girls]

On 25 April 2019, a Shanghai human rights activist, along with his wife and his friend, were dragged into a car by police and government officials near the Beijing South Railway Station (Fengtai District, Beijing) and were subsequently detained in the Shanghai Municipal People's Government Beijing Office. The activist's wife and the friend were released in Beijing the next day morning, whereas the activist was sent back to his home in Shanghai in the evening.

On 25 April 2019, a Shanghaiese rights defender-cum-forced evictee and his wife were taken from Beijing South Station in Fengtai district (Beijing) by police forces and government officials from Hongkou district of Shanghai. Albeit recovering from a stroke and physical disabilities, the rights defender was detained at the Shanghai Liaison Office, while his wife was escorted back to their hometown. The couple was in Beijing for a medical visit.

On 25 April 2019, a Shanghai human rights defender was taken away by the Fengxian government officials when she was petitioning in front of Beijing Municipal High People's Court (Chaoyang district, Beijing). She was forced to return to Shanghai was subsequently detained by authorities in a compound in Fengxian District, Shanghai for 5 days. On 29 April 2019, she was transferred to a hotel, before being released on 30 April 2019. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the second Belt and Road Forum on International Cooperation which held in Beijing on April 25-27. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 26 April 2019, an activist was called in to the station by Zhuzhou City (Hunan) police before being brought to have drinks at a restaurant nearby. Around midnight, two police officers took him to a nearby hotel, where he was held incommunicado until the following evening. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before nad during the Golden Week.

On 26 April 2019, a Shanghai human rights defender who had been detained with her husband at the Shanghai Municipal People's Government Beijing Office the night before was taken by government officials to the Beijing South Railway Station (Fengtai District, Beijing) and forced to return to Shanghai. When she resisted boarding the train, she was beaten by Shanghai officials. She was then detained in a black jail housed in a hotel in Hongkou District, Shanghai and released on 30 April 2019. She was diagnosed with a brain concussion after being released. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the second Belt and Road Forum on International Cooperation which held in Beijing on April 25-27. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 26 April 2019, a Shanghai human rights defender was taken away by the government officials in Beijing. She was detained in a black jail in Songjiang District, Shanghai before being released on 30 April 2019. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the second Belt and Road Forum on International Cooperation which held in Beijing on April 25-27. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 26 April 2019, 3 female petitioners from Caidian District of Wuhan City were kidnapped by government officers of the Wuhan City People's Government Beijing Office outside the Ministry of Agriculture in Chaoyang District of Beijing after they submitted petitions. They were sent back to Wuhan by cars and held incommunicado. It was part of a campaign by the local police to silence dissent before and during the second Belt and Road Forum on International Cooperation which held in Beijing on April 25-27.

On 26 April 2019, a Quanzhou petitioner was arrested and sent to a black jail by the police in Xicheng District of Beijing. On the next day, he was transferred to Quanzhou police station by the police and the Gekeng township deputy mayor and detained in the police station after that. He was detained incommunicado between 27 April to 1 May, after which he was still detained, but at least the police confirmed and informed his family about the detention.

On 27 April 2019, a female petitioner-cum-rights defender from Huishan district, Wuxi was transferred by Wuxi government officials to the first floor of Jinghua Hotel from Fuyou Street police station in Xicheng district (Beijing), and escorted back to Wuxi that evening by a policemen, a government official and a government-hired security guard. Her mailing documents were stolen when she arrived in Beijing on 26 Apr with letters and complaints to send to central authorities. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 29 April 2019, a rights activist was taken away by authorities from the Lingyan Shan hillside cemetery in Wuzhong District (Suzhou, Jiangsu) after he tried to visit the grave of an executed political dissident. He was incommunicado thereafter and is believed to be detained in the Xukou Police Station.

On 30 April 2019, a man who had a disability in one of his legs died after being punched by a city administrator in Shangjie District, Zhengzhou City. The man resisted when the city administrators tried to stop him from setting up his fortune telling stall, when he fell to the ground when one of the administrators punched him.

On 30 April 2019, two petitioners were transferred by a triad leader, employed by the government, from a black jail in Chongming Island, Shanghai to an unknown place. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to silence dissent before and during the second Belt and Road Forum on International Cooperation which held in Beijing on April 25-27.

Around 1 May 2019 (between 28 Apr - 4 May), more than 10 leftist students from Peking University were arrested by the police from the Yanyuan Police Station and the university security guards near Peking University in the Haidian District of Beijing across several days as of 4 May 2019. Students were held incommunicado after that, and suspected to be under house arrest. The arrests were made in relation to the approaching 100th anniversary of the May Fourth Movement, and the students were monitored and followed while conducting and planning a factory visit around the Labour Day and Youth Day in the first week of May.

As reported on 2 May 2019, three petitioners were forcibly taken away by Zhanqian township officials and police forces from a hotel in Wuchang district, Wuhan after visiting the State Bureau for Letters and Calls. They were then detained incommunicado in the Zhouji Residential District Police Station (Qianjiang, Hubei) for a few days. During the detention, one petitioner was beaten twice by the government officials and had to be hospitalised due to severe injuries.

On 6 May 2019, the 86-year-old mother of a dissident, who had been under house arrest for 5 months, was attacked by a National Security Force officer in Wuhou (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province) on their way home from a local hospital. The mother was repeatedly pushed and had her thumb sprained by the officer when they were quarrelling. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 7 May 2019, the police forbade a female human rights defender from leaving the police station in Yan Village (Fangshan District, Beijing City) after she assisted a case on the ground that she was on a monitoring list. She was consequently detained in a black jail for 5 hours before sending back to her home town in Heilongjiang by some government personnel. She was released on the next day. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 7 May 2019, six rights activists from Xinwu district, Wuxi were beaten in the car by liaison office-hired triad members in Fengtai district (Beijing) (coded as Beijing-Fengtai) after they were taken away. They were then escorted from Majialou ''black jail'' back to Wuxi. They were held for over 30 hours in the basement of Meicun Police Station without any of their belongings, five of whom were held in ''unofficial criminal detention with no legal paperwork'' for 30 more days.

On 8 May 2019, a dozen police officers arrested a representative of a non-profit labour group at his office in the Haidian District in Beijing. The police also arrested his wife and other staff, but they were released afterwards. The man was held incommunicado.

Around 8 May 2019 (in the week before 13 May 2019), a total number of 137 Uygurs (95 males, 42 females) were arrested by the police around Hotan (Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region) as they were accused of having resistance against the government's stability maintenance policy. 30 people were detained in the Hotan police station because they practised fasting during Ramadan. The rest of the group were sent to re-education camps.

Around 8 May 2019 (during the week of 6 May 2019), 137 Uyghur people were arrested in Hotan, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, by Chinese police to prevent them from fasting during Ramadan. 30 of them were charged with 'illegal participation in religious activities' and detained in police stations. The rest of them were sent to concentration camp for re-education.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Muslim Group (China); Women (China); Kazakh Ethnic Group (China)
NOTES: Around 9 May 2019 (from the start of Ramadan on 5 May to 13 May 2019), during the month of Ramadan, more than 500 Kazakh female factory workers, aged between 16 and 25, in Ili Kazak Autonomous were forcibly sent on a train to an unknown place by the police and have been missing since. At the same time, more than 300 men were transferred from re-education camps to reconstructed factories to carry out foced labour and attend 'political education' classes.

On 12 May 2019, more than 100 bereaved parents who lost their children in the 2008 earthquake were beaten up by 200 police and government officers at the site of a collapsed high-school in Dujiangyan City (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province). The parents were attacked when they were hanging banners and placards for a quake memorial for victims. Several injured parents were sent to the hospital.

On 12 May 2019, a petitioner from Hongkou district, Shanghai was intercepted by police and some unidentified security personnel at Hongkou Railway Station in Hongkou district (Shanghai), during which he was violently beaten up. His face was reportedly covered in blood. He had a concussion and was sent to hospital for immediate treatment. He was later sent to a black jail. This incident is allegedly related to the Conference on Dialogue of Asian Civilizations that took place on 15 May.

On 13 May 2019, a human rights defender who was going to attend an open court hearing concerning another human rights defender was beaten by the police in front of the Suzhou Intermediate People's Court in Gusu District (Suzhou City, Jiangsu Province). He was hit in his left eye and was consequently detained in a police station.

On 13 May 2019, a Hubei human rights defender was kidnapped by 5 masked men during lunch with a friend in Fangshan District of Beijing City. As of the reporting on 15 May, he still had not been heard from and could not be contacted. It was reported that he had been under surveillance and demanded to leave the city by the Beijing police recently.

On 15 May 2019, two Shanghai petitioners, including a retired local government official, were intercepted by police at the Ministry of Public Security in Dongcheng district (Beijing) and taken to a detention centre. The retired official was locked up in a farmhouse in Pudong (Shanghai) until at least 22 May. It was reported that 4 other petitioners were also detained in the same farmhouse starting from 16 May 2019, though the location of where they were first taken away from was not reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Kazakh Ethnic Group (China); Labour Group (China); Women (China)
NOTES: In May 2019, more than 500 Kazakh women from a local factory were secretly transferred by Chinese police from Ili Kazak Autonomous (Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region) to an unknown place during Ramadan.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Tibetan Ethnic Group (China); Buddhist Group (China); Women (China)
NOTES: Around 16 May 2019 (month of), more than 70 Tibetan Buddhist nuns were expelled from a temple in Acha township, Baiyu County, Garze by the authorities and forced to return to their hometown in Jomda County (Qamdo, Tibet). Upon returning to their hometown, they were immediately detained by the police in a detention centre and sent for political re-education.

On 16 May 2019, a dissident was arrested and tortured by the police in Hefei City, Anhui Province during a 24-hour custodial interrogation. He suffered from hunger, fatigue, sleep deprivation, and being denied access to the toilet. He was interrogated about his involvement in the commemoration of the 30th anniversary of Tiananmen Square protests and his interviews by foreign reporters.

Around 16 May 2019 (month of), a former female employee with the Home Affairs Bureau's Child Welfare Department was intercepted and beaten by stability maintenance officers at Xiangyang train station in Fancheng District (Xiangyang, Hubei) to prevent her from petitioning in Beijing. Prior to this, she was targeted and assaulted at least once due to disputes at her former government job, as well as forcibly admitted to a psychiatric ward.

On 17 May 2019, a female human rights defender from Pingnan County of Fujian Province was arrested and held incommunicado by Beijing police in the Beijing Municipality. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 17 May 2019, a female human rights defender was incommunicado after being kidnapped by the officers of Shanghai's Letters and Calls Bureau in Hongqiao railway station in Minhang District of Shanghai City. Her friend reported that she was likely to be detained in a 'black jail' in Chongming Island of Shanghai, where she had been detained several times before. She had petitioned for many years over the demolition of her husband's house by the government. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 17 May 2019, the chief official of an eviction operation and five of his subordinates cut the power cords to a forced evictee's house in Qujiang new district (Xi'an, Shaanxi) (coded at Xi'an City) and hit him in the face and body with twisted steel rods and picks. The evictee had to be hospitalised with concussion, soft tissue damage and broken bones. Eviction personnel on the scene claimed that perpetrators were not related to them.

On 19 May 2019, a pastor was beaten up at Xigu house church in Hongqiao District (Tianjin) when preventing the demolition of church properties by local police. He was sent to hospital. The cameras of some believers were also confiscated.

On 20 May 2019, a female petitioner who lost her home to forced demolition, had her mother taken away by the police and her son missing, was kidnapped by 5-6 unidentified persons in Rongchang District in Chongqing Municipality. Her kidnappers worked for the government courts, and stated that they brought her in for a discussion with the office in charge of forced demolitions. She was held incommunicado and detained in a windowless room at a legal court. In a state of 'deep desperation', she attempted to commit suicide and needed to be sent to the hospital. She was transferred from ICU to a regular ward after 3 days.

On 21 May 2019, a female human rights defender was taken on 'mandatory vacation' by the authorities in Foshan City of Guangdong Province, to prevent her from having a reunion with another human rights defender who would be released from the prison on 24 May 2019. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 21 May 2019, an activist in Zhuzhou City, Hunan Province was 'taken on mandatory vacation' by the police and the National Security Brigade for more than half a month. He was not allowed to use his phone during the journey. It was part of a national campaign by the authorities to suppress dissidents ahead of the 30th anniversary of Tiananmen Square protests.
