On 22 May 2019, the chief official of an eviction operation and more than 20 hired private security guards cut the power cords to a forced evictee's house in Qujiang new district (Xi'an, Shaanxi) (coded at Xi'an City), and beat him with picks and wires for 30-40 minutes. The evictee was severely injured, and was transferred to three different hospitals for treatment of concussion, soft tissue damage and broken bones.

On 22 May 2019, a female petitioner from Rudong, Jiangsu was abducted by police from a hotel in Xicheng (Beijing) and put into a black jail in Majialou, Fengtai, Beijing. She was sent back to Rudong, Jiangsu the next day.
On 24 May 2019, a human rights defender was taken on 'mandatory vacation' by the authorities in Sihui (Zhaoqing City, Guangdong Province) right after he was released from the Sihui city prison.

On 27 May 2019, an activist in Zhuzhou City, Hunan Province was 'taken on mandatory vacation' by the police to Xiangxi Tujia and Miao Autonomous Prefecture (Hunan). It was reported that the act might be part of a national campaign by the authorities to silence dissent and religious individuals before the 30th anniversary of Tiananmen Square protests.

On 28 May 2019, six art workers went missing in Nanjing (Jiangsu Province) during their exhibition tour. One of them had his home raided by the police on 29 May. Police told his wife that he was in detention due to potential charge of the 'crime of picking quarrels and provoking troubles', but there was no official decision issued. No further report on what happened during the period when they were missing.

On 30 May 2019, a couple from the Church of Almighty God was arrested by the police in Xinmi City (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province). During the interrogation, the police repeatedly struck the face of the husband, kicked him in the lower back, clubbed his toes with an iron bar, and forced him to take off his clothes and kneel on an iron rod. He suffered two broken ribs on the left side. The police also stomped on his wife's toes, struck her face with a ruler, and handcuffed her behind her back with one arm twisted up over her shoulder and one arm twisted from below.

SOURCE: Xinjiang Victims Database; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 31 May 2019, the Beijing police entered the hotel room in Beijing where a Uyghur woman and her four children were staying, and forced them to return to their hometown Urumqi (Xinjiang). They disappeared incommunicado for 18 days until contact was reestablished with a witness in Urumqi, and refused to disclose any details about those 18 days. Her Uyghur husband was in exile in Belgium, so she was in Beijing at the end of May to apply for a visa to rejoin the family at the Belgium ambassy, which sparked a controversy as the Belgium ambassy allowed Chinese police onto ambassy grounds when they learnt of the Uyghur family's visit. On 18 Jun 2019, it was learnt that the woman was coerced into signing a crime confession, and received daily visits and interrogations at her Urumqi home from the police. As of Sep 2019, the police and neighbourhood administration also drilled a hole into her apartment to facilitate surveillance.

As reported on May 31, 2019, a well-known Uyghur scholar involved in studying indigenous people's rights was reportedly killed in custody as a result of torture or ill treatment while in state custody.

On 1 June 2019, two petitioners from Xinjiang were abducted in Beijing by triad members hired by stability maintenance officials of Yingshan, Sichuan. They were naked while being taken away and sent back to Yingshan, Sichuan and were then detained in an iron cage there.

On 3 June 2019, a human rights activist and his fiancee were taken away by police from their home in Qiaodong (Xingtai, Hebei) and put in 'black jail' for a few days before sending to a detention centre and detained for 15 days. The reason for the detention was that the activist had posted a photo of him wearing a T-shirt written 'June Fourth' on Twitter earlier on the same day.

Around 4 June 2019 (month of), around the period close to the anniversary of the June 4th Tiananmen Square Protests, a former University of Guizhou professor was arrested and tortured by the police force of Huaxi District (Guiyang City, Guizhou Province) for 'picking a quarrel' in relation to his online political commentaries. During an 8-hour custodial interrogation, his wrists and legs were chained and he was placed in a tiger chair. He was also stripped naked and forced to provide blood and urine samples and fingerprints.

On 8 June 2019, a female petitioner from Xi'an, Shaanxi was beaten up by multiple local stability maintenance officials in Yanta (Xi'an, Shaanxi) as she was on her way to Shaanxi Guesthouse to petition to Central Government officials. She tried to call the police for three times but no one responded.

On 9 June 2019, a forced evictee was hit unconscious after being axed in the head and neck by unknown individuals as he stepped into his own house in Qujiang new district (Xi'an, Shaanxi) (coded at Xi'an City). He had been a target of at least two violent attacks by government officials and hired personnel prior to this, and was just released from the hospital on that day.

On 10 June 2019, a human rights defender was beaten while held in custody at a detention centre in Huai'an City (Jiangsu Province) . The person had been detained by police since 15 May 2019 and had yet to be released at the time of reporting on 19 October 2019.

On 10 June 2019, the lawyer of a human rights defender from Jiangsu was beaten by a group of assailants sent by the local authorities from Huai'an, after he visited the human rights defender in a detention centre in Huai'an, Jiangsu. He was injured in his arms and body. His phone was confiscated.

On 13 June 2019, an activist from Hunan was forced to go on ''mandatory holiday'' after he was released from a detention centre in Hunan province. His phone has been confiscated and his whereabout was unknown by the time of reporting on 17 June 2019. The activist has been prosecuted after expressing support for the Occupy Central Movement in Hong Kong years ago. It was believed that he was temporarily prevented from returning home in order to prevent him from supporting the ongoing anti-ELAB demonstration in Hong Kong.

In June 2019, two missionaries from Shandong Province were arrested in northern Xinjiang (coded as Urumqi), based on a tip-off to the police from a resident. When they were refused to sign a statement proclaiming that they would not engage in evangelism in the future, one of the missionaries were brutally beaten until he lost consciousness. They were ordered to return to Shandong the following day.

On 15 June 2019, a human rights activist was beaten up by government personnel stationing outside his apartment in Huiyang district (Huizhou, Guangdong) after he questioned them why they were preventing him from leaving his home. He was injured in the neck, face, head, chest, legs and arms. His camera was damaged. He was initially refused to be treated at a hospital but he received treatment after filing a complaint to the hospital's vice president. He was then taken to a police station.

On 19 June 2019, a democracy-cum-labour activist became incommunicado after the police took him away from his toy factory workplace in Heyuan prefecture (Guangdong). He was placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location for four months. He was later charged with 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble' (any in-between release was not reported), and officially arrested on 22 Nov for spreading democracy and freedom online. On 4 Aug 2020, his family learnt that he was imprisoned after a secret trial. It was revealed on 27 Oct 2020 that he received an 18-month prison sentence for crimes still unknown (location coded at Yuancheng, municipal seat of Heyuan).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 26 June 2019, a drunken man was tortured by three police officers at the North District Hospital (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong-North). He had been arrested for assaulting police officers during the night before, and then kicked one of the officers during the investigation at the hospital. They tied him to his bed, shone bright light into his eyes and pluck off his leg hairs. They also tried to suffocate him with fabrics, hit his lower body with their fists and baton, and shoved the baton into his mouth.

On 30 June 2019, a petitioner was forcibly taken away from her home in Zibo, Shandong by police officers who refused to provide a reason for her arrest. This is likely part of a nationwide crackdown on petitioners and human rights defenders in anticipation of the anniversary of the CPC Founding Day, which falls on 1 July.

On 2 July 2019, a human rights activist from Chongqing was arrested by the police in Xicheng, Beijing when she was on her way to petitioning in Beijing. She was beaten up during more than 20 hours of detention and was sent back to Chongqing. She arrived in Chongqing on 4 July. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

As reported on 2 July 2019, the Chinese police pepper sprayed 3 human rights lawyers in Luoshan county in Xinyang city, Henan and took them away when they were visiting another human rights lawyer who was prosecuted as part of the '709 crackdown' and recently got released.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 4 July 2019, around a dozen petitioners were violently arrested by armed police while paying visit to a severely disabled petitioner in Dadukou district in Chongqing. Police dragged one petitioner into a police car and injured his wrist in the process, and they also ordered the disabled petitioner to use a crutch to get in. All were detained and questioned, and one of them were released later in the day.

On 5 July 2019, a female human rights activist from Jiaozuo, Henan was forcibly abducted in Muxidi, Xicheng District (Beijing) by more than 10 unidentified people dressed in black. According to CRLW, she was later confirmed to be detained by the Jiaozuo local government for crime of picking quarrels and provoking troubles on 7 July 2019. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 6 July 2019, a lawyer from Shenzhen went to Liutang Police Station in Bao'an District (Shenzhen City, Guangdong Province) to petition on behalf of his wife, for the police to launch an investigation into a fraudulent multi-level marketing company and recover the assets lost by the family. When the police refused to file a case, the lawyer got into an altercation with the police. Three members of the counter-terrorism unit (under the People's Armed Police) pushed the lawyer to the ground and tied his hands against his back. He was later dragged outside the police station, and forced to stand in the courtyard under the blistering heat without water or food. The lawyer was detained for 27 hours and assaulted multiple times during this period. He visited a doctor after his detention where they found multiple injuries, two fractures and nerve damage in his wrist.

On 7 July 2019, a female petitioner was beaten up and taken away by members of an unknown triad groups in Qianjiang, Hubei. She was illegally detained in a house in Yonglin Village, where she was forced to kneel down for two hours, three times a day. Throughout her detention, she was repeatedly threatened and assaulted by the triad members, who forced her to sign an agreement to have her home demolished by the government. She was also forced to turn in her identity documents and receive 5000 RMB and a letter of guaranty. On 5 November 2019, she was released after she had signed the agreement.

On 10 July 2019, a resident was assaulted by the village committee head and a villager in Liulin village, Jinshui district (Zhengzhou, Henan). This was part of a months-long operation to cut off economic support and force villagers to evict, during which several hundred government-hired villagers gathered to block roads within and at the South Gate of the village. The government-hired individuals had set up checkpoints to intercept villagers and vehicles. There had reportedly been other assault cases between 4 and 15 July.

SOURCE: Weiquanwang; Epoch Times; Radio Free Asia; CRLW
NOTES: Around 10 July 2019 (month of), a rights defender-cum-lawyer died at an intensive care unit ward in Xiangcheng Hospital in his hometown (Zhangzhou, Fujian) (coded to Gulou). He was first transferred to the hospital on 26 April 2019, after completing his jail sentence in a prison hospital (Jianxin Hospital) in Fuzhou. During his time in the ICU, he was constantly guarded by the police and was not allowed to communicate with others. His family's requests for transferal for better treatment were denied, and visits were prohibited or occasionally granted and limited to 15 minutes a week. He was effectively detained until his death on 10 July 2019.

On 11 July 2019, more than 20 officers from the Lugang Township government in Changyuan county were dispatched to demolish the chicken farms of three chicken farming households in Qiaozhai Village, Changyuan (Xinxiang, Henan). Physical clashes broke out between the officers and the villagers who resisted the demolition. Police officers took away 7 villagers in total.

On 11 July 2019, a Uyghur man returned to Turpan City, Xinjiang (coded as Gaochang) and went incommunicado after letters that his family had received from relatives in camp were published online and spread through social networks. On 9 July, the police called him to ask whom he shared the letters with. Around 20 July, it was suspected that he was held at a detention centre in Turpan, however, this was not an official claim by authorities.

On 12 July 2019, more than 100 government officials and police besieged a house church located on West Third Ring Road in Zhengzhou City, Henan province and forcibly demolished the church. One believer who was resisting the officers were beaten up by more than 10 people. He was severely injured in his left arm and was sent to hospital immediately.

Around 16 July 2019 (month of), an Uyghur woman disappeared incommunicado in Xinjiang province (coded to Shuimogou), whereabouts and developments unknown as of the time of reporting on 29 Dec 2020. She and her two younger children were among the several Uyghurs deported back to China by the government of Turkey in Jun 2019, after the extradition treaty between Turkey and China was submitted to the Turkish parliament in Apr 2019.

On 17 July 2019, an online democracy activist was first held by around ten police officers at a police station near Guanyinqiao Guangchang (Plaza) in Jiangbei district (Chongqing), then forcibly transferred to the psychiatric ward at the Jiangbei Chinese Medicine Hospital. He was detained for publicizing an op-ed about the anti-ELAB demonstrations in Hong Kong at Guanyinqiao Guangchang. At the psychiatric ward, he was tied to his bed with ropes and forced to take hospital-administered pills that caused several side effects. After 37 days, he signed an agreement to stop all advocacy efforts, and was approved for release.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; Journalists (China)
SOURCE: Ming Pao; HKFP; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 21 July 2019, hundreds of masked assailants dressed in white assaulted residents, protesters, journalists and a lawmaker in Yuen Long, presumably targeting anti-government protesters returning from HK Island to New Territories. These attackers used bamboo sticks and other weapons to attack people in the station, causing 45 injuries, including one Legislative Councillor. Police officers were not visibly present when the attack occurred. In a widely circulated online video, pro-Beijing lawmaker was seen applauding to people dressed in white.

On 21 July 2019, the founder of Changsha Funeng, a public welfare organization focusing on disability rights, was taken away by Changsha Ministry of State Security officers in Shenzhen, Guangdong, and placed under residential surveillance in a designated location for 'inciting subversion of state power.' He was detained at Changsha City Kaifu District Detention Centre and held incommunicado with another two staff members of the same organization. On 20 July 2021, he was sentenced to five years in prison for 'inciting subversion of state power.'

On 22 July 2019, a female petitioner was taken by government employees to a black car upon her arrival at the Beijing West Station, Fengtai District (Beijing Municipality). She was then held shortly in a black jail in Gaojiachang, Beijing before being transferred to Chongqing on the same day. She was beaten several times on the way.

On 22 July 2019, two staff members of Changsha Funeng, a public welfare organization focusing on disability rights, disappeared in Changsha prefecture (Hunan) (coded to Yuelu) and were found to have been arrested on suspicion of 'subversion of state power.' They were detained at Changsha City Kaifu District Detention Centre and held incommunicado for 13 months until the Changsha Intermediate Court secretly tried them at the beginning of Sep 2020. On 20 July 2021, they were sentenced to two years and three years in prison for 'inciting subversion of state power.'

On 25 July 2019, a veteran from Nanjusi village of Chengguo town, Yantai prefecture was beaten in Beijing municipality by 10 police officers and five Chengguo town government officials. He was targeted for his petition efforts for forced eviction compensation owed by village authorities.

On 27 July 2019, a female petitioner was abducted and beaten up by thugs hired by village leaders in Xinxin village, Qianjiang. She was then transferred to Yonglin village, where she was subjected to violence, forced prolonged positioning, and 24 hours surveillance intending to force her to sign a house demolition agreement. She was detained for 101 days and finally set free on 5 November 2019. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 28 July 2019, a petitioner from Jiangbei, Chongqing was abducted by a a group of people led by the Civil Police at Beijing West Station, Fengtai District (Beijing Municipality). She was then choked by an unidentified group of people and her phone was taken away. She was then held in a black jail in Gaojiachang, Beijing for a few hours before being transferred to Chongqing on the same day.

On 29 July 2019, a suspect was tortured and killed by two police officers and two convicts at the Xinle Detention Centre in Xinle county (Shijiazhuang, Hebei). He was arrested for driving under influence on 26 Jul, then cuffed and tied to his bed on 28 Jul until the early morning of 29 Jul. For eight hours, they repeatedly tortured him with pepper spray, slaps on the face and body, and covering him with thick blankets under hot weather conditions. The victim died after displaying full-body seizures in the evening.

On 29 July 2019, the ex-vice chairman of Wuhan Workers' Autonomous Federation was discovered to be missing in Chenzhou, Hunan and has been incommunicado for at least 2 days since. A few days prior to his disappearance, he had shown his friends a photo of him with the ex-premier of the PRC Li Peng on his phone and it is suspected that his disappearance is linked to this.

On 29 July 2019, a retired professor and inventor was arrested and beaten up by police officers at Babaoshan Revolutionary Cemetery on Shijingshan Road, Shijingshan district (Beijing), where he shouted remarks during a memorial event for a former Premier of the PRC Li Peng, stating that he must be defeated.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Tibetan Review; Free Tibet
NOTES: On 1 August 2019, three Tibetan Bon monks were taken into custody in Ngawa county (also Ngaba, Aba) (Ngawa Tibetan and Qiang Autonomous, Sichuan). While two of them were released a few days after, one of the monks remained detained and held incommunicado. It was reported on 2 Dec 2020 that his now-shut down social media account and website about Tibet had drawn the attention of police for several years. The National Security Bureau officially notified his family on 23 Mar 2020 about the charges brought against him - inciting separatism. Local police verbally informed his family on 26 Mar 2021 that the victim had been held at a prison in Chengdu prefecture for four and a half years, and would be accepting visitors now.

On 2 August 2019, around noon, village officials leading dozens of black-clad men with shields restricted a villager's mobility at his house in Da Tong village of Yancun township in Fangshan District, Beijing, as a practice of forced evictions. In the evening, the black-clad men forced their way into the villager's home, confiscated his properties, and beat him, causing him to be seriously injured and needed to be admitted to a hospital.

On 5 August 2019, a group of men in white assaulted citizens in North Point in the Eastern district of Hong Kong, presumably targeting anti-government protesters. These attackers used large bamboo sticks to attack people.

On 7 August 2019, a female petitioner was transferred from the police station in Qingxi town of Shaoshan (Xiangtan, Hunan) to the psychiatric ward of Xiangtan No.5 Hospital, where she witnessed medicine 'arbitrarily administered' and inserted into her meals. She was taken away by the officials onto a taxi on 6 Aug, when town government officials promised to resolve the issues she was petitioning about and deceived her into meeting. They sent her to the Qingxi town police station the day after, and confiscated her luggage and identity documents. She was detained at the psychiatric ward until 26 October 2019, and claimed that she was forcibly administered ecstasy tablets during this period.

On 11 August 2019, a large group of people dressed in red clothes with the characters 'Fujian people' written on them gathered in North Point in the Eastern district of Hong Kong. It is suspected that they are an organised group. They ganged up with a middle aged man to attack a citizen wearing black clothes and many reporters. Police took some of the attackers into a police car. Number of arrests and injuries unknown.

On 11 August 2019, a house church in Tianhe District of Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province was raided by 30 police officers, after receiving reports that it was holding illegal meetings. Police officers fractured the hand of a member of the congregation fractured when they stormed in. Personal information of all members were taken down, before they were removed from the venue. Two church leaders were taken away to the police station for interrogation, and forced to sign statements declaring never to organize religious gatherings. It was reported that the pastors of the church were among the signatories of a declaration that denounced the Chinese government's persecution of Christians.

On 12 August 2019, an activist from Heyuan, Guangdong was taken away by the police from his home. Police did not specify the reason for the arrest when they were asked. His personal belongings such as phone, passport, bank cards and ID card were confiscated.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Xinjiang Victims Database
NOTES: Around 15 August 2019 (month of), a Kazakh man was coerced into sitting on an iron chair for 24 hours and tortured by the police in Emin county (Tarbagatay, Xinjiang) during a 24-hour detention. He would later flee China due to the repressions he faced in Xinjiang and news about his near-future imprisonment, illegally crossing into Kazakhstan on 6 Oct to seek political asylum.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; The Stand News
NOTES: Around 15 August 2019 (between 9 August and 24 August), a former employee of the British consulate in Hong Kong was tortured by Chinese state security police during a 15 days' detention in Shenzhen City (Guangdong Province) and forced to confess about the British involvement in the anti-ELAB movement in Hong Kong. The man was reportedly arrested from Hong Kong West Kowloon Highspeed Railway Station on 9 August 2019. Chinese government only confirmed his arrest on 21 August 2019. He reported that he was restrained in a 'tiger chair' during interrogation, deprived of sleep, forced to do the spread-eagled pose for hours, and hold his hands up to prevent blood from pumping up his arms during the detention which caused extreme pain. He was forced to confess to crimes of 'soliciting prostitutes' and treason before being released on 24 August 2019.

On 19 August 2019, on the first day of imprisonment, a prisoner was punched and kicked by a few prison officers at the Wuyishan prison in Shangpu village (Wuyishan, Nanping, Fujian) as a punishment for not being able to do squats. A prison officer then cuffed his hands behind his back and fired pepper spray at him. The prisoner was arrested after lighting firecrackers to celebrate the release of a prisoner in Fuzhou on 12 September 2018.

On 19 August 2019, a female rights defender-cum-petitioner from Fujian was forcibly admitted to Kangning Psychiatric Hospital in Luohu district (Shenzhen, Guangzhou) (coded as Shenzhen-Luohu), and was reportedly forcibly medicated during her stay. The victim was a retired migrant worker and was known to be staying in Shenzhen since Sep 2018. She visied the law courts and Human Resources and Social Security Bureau until she lost contact with her family on 19 Aug. She was released in early 2020. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 19 August 2019, a female Fujian petitioner went missing until she was found to have been detained by Shenzhen police at a mental hospital in Biling, Pingshan (Shenzhen, Guangdong) after a doctor called her parents on 18 October. She was forced to take medicine in the hospital. She was released home on 27 December 2019.

On 20 August 2019, at least 3 people (2 women and 1 man) were injured in a knife attack by an unidentified assailant at a Lennon Wall in Tseung Kwan O, Sai Kung District (New Territories, Hong Kong). It was reported that the assailant attacked the three people after hearing their political views.

On 20 August 2019, a Taiwanese voluntary consultant went missing after arriving in Shenzhen from Hong Kong. The Chinese government confirmed on 11 September that they had detained him under charges of endangering national security. He has been held incommunicado for more than 20 days since his detention.

Around 21 August 2019, a Uyghur Internment Camp detainee was reported to be beaten to death by a police officer in Shanshan (also known as Pichan) county (Turpan City, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region), although the authorities claimed that he died of a heart failure. His family were told by the authorities that he had suffered a myocardial infarction brought on by an undiagnosed heart condition at the camp.

On 21 August 2019, a petitioner from Jiangsu was kidnapped by an unidentified group of people right outside the National Letters and Calls Bureau in Xicheng, Beijing. She was first detained in a hotel before being transferred to a police station where she was locked up in a metal cage and provided with no food or water. Later the same day, she was secretly transferred to a hospital in her home town in Jiangyin, Jiangsu.

On 22 August 2019, a member of Esuweiji - a group of doxxing websites focused on President Xi, CCP high officials and their relatives - was beaten up following his arrest by police officials in Maoming prefecture (Guangdong) (coded to Maonan). On the same day, a coordinated arrest of all members of the websites was conducted across their respective regions in China. The arrests were reported to be in connection with the webmaster - who was also arrested - travelling to Hong Kong on 22 June to observe the anti-ELAB demonstrations.

On 26 August 2019, a petitioner from Wuxue, Hubei was taken away by local security officers outside the National Letters and Calls Bureau in Xicheng, Beijing. He was not able to be contacted thereafter and is suspected to have been kidnapped.

On 26 August 2019, an activist from Jiangbei, Chongqing was abducted by 6 to 7 people of unknown identity in Fengtai, Beijing with a black car. Upon arriving in Chongqing, she was sent to a 'black jail' in Geleshan and locked up for 45 days. She was released few days before 19 October 2019.

On 29 August 2019, a human rights lawyer was taken away by the police at Guangzhou South railway station in Panyu, Guangzhou, Guangdong province. The police said they were trying to prevent him from going abroad. He went missing for 10 days. On 8 September 2019, he returned home in Jingzhou.

On 29 August 2019, a human rights lawyer from Guangzhou who was just released from prison four months ago went missing after arriving at Guangzhou South railway station in Panyu, Guangzhou, Guangdong province. She has not been able to be contacted for at least 24 hours and is suspected to have been kidnapped. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 29 August 2019, a Hong Kong activist was attacked by four men of South Asian descent with metal rods and umbrellas in Tai Po while he was being interviewed by a reporter. This happened shortly after he was granted unconditional release by police following his arrest on 28 July for organising the 27 July Yuen Long demonstration. The activist was the person who initially applied for the letter of no objection for the Yuen Long demonstration on 27 July, but the march, which demanded that authorities launch an independent investigation into the Yuen Long attacks a week ago, was banned and a subsequent appeal was rejected.

On 29 August 2019, a Hong Kong activist affiliated with Civil Human Rights Front (CHRF) and his friend were attacked by two masked men wielding a baseball bat and knife in Jordan in Yau Tsim Mong district. His friend was injured and hospitalised.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: The Stand News; Ta Kung Pao
NOTES: On 30 August 2019, amidst the anti-extradition law protests, an off-duty police officer in charge of the armoury (arms inventory room) was chased and stabbed by three black-clad men across the street from Kwai Chung Police Station in Kwai Tsing district (Hong Kong). He suffered over 20 cuts and had four fingers severed.

Around 1 September 2019 (beginning of month), the vice chairman of political party Demosisto was beaten by three men outside his family home in Hong Kong after he helped to organise a school strike. Violence has reportedly been increasing on both sides of the ideological divide in Hong Kong after a few months of demonstrations, and victims often include rally organisers, opposition lawmakers, student leaders and people standing for upcoming polls.

On 1 September 2019, a female Christian petitioner went missing after she was last seen around the public toilets near her rental place in Beijing. It was believed she was sent back to her hometown Chongqing, although it was later reported that she remained missing at the time of reporting on 29 October 2019. Her friend also went missing and became incommunicado. The incident is allegedly related to the approaching Chinese National Day.

On 1 September 2019, a street vendor was beaten and choked to death by 7 to 8 urban management/'chengguan' officers in Liudongzhen, Yunyang, in Hebei province for not letting the chengguan officials take things from him. One of the vendor's relative tried to stop the officials from beating him but was unsuccessful.

Around 1 September 2019 (week of), police and security forces from Lhasa beat monks and villagers during a night raid in Dranak village, Tingri county (Xigaze, Tibet) (code as Shelkar) and the adjoining monastery of Tengdro. Police arrested about 20 people for exchanging messages with other Tibetans abroad, having contributing to the earthquake relief sent to Tibetans at the sister monastery in Nepal or having possessed photographs or literature related to the Dalai Lama.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Tibetan Ethnic Group (China); Buddhist Group (China); Prisoners (China)
NOTES: Around 1 September 2019 (beginning of month), a Tibetan monk from Tingri's Tengdro monastery was arrested and beaten up by police during interrogation in Lhasa city (Tibet) after the police found his cell phone. Suggested by the messages on his phone, police found that he had donated to Tibetans living in Nepal to recover from the April 2015 earthquake that caused widespread devastation across Nepal.

On 2 September 2019, a large group of police took away petitioners from around China who had queued up outside the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng, Beijing to petition. They petitioners were taken away in four full coaches and detained at the Majialou 'black jail' in Fengtai, Beijing until early the following day. Some of them were sent to other places after being released from Majialou. This was part of the crackdown on petitioners before the 70th anniversary of the establishment of the PRC in October.

On 3 September 2019, a petitioner from Henan was taken away by Beijing police while he was walking along the Fourth Ring Road in Beijing. He was then brought to the Yuquanying Police Station and has not been able to be contacted for at least 2 days since then. He was suspected to have been sent back to his hometown due to Beijing's crackdown on petitioners before the 70th anniversary of the establishment of the PRC in October.

On 3 September 2019, a human rights activist in Huishan District (Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province) was placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) by the local court on charge of the 'crime of picking quarrels and provoking troubles'. The charge was based on some twitter posts in relation to Xinjiang and the Tian'anmen event of 1989 among the others. The person was also a petitioner and was called into the police station on 2 September to 'discuss' the petition case. The RSDL decision on 3 September was not related with the petition.
On 5 September 2019, a petitioner from Wuhan, Hubei was abducted by 2 men dressed in black in Dongxihu (Wuhan, Hubei) and has been detained in a black jail since then.

On 9 September 2019, a dissident from Shanghai went missing after being detained by Shanghai police around Disney subway station in Pudong New Area (Shanghai) that afternoon. His whereabout has been unknown since then.

On 12 September 2019, a female petitioner was taken to a police office in Xicheng District (Beijing) by the police after she delivered her petition to the central government. Then, she was sent to be detained in Majialou 'black jail' in Beijing for an unreported amount of time before being transferred back to Shanghai, where she was subsequently detained for 15 days in prison.

On 12 September 2019, a female petitioner from Fancheng, Xiangyang and her son petitioned at the Letters and Visits Bureau in Xiangcheng District (Xiangyang, Hubei) demanding to bring her son to a doctor. The neighbourhood committee secretary, along with 6 other men stormed into the Bureau and beat them up. The petitioner called the police but when they arrived, they refused to help her after finding out that she came to petition. They were hospitalised.

On 12 September 2019, a female petitioner and her son were assaulted by two government officials and six thugs at the Xiangyang Letters And Calls Bureau in Xiangcheng District (Xiangyang City, Hubei Province). It was reported that the female petitioner tried reporting the case to the police, but did not receive any assistance, on the grounds that assault happened due to her petitioning activities.

On 12 September 2019, a female activist from Wuhan was beaten up and kidnapped in Donghu, Hongshan, Wuhan in Hubei province by a group of three thugs related to local stability maintenance force, who warned her a day before at her doorstep not to petition until the end of October. They promised her to give her 20,000 RMB if she did not go petitioning, but she rejected. She was locked up in Guandong police station and was allowed to go home on 15 September. She went to the hospital for a check-up.

On 14 September 2019, a prominent 'barefoot lawyer' (a self-taught legal activist) who worked to defend human rights went missing in Changyuan, Henan and has not been heard from for at least a week. It is suspected that he has been kidnapped. He had reportedly been monitored by Guangzhou police all the way from Guangzhou to Henan after he was released from prison lately.

On 14 September 2019, a human rights activist from Shenyang, Liaoning went missing shortly after he forwarded a message supporting a female petitioner who were forcibly taken away from her home in Beijing. He was reportedly taken away by stability maintenance officials in the district where he resided in Shenyang.

Around 15 September 2019 (month of), a couple who had been petitioning for 18 years was beaten up by the authorities while they were submitting their petition at the letters and calls bureau in Qionglai City (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province). They were then detained at a local police station for 7 days for 'disrupting work unit order'.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Xinjiang Victims Database
NOTES: Around 15 September 2019 (month of), a Kazakh man and his business partner were beaten up by the police in Emin county (Tarbagatay, Xinjiang) during a 24-hour detention. The police did not ask them any questions. He would later flee China due to the repressions he faced in Xinjiang and news about his near-future imprisonment, illegally crossing into Kazakhstan on 6 Oct to seek political asylum.

Around 15 September 2019 (month of), a female petitioner from Zhou village, Huancheng town (Weishan, Jining, Shandong) was abducted from her home by people employed by the government and held in a nursing house in Huancheng town (Weishan county, Jining City, Shandong Province). She was still guarded by 8 people in the nursing house by the time of report on 14 November 2019. This is the third time she's been abducted since 12 February 2019 due to the upcoming 70th anniversary of Chinese National Day.

On 16 September 2019, a human rights defender/petitioner from Shenyang went missing in Beijing when he was on his way to meet a friend at Xihongmen station. He was stopped by local stability maintenance officials and ordered to go back to Shenyang, after that he could no longer be contacted on phone.

Around 16 September 2019, a human rights activist was transferred from a detention centre in Peng'an County (Nanchong City, Sichuan Province) and detained at a psychiatric hospital for two months. During the detention, he was forcibly administered drugs every day, which he claimed would make him drowsy and nauseous. The activist had first been taken away by three police officers from Beijing on 12 August 2019, before he was repatriated to Nanchong City where he was first administratively detained for 15 days, before being transferred to criminal detention for a further 20 days. He suspected that he was detained for an extended period as the authorities were concerned that he would 'cause trouble' during the National Day Parade and the 2019 Military World Games held in October.

On 17 September 2019, two female petitioners from Fuqing, Fujian province went missing in Xicheng, Beijing after reporting problems of land use to the central government in the morning. They held incommunicado thereafter and are suspected to have been kidnapped.

On 18 September 2019, a veteran was transferred from a detention centre in Nanchong City (Sichuan) [coded to Shunqing] at the end of his criminal detention and sent to Nanchong No. 2 Mental Hospital. He remained detained at the hospital until 28 October 2019. At the hospital, he was repeatedly forced to take medicine for 'treatment' purposes. He was first arrested by the police in Beijing on 12 August 2019 because of his previous petitioning activities to demand government compensation for his injuries during his military service.

On 18 September 2019, more than 10 people who self-claimed to be police broke into the home of a female CCP distinguished party member in Xihongmenzhen, Daxing, Beijing and took her away in a police car. She was incommunicado since then. Her phone was confisticated. [women targeted: political party supporters]

On 18 September 2019, a female petitioner from Hubei was abducted by government officials in Chenzhou, Hunan and admitted to a mental hospital. The stability maintenance unit arranged 12 officials to keep an eye on her and to stop her from going out and meeting her family. The reason for locking her up was to prevent her from petitioning in Beijing during the National Day.

Around 18 September 2019 (more than a week before 29 September 2019), a human rights defender was taken from Beijing to Zhongshan (Guangdong province) on a 'forced vacation' due to the stability maintaince in Beijing before the National Day on 1 October.

On 19 September 2019, a woman was beaten downstairs of her home in Dongxihu District (Wuhan City, Hubei Province) by unknown people and then kidnapped for 2 days. She later reported to the police. But the police refused to take the case because the beating was 'a government act'. She later visited the doctor, where they found five fractured ribs. No further report on the beating and kidnapping incident.

On 19 September 2019, a Tibetan monk in the Ngaba county (also known as Aba county, Sichuan Province) was taken into custody by Chinese authorities and has been held incommunicado for at least 2 weeks. The arrest was likely related to his pro-Tibetan language post on wechat. His whereabout and the official reason for the arrest was not known.

On 19 September 2019, a dissident and human rights activist from Sichuan was taken away by the police in Sichuan province and was held incommunicado. The reason for the arrest was unclear, but it was suspected that it had to do with his plan to open an animal farm in Zhongnanhai.

SOURCE: Voice of Tibet; Free Tibet; Tibet.net; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 20 September 2019, six Tibetan residents of Nagqu prefecture (Tibet) (coded to Nagqu Town) were detained for refusing to participate in celebrations of the 70th anniversary of the founding of the PRC, and at least three were sent to attend a political reeducation class. Two of them were released at some point, but the whereabouts of one of them - from Geso village in Tsalhi (Daqian) township - remained unknown for a long time. It was finally reported in May 2021 that he had died in 2019 after alleged torture by authorities, who stated the victim committed suicide due to financial debt. His family and fellow villagers refuted the claim by stating the victim 'didn't own money to anyone' and 'lived responsibly at home.'

On 21 September 2019, a Christian couple from Beijing were forced to go on ''mandatory holiday'' to Henan. The incident was allegedly related to heightened security measures ahead of the Chinese National Day.

On 22 September 2019, a petitioner was forcibly detained for 24 hours by the local police in Yubei District, Chongqing. She had planned to travel to Beijing to appeal for her petition against the illegal requisition of her land and demolition of her house by the government. During her detention, she sustained injuries to her ankles after being dragged by the handcuffs and shackles.

On 23 September 2019, an activist from Changsha, Hunan went missing in Changsha. He reported the day before that some National Security Force officials wanted to meet him due to the incident in which another activist from Hunan was found dead in a detention centre earlier. He then became unreachable on phone. He has been missing for four days by the time of reporting.

On 24 September 2019, a leader of an evangelical church in Qiupo village, Tanghe county, Nanyang City (Henan Province) was taken away by the police and has not been heard from for at least a week thereafter. He had been ordered earlier by the government to demolish the church built on the commune land but he refused to do so. [location coded at Wolong]

On 24 September 2019, a female citizen from Nanjing was knocked unconscious by government officials in Xuanwu, Nanjing and sent to a 'black jail' where she was deprived of any rights, including the right to watch TV, read, write, etc. She was released on 6 October 2019. Her home had been destroyed by the government in 2014 and she hass been seeking legal redress for this matter since.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong)
NOTES: On 24 September 2019, a Democratic Party legislative councillor was attacked near the Wetland Park in Tin Shui Wan in Yuen Long, Hong Kong by a group of three masked attackers. A fourth person was filming the attack. The councillor was injured in his cervical vertebrae, arms and legs and was hospitalised. The Police said they would follow up seriously.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 27 September 2019, a female protester was allegedly raped by police officers when she was detained in Tseun Wan Police Station. As reported on 16 January 2020, she later filed a report to the Hong Kong Police Force about the incident. It was reported that she subsequently became pregnant and had to undergo an abortion. The Commissioner of the HKPF has denied the allegations.

On 27 September 2019, four triad members employed by a communal office beat two petitioners at Hushan village in Yiwu City (Jinhua City, Zhejiang Province) because of their previous petitions against the Yiwu City government. The two petitioners were sent to the hospital later. They reported the incident to the police but the police refused to register the case without giving any reason.

On 27 September 2019, a female Falun Gong member from Mengzi county (Honghe, Yunnan) was kidnapped by police officers while she was on her way back from Kunming prefecture (Yunnan) to Mengzi, after visiting a fellow Falun Gong member in the prefecture. It was reportedly part of a stability maintenance effort ahead of the military parade celebrating the 70th anniversary of the founding of China. She was later arrested by the authorities of Jianshui County on 2 November 2019, but her circumstances between 27 September and 2 November were not reported. She had been a repeated target of imprisonment, torture and re-education camps since 2001.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 29 September 2019, around 10 policemen used force against a man near Cameron Road (Tsim Sha Tsui, Yau Tsim Mong, Kowloon City) because he insulted them while they were checking his ID.

On 29 September 2019, a female petitioner from Yiwu (Jinhua, Zhejiang) called the police after her motorbike was destroyed. Police came and did not arrest any of the personnel who were guarding the female petitioner. Rather, police arrested the petitioner and beat her up somewhere near the police station. She was then detained for 10 days.

On 30 September 2019, the eve of China's National Day, a female petitioner was arrested in Beijing by private security personnel employed by the authorities of her home province, Fujian. She was brought back to Fujian and detained in a farm in Pingnan county until 4 October when she was released. There was no charge brought against her.

Around 30 September 2019 (between 16 September and 17 October 2019), a female human rights defender in Nanchong City (Sichuan Province) was detained by police and beaten while in custody due to her Twitter post supporting the anti-ELAB demonstrations in Hong Kong. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), the Bishop of Wenzhou Diocese in Wenzhou City (Zhejiang Province) was taken away by national security personnel sent by the Religious Affairs Bureau to be indoctrinated because of the upcoming 10th anniversary of the death of the former Bishop of Wenzhou on 4 October. Both of the bishops had been punished by the authorities because they refused to join the state-controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Church. He was allowed to go home on 8 October.

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), a petitioner from Rugao, Jiangxi was abducted by government personnel in Beijing and sent back to Rugao, Jiangxi. He was beaten up during his way back to Jiangxi.

On 1 October 2019, an activist from Shaanxi was arrested by state security force in Liwan District (Guangzhou, Guangdong) and was forced to fly back to Xi'an, Shaanxi on the same day. He was escorted by a few officers who also stayed with him in a hotel for one night before sending him back to his hometown Yan'an the next day and handing him over to the local police.

Shortly before 1 October 2019, a citizen from Wuyi county (Jinhua City, Zhejiang Province) was abducted from Beijing (no specific location in Beijing reported) because of his petition activities. He was taken by some gangsters hired by the county government of Wuyi and kept in police detention there for at least a week.

On 1 October 2019, a Tiananmen Incident activist from Shandong being held in a detention centre in Liancheng County (Longyan, Fujian) was slapped by a police officer after making a comment about Xi Jinping while being forced to watch a live broadcast of the military parade. He had been detained since 25 Sep 2019 for 'spreading rumours'.

Around 1 October 2019 (during the 13 days from 24 September 2019), a citizen in Nanjing was held in the black jail for 13 days and severely beaten by government employees of the Xuanwu District (Nanjing, Jiangsu Province). She was knocked unconscious and taken to the 'black jail' on 24 Sep because of her previous pleading activities to get government compensations for her destroyed houses. She was eventually dropped on the side of a road near her home because the government staff feared that she might die from injuries.

On 1 October 2019, a female petitioner was arrested by the police from Ciqikou in Dongcheng District (Beijing) when she was watching the National Day Parade together with several other petitioners. She was sent back to Shanghai on the same day and held in detention for a month before she was released. During this time, unlike other petitioners who were quickly charged with the 'crime of picking quarrels and provoking troubles', her parents were told by the authorities that she was 'on holiday' in a hotel.

On 4 October 2019, a female petitioner from Xi'an, Shaanxi who went to appeal in Beijing was arrested in Haizijiao Village in Daxing district (Beijing) by governmental personnel from Shaanxi and hired thugs. She was then brought back to Shaanxi by car. The next day, she was detained in a hotel next to the Bianfang Elementary School in Weicheng District, Xianyang City until 11 October 2019. She was not allowed to have contact with anyone during her detention.

On 8 October 2019, a Tibetan man was taken by the police from his residence in Geso Tsalhi village, Nagqu Town (Nagqu, Tibet) on unknown charges. He had since been held incommunicado. He was taken into custody after being told by the police not to leave the area. Some sources stated that he was likely to be arrested for 'leaking state secrets'. There had been no news about his whereabouts and the reason for his arrest by the time of reporting on 15 November 2019. The man had been outspoken on issues concerning the reunion of Tibetan people inside Tibet and in exile, and expressed hope for Dalai Lama's return to Tibet.

On 8 October 2019, a female candidate who was running for District Council in the Yuet Wah constituency in Kwun Tong District (New Territories, Hong Kong) was attacked in the back of her head with an unknown object while she was waiting to cross the road. She did not suffer major injuries from this attack. She had been harassed via text message and on Facebook by unknown people aiming to deter her from campaigning. [women targeted: candidates for office]

On 8 October 2019, a petitioner was about to be released from the Rugao police detention centre (Nantong city, Jiangsu Province). Before he could walk out of the detention centre, he was immediately taken by several unknown people to a car and driven away. There was no further news about his whereabouts.

On 11 October 2019, a female rights-defenders-cum-forced evictees from Pingnan county, Fujian, and her father were transferred by Beijing police in Beijing municipality to the hands of Pingnan government officers after they reported a case to the police. The officers beat the father, causing him to sustain six rib fractures during the ride back to Pingnan (Ningde City, Fujian Province). The daughter was charged with 'using other people's ID cards' and placed in administrative detention upon arrival. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 12 October 2019, a female candidate who was running for District Council was attacked at her booth in the City Garden constituency of North Point, Eastern District (Hong Kong), by a middle-aged man. The man tore up her election leaflet in front of her, and punched her in the head twice. She was then taken to Ruttonjee Hospital after feeling dizzy and nauseous. [women targeted: candidates for office]
On 13 October 2019, two Christians were beaten up by one police officer in a hotel in Liqiaozhen, Shunyi, Beijing. The reason for the attack was unknown.

On 14 October 2019, a female petitioner was kidnapped by government interceptors near the National Bureau of Letters and Visits in Xicheng District (Beijing Municipality) and sent back to her home town in Hubei Province. She was beaten on the way.

On 14 October 2019, a female petitioner was taken away by local authorities around the State Bureau of Letters and Calls in Dongcheng, Beijing and forcibly sent back to her hometown in Ezhou, Hubei province. Authorities violently beat her up during the journey. Back in Ezhou, she continued to be controlled by the authorities and was not allowed to seek treatment for her injuries. Officers threatened to send her to a mental hospital if she continued to cause trouble.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Xinjiang Victims Database
NOTES: Around 15 October 2019 (month of), a Kazakh woman from Ulanbuqa village, Maralsu township of Emini county (Tarbagatay, Xinjiang) was questioned and beaten (most likely by authorities) after her husband's escape into Kazakhstan on 6 Oct, reportedly fainting from the assault. Her husband would succeed in obtaining political asylum in Kazakhstan.

On 17 October 2019, a journalist was arrested by the Guangzhou Police for reporting on the anti-extradition protests in Hong Kong. She was detained for over 40 days before being placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location.

SOURCE: Ming Pao; DW; HKFP; Radio Free Asia; RTHK; Weiquanwang
NOTES: On 17 October 2019, a female journalist went missing after being called to the Baiyun District (Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province). She was confirmed to be arrested by the police after a week because of her reporting on the recent demonstrations in Hong Kong.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 17 October 2019, believers of a Three-Self Church in Yuanjiang (Yiyang, Hunan Province) were hit indiscriminately by armed police officers, when 20 congregation members and 70 believers attempted to block the removal of a church signboard. Three elderly protesters reported injuries to their ribs, waist and head, and more than 20 others suffered minor injuries. Four protesters were violently dragged into a vehicle then detained.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 17 October 2019, several elderly believers were assaulted and injured by armed police officers during a government-led signboard removal operation at a Three-Self Church in Wudao community, Qionghu sub-district of Yuanjiang county (Yiyang, Hunan). The operation was one of seven targeting True Jesus Churches within the county that day.

On 19 October 2019, a Seventh-day Adventist house church in Neijiang City, Sichuan Province was raided by more than 200 people (including government officials and police officers). They ordered to have the electricity cut off, and took some valuables from the church. Two employees of the church were beaten up by four police officers. The two employees, the pastor and a preacher were taken to a detention house for interrogation.

On 19 October 2019, a man handing out flyers near the Lennon Wall in Tai Po District (Hong Kong) was attacked by a black-clad assailant. According to accounts from an eyewitness, the assailant charged at the victim and slashed him in the neck and stabbed him in the stomach. The assailant then walked to a bus terminal nearby where he shouted 'Hong Kong is a part of China, and I will go against whoever disrupts Hong Kong'.

Around 20 October 2019 (between 13 - 28 Oct), a petitioner was abducted by police from Zhushan County and some gangsters at Wuhan City Train Station (Hubei Province) and sent to the nursing home in Majiadu Town (Zhushan County, Shiyan City, Hubei Province) at night. During his 15-day detention, petitioner was beaten several times by the director of the nursing home together with the leader of a local triad and others on orders of the town government. The petition went on hunger strike during his detention in protest. After his family shared the pictures online which showed that the police had followed him on the train before he was abducted, he was treated medically and released on 28 October 2019.

On 23 October 2019, a petitioner from Dengfan village, Hubei, was intercepted in Beijing Municipality by police officers from Fangshan District Police Station and escorted back to Dawu county, Hubei, where he was detained at a farmhouse for 232 days. He escaped successfully on 6 June 2020.

On 25 October 2019, a Christian activist who was being held in criminal detention in Zhenjiang City (Jiangsu) for 'provoking troubles' was placed under Residential Surveillance in a Designated Location. He was first arrested in Beijing on 12 Sep 2019 and sent back to Zhenjiang, on 26 Sep.

Around 25 October 2019 (between 23 and 26 Oct), a petitioner being held at the Minhou detention centre in Fuzhou City (Fujian Province) was suspected to have been severely beaten in custody. His family was notified on 26 Oct that he was in a coma and had been hospitalised, leading them to suspect that he was assaulted after meeting with his lawyer on 23 October 2019. The petitioner was first taken away and detained by the police on 27 August 2019, and looked fine when he met his lawyer. The police stopped his family from examining his body in hospital. He died later in hospital on 6 November 2019.

On 25 October 2019, the founder of a citizen anti-corruption website was placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) by the Pizhou County Public Security Bureau (Xuzhou, Jiangsu) with charges of 'illegal commercial operation,' accusing him of receiving fees for stability maintenance. He was transferred to criminal detention on 26 Nov, then to the Pizhou Detention Centre on 5 Dec under formal arrest, where he continued to be detained at the time of reporting on 22 Jan 2021.

On 25 October 2019, a detained Christian petitioner was transferred from the Zhenjiang city detention facility in Runzhou district (Jingkou, Zhenjiang, Jiangsu) and placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location near Beishan Reservoir in Jurong city, at the People's Armed Forces Department in Dantu District, and at the Weida Driving School in Jungkou district, during which they beat him up. He was then held there for four months without hot water for showering and he would often catch a cold because he had always been very ill. On 27 February 2020, he was transferred back to the Zhenjiang city detention facility.

On 25 October 2019, a woman human rights defender was taken by the police at the Liwan District Court (Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province) after she quarrelled with the security personnel while entering the court. She was held incommunicado for a week after getting into a physical confrontation with the police during security check before attending a trial. She was later confirmed to be arrested and would be probably charged later because she had bitten one of the policemen while she was taken. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 28 October 2019, three rights-defenders-cum-forced evictees from Pingnan county, Fujian were beaten by government-hired private security forces after a court hearing in Beijing, one of whom (the father) sustained six rib fractures. One of the female victims (the daughter) had been repeatedly targeted since winning multiple court cases against the government. After they were taken back to Pingnan, the daughter was charged with 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble,' and had since been detained at the Ningde City Detention Centre till the time of reporting on 14 Oct 2020.

On 29 October 2019, a petitioner was intercepted by a dozen government employees at Beijing West Station (Fengtai District, Beijing) and detained in a hotel on the Gulou West Street (Beijing). By the time of report, 1 November 2019, he was still detained.

Around 30 October 2019 (from 29 to 31 October 2019), a woman was trapped at the waiting room of the Shenyang North Station located between Shenhe District and Huanggu District (Shenyang City, Liaoning Province) for three days and reportedly beaten and threatened. She was stopped by a group of unknown people while she was about to take the train at the station on 29 Oct and was trapped after her wheelchair, luggage and other belongings were all taken away. The incident was possibly because of the upcoming national CCP meeting. She reported to the police but they refused to register the case.

On 31 October 2019, a Buddhist temple in Zhengzhou, Henan and its affilated nursing home were demolished by the local government on the grounds of 'illegally using the land' and 'holding religious activities without approval'. The temple's person-in-charge was also forcibly dragged out of the temple with her clothes ripped, and one of her eyes injured, after she asked the employees for documentation when they barged into the temple.

Around 31 October 2019 (end of month), a female petitioner from Fujian Province was beaten by government employees and government employed thugs in Beijing when she was on a trip in Beijing with her father. She was then taken back to Pingnan county (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province). There is no further report on this event.

On 1 November 2019, a female petitioner was handed over from Huangpu District detention centre in Shanghai to be detained at a black jailed named 'base 751' in Fengxian District, Shanghai. She was taken from the Huangpu District detention centre by government employed 'thugs'.

On 3 November 2019, a female petitioner from Shanghai was forcibly taken away by 12 Shanghai police officers in Beijing and sent back to Shanghai. The reason for the abduction was related to the China International Import Expo that was to be held in Shanghai soon. She was locked up in a resort with 5 personnel guarding her.

On 4 November 2019, a lawyer was beaten by police at a bus station in Tianhe District in Guangzhou City (Guangdong Province) after he refused to show his ID and got arrested. He reported that the police beat him in the car leaving several injuries on his body. He was released later on the same day but there was no reason for his arrest.

On 5 November 2019, a female petitioner from Suzhou City was taken by police and government workers in Shanghai when she was visiting during the China International Import Expo. They broke in her room in Shanghai and beat her. She was then taken to the Shanghai airport on 9 November after being detained at an unknown location without any food. She was sent back to Suzhou on 10 November.

On 6 November 2019, more than 10 construction workers employed by the government in Nantong City (Jiangsu Province) destroyed a house in Chongchuan District and beat the house owner and his mother when they tried to stop the workers. The house owner suffered multiple injuries on his body, and his mother was injured in her head and hospitalised.

On 6 November 2019, 10 government-hired workers beat up three fast food restaurant owners (the son, and his parents) from Nantong prefecture (Jiangsu) during an attempt to start construction work at their illegally demolished restaurant. They sustained injuries to their ribs and skull. It was their second government-related assault case since 2014.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 6 November 2019, a pro-Beijing Hong Kong lawmaker was attacked during a campaign trail in Tuen Mun District, Hong Kong by a man with knife. His assistant and himself were both injured and sent to the hospital. The attacker accused him of orchestrating the July 21 attacks on train passengers and others at the hands of white-clad thugs in Yuen Long district.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: DAB: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 6 November 2019, a district councillor from DAB's Yau Tsim Mong branch was attacked by an unidentified man with a wooden stick during the District Council election campaign in Yau Ma Tei, Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong).

On 6 November 2019, a man from Hebei Province was forcibly dragged off the bus in Beijing by government officials from the Fengnan District representative office in Beijing. He was reportedly sprayed with pepper water, handcuffed and beaten by the officials. He was later detained at the representative office for three and a half hours. He was then transferred to a detention centre and detained for 7 days. It was reported that the man had been demanding for a fair settlement for the demolition of his house by the Fengnan district government.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 14 November 2019, 20 to 30 unknown individuals indiscriminately attacked people with retractable batons and iron bars near the North District Town Hall, North District (New Territories, Hong Kong). They also destroyed the memorial walls. At least 4 people were injured. It was suspected that the assailants were off-duty police officers, but the police denied any connection. It was reported that, on the same day, multiple mob attacks took place in the district due to political differences sparked by the extradition bill. Later during the same day, police fired pepper spray and tear gases in the district as crowds gathered outside the Sheung Shui Centre shopping mall in the evening.

On 14 November 2019, dozens of policemen and personnel from religious affairs bureau and fire department in Pukou District (Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province) demolished a Three-Self church in the district which served nearly 1,000 believers. They forcibly entered the church around 4pm and dragged out the people who were meeting inside. Some believers refused to leave and got beaten. It was reported that multiple officially approved churches in Nanjing city had received orders to demolish their churches and transfer their members to larger churches so that the government can administer more easily.

On 16 November 2019, a pro-democracy district councillor candidate was beaten by two unknown individuals at his campaign booth at Sheung Shui in North District (New Territories, Hong Kong) around 6pm. He was injured on his head and arms and was sent to the hospital. It was reported that the assailants threatened to kill him if he got elected.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong); Former Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: Ming Pao; Radio Free Asia; HKFP; CRLW
NOTES: On 19 November 2019, the former chairman and lawmaker of the Democratic Party (Hong Kong) was followed by several unknown individuals in black clothes after he exited the Tin Hau MTR station in Wan Chai District (Hong Kong) at night and later attacked by those people in a nearby alley with rods. He suffered multiple injuries to his head, back and arms. The incident was reported to be among the several attacks against district councillor candidates and pro-democracy party members that happened in the context of the anti-ELAB movement in Hong Kong since June 2019.

On 20 November 2019, nearly 1,000 police and other government workers in Chuxiong City (Chuxiong Yi Autonomous, Yunnan City) set out to demolish the Mosque in the city that had lasted for nearly 80 years. They arrived in the morning, dragged out the people who were praying in the mosque, and managed to demolished the exterior wall, kitchen and toilet section of the estate. Some believers tried to stop the demolition. It was reported that many believers were beaten by government workers during the demolition, and a 80-year-old man was sent to the hospital for emergency treatment.

On 21 November 2019, two Tibetans were severely beaten by police while in detention in Dza-Mey Township in Shiqu County (Garze Tibetan Autonomous, Sichuan). They had been arrested the same day after scattering leaflets calling for Tibet's independence. After being detained for two days, they were transferred to a detention centre in Shiqu (Sershul) County

On 23 November 2019, an elderly female owner was abused during an undocumented forced demolition at the Taoist temple in Yanshi county (Luoyang, Henan) by over a dozen government officials and demolition workers. Four young men covered her head with clothes and dragged her down the hill until she lost consciousness. Her clothes were reportedly stained with blood from being dragged and then hospitalised for her wounds. The temple was eventually demolished and two disciplines were detained.

On 23 November 2019, a female petitioner was beaten by a police at the Chongqing City Petition Offices in Beijing in Fengtai District (Beijing). The police also erased all materials from her phone, including a video that she took during her transfer by the police.

On 28 November 2019, an activist from Xi'an City, Shaanxi Province was believed to have been taken away by the local police when he was visiting in Hunan Province and had since been held incommunado. The reasons for his detention were not known.

On 29 November 2019, two female petitioners were taken by 8-9 unidentified individuals into a blue van at Daxing District (Beijing) in the morning. One of them was beaten in the car, and the other were forcibly taken out of the car after some distance and beaten along the roadside in the same district. Four government officials from her hometown, Jiuhua Town (Rugao City, Jiangxi Province) arrived at the scene with another car and tried to bring her back to Jiangxi. She reported to the police. By the time of report on 29 November 2019, she was sent to a hospital in Beijing in the afternoon. The other petitioner went missing with the unidentified group. Her family later received a notice from the Huishan Branch of the Public Security Bureau that she had been detained for 10 days for violating surveillance residence regulations.

On 1 December 2019, the meeting venue of a church in Nubu Residential District, Lanxi City (Jinhua City, Zhejiang Province) was forcibly shut down by the government, on the grounds that it was not registered. The government personnel confiscated tables, chairs, pianos and tableware. When the congregation members tried to block the personnel from removing the items in the venue, they were beaten. It was reported that many people were bleeding and some sustained fractures. 5 male believers were later detained in a detention centre on 3 January 2002, on charges that they were 'disrupting public order'.

On 1 December 2019, more than 200 public security personnel and officials stormed into a house church meeting venue in Lanxi City (Jinhua City, Zhejiang Province), and ordered the congregation to stop gathering. When believers complained about the behaviour of the security personnel and officials, at least three believers were beaten by the authorities, including a young man, the mother of the young man, and the venue director. The church's donation box was also seized by the police, and the director and three believers were taken away to the local police station for questioning, and ordered to sign applications to join the state-run Three-Self Church. The entrance to the venue was also welded.

Around 7 December 2019, an activist in Shanxi sent a message that he was held in a mental hospital by government security forces, where he was forced to delete all his Tweets from his Twitter account. He has since lost contact, and his Twitter account had been shut down on 12 December 2019.

Around 8 December 2019 (during the 10 days from 3 December 2019), a retired female worker was severely beaten up by police while being detained in Taiyuan, Shanxi. She was arrested on 3 Dec for sharing Hong Kong protest videos online and detained for 10 days.

On 9 December 2019, a Tibetan Buddhist temple was demolished by local authorities in Horqin (Tongliao City, Inner Mongolia). The police used pepper spray to disperse the crowd when hundreds of local herders tried to stop the demolition.

On 10 December 2019, a detained political dissident (the webmaster of Esuweiji -- a group of doxxing websites focused on President Xi, CCP high officials, and their relatives) was transferred by the police force of Foshan prefecture to Residential Surveillance at a Designation Location (RSDL) amidst investigation and custody under the Maoming City Procuratorate (Guangdong) (coded to Maonan). He was held at Nanhai District Detention Centre in Foshan from 10 Dec until the end of his RSDL on 22 Jan 2020, during which he was crippled by torture and coerced into admitting charges. As reported on 20 June 2021, he was sent to a prison in Sihui, Guangdong where he was expected to serve until 2033.

As reproted on 11 December 2019, a citizen from Liaoning who had previously called for government reforms was taken away by Liaoning police from his home in Shenzhen, Guangdong province. His belongings such as computer were also confiscated. Police informed his family about the arrest but did not disclose the reason for it.

On 14 December 2019, a man under residential surveillance in a designated location in a hostel was transferred to Panjin Public Security Bureau in Xinglongtai district (Panjin, Liaoning), where he was beaten up for almost 36 hours before being sent back to the hostel. He was arrested for committing 'trap loan' fraud and detained at a hot spring hostel in the Dawa district of Panjin prefecture between 11 August 2019 and 24 January 2020. After the period, he was sent to a legal detention center since a court hearing was approaching.

On 16 December 2019, the mother of an activist was attacked in her home in Guangshan, Henan, by people hired by the local government. They attacked her with knives, and she sustained injuries in her tendons in both her arms. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

Around 16 December 2019 (month of), at least three Protestant Christian believers were assaulted by over 30 local government personnel during an operation to merge and shut down the Lu'nan Three-Self Church in Guannan county (Lianyungang, Jiangsu). They were thrown on the floor, pushed and shoved around. One elderly believer reportedly vomited and fainted, while another believer suffered a heart attack. It was reported that at least 142 Protestant churches (state-run Three-Self churches or unregistered house churches) were shut down in Lianyungang prefecture in the second half of 2019, as part of a six-month crackdown campaign in Jiangsu province.

On 18 December 2019, two activists from Chongqing City were taken away to a police station from Dongcheng District, Beijing and detained for no reason. After being detained for nearly 8 hours, both of them were taken to a 'black jail' by 7-8 people from the local public security bureau and were detained there until the next day.

On 20 December 2019, a petitioner from Rugao, Jiangxi was taken away by police forces in Tiananmen (Dongcheng, Beijing) after he had submitted litigation documents to the central government. He was sent back to Rugao and then locked up in a hotel room.

On 20 December 2019, the mother of a man who was prosecuted for 'illegal' possession of state secrets' was intercepted and beaten by four unidentified persons in front of her house in Chongqing Province. One of the men claimed to act on behalf of the Chinese government, though this has not been confirmed. The incident happened one day after she granted permission to travel to Beijing to testify at her son's trial. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 22 December 2019, a petitioner was forcibly removed from a police station in Rugao City, and held in a 'black jail' at a hotel in the same city for two days. He was violently punched and kicked by personnels from the Public Security Bureau. The petitioner had previously submitted a petition reporting on corruption within the Rugao City local government.

On 26 December 2019, a human rights lawyer from Yichang, Hubei was taken away by Shandong National Security Police from his friend's place in Beijing, and held incommunicado in state custody. Officials notified his lawyer on 10 Jan 2020 that he was taken into Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) for 'inciting subversion of state power.' The RSDL was later reported to have taken place in Yantai, Shandong, during which he was subjected to torture, including sleep and food deprivation. He was transferred to the Linshu County Detention Centre (Linyi, Shandong) at an unreported date. Three more human rights defenders from Fujian and Shandong were taken away by the Shandong police on 26 Dec, as part of their crackdown on a civic gathering in Xiamen on 13 Dec 2019.

On 26 December 2019, a human rights defender was taken away by Shandong National Security Police from his residence in Huli District (Xiamen City, Fujian Province). His family was informed by Huli police that he was held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location in relation to criminal charges. No legal document was provided by the police. His family was not sure if the arrest was related to his participation in the Xiamen meeting on 13 December. On the same day, three other people (including a human rights lawyer) were also taken away by Shandong police. The human rights defender has been set free on 19 June 2020.

On 26 December 2019, a human rights defender was taken away by Shandong National Security Police from his residence in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province. He was held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location. No legal document was provided by the police. On the same day, three other people (including a human rights lawyer) were also taken away by Shandong police. Their arrests were part of the crackdown following the civic gathering in Xiamen on 13th December 2019. The human rights defender has been set free on 19 June 2020.

On 26 December 2019, a human rights defender was taken away by Shandong National Security Police from his residence in Yantai City, Shandong Province.
