His wife received a notice saying that he was being held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location and that their houses would be searched. She said the arrest was related to his participation in the Xiamen meeting on 13 December. On the same day, two Fujian residents and a human rights lawyer in Beijing were also taken away by Shandong police. The human rights defender has been set free on 19 June 2020.

On 26 December 2019, a Christian Brother was at the Chengdu Intermediate People's Court in Wuhou District (Chengdu, Sichuan) for the trial of a reverend, when he was pushed down and attacked by a few plainclothes police. He was later taken away to the police station for questioning, on who is the leader of his church, and the reason for his appearance at the trial.

On 26 December 2019, a petitioner was intercepted by two police officers and illegally detained. The petitioner was visiting the Complaints Bureau of Wuhan City with his wife. No reason has been given for his detention.

Around 1 January 2020 (week of), a detained political dissident (the webmaster of Esuweiji -- a group of doxxing websites focused on President Xi, CPC high officials, and their relatives) was sexually assaulted by police officers during Residential Surveillance at a Designation Location (RSDL) in Foshan prefecture (Guangdong) (coded to Chancheng), where he had been transferred to since 10 Dec 2019 amidst investigation and custody originally under the Maoming Prefecture Procuratorate. He was groped, forced to take nude pictures, and had his private parts lit with cigarette lighter. He was then held at Nanhai District Detention Centre in Foshan until the end of his RSDL on 22 Jan 2020. During this time, the victims (including other underaged dissidents) were tortured to deter them from seeking legal representation, and to coerce them into admitting charges through handwritten confessions. His left shoulder was crippled, and records showed multiple hospitalisations due to beatings. He was first detained on 24 Aug 2019 for criminal internet activities, then officially charged on 30 Sep for proliferating misinformation. He was sentenced to 14 years of prison on 30 Dec 2020.

On 6 January 2020, two petitioners were taken by police forces while shopping in Wangfujing, Beijing. They were later taken to Qiluqing hotel (Haidan, Beijing) and has since been detained in the hotel.

On 9 January 2020, an activist was taken to Daxigou police station in (Yuzhong District, Chongqing) after stopping three unidentified men from kidnapping a lady (whom was later found to be another activist). When she requested for lunch at the police station, the police officers declined her request. She was subsequently violently dragged and detained in an iron cage for 7 hours. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 9 January 2020, a member of Holy Love Fellowship (and also a petitioner) was taken away by 'interceptors' at Beijing South Railway Station (Fengtai District, Beijing) and had since disappeared. She was on her way to attend a court hearing of another petitioner's lawsuit. It was also reported that she had been intercepted several times for her petition in Beijing and was previously placed under house arrest.

On 9 January 2020, two members of a Hong Kong-based volunteer group, which had previously provided medical support to protesters during one of the protest campaigns, reportedly went missing in Guangzhou (Guangdong, China). One of them was later released, while the other was still detained for an estimated 40 hours and had lost contact. The reasons for their detentions were unknown.

Around 12 January 2020 (between 1 January - 22 January), a female petitioner was summoned to the Dongjiang Police Station in Binhu district (Wuxi, Jiangsu) without legal reason. She was tortured on a tiger bench for eight hours. Police interrogated and threatened her to not interfere in a 'private dispute' between two named individuals. She was also beaten on the floor, and stepped on.

On 12 January 2020, a human rights lawyer from Shaanxi was taken away from his residence in Xi'an, Shaanxi by the Xi'an Public Security Bureau on the grounds of endangering national security. He was then transferred to an undisclosed location and held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) for ten days. He was reportedly fixed onto a tiger bench for the entire duration. The torture resulted in the loss of sensitivity in two of his fingers (as of 23 Oct). He was the fifth citizen-lawyer from the police crackdown on a 13 Dec 2019 civic gathering in Xiamen to face RSDL.

On 12 January 2020, a human rights activist from Hebei Province was forcibly dragged into a car by unidentified persons near the Beijing South Railway Station (Fengtai District, Beijing). The activist was subsequently detained for 15 days in her hometown of Julu County, before being transferred to a small hotel guarded by two people. It was also reported that on 4 February 2020, she was transferred and detained in a mental hospital. The activist had previously filed a petition for illegal land occupation. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 14 January 2020, a lawyer from Shaanxi Province was held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location for allegedly endangering national security. He was taken away by Xi'an Public Security Bureau on 12 January 2020. He had previously participated in the defense of many human rights cases.

On 15 January 2020, a petitioner was taken away by two 'interceptors' after he submitted a petition at the annual meetings of the National People's Congress (NPC) and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPC) in Shanghai. That evening, he was transferred to a detention centre in Pudong New Area, Shanghai and tortured on the grounds of 'provoking trouble'.

Around 16 January 2020 (month of), an Uyghur model and ex-convict was taken away by authorities in Foshan prefecture (Guangdong) and placed under 'compulsory measures' in Kuqa county (Aksu, Xinjiang), allegedly for assaulting health workers. Authorities stated that the transferral was part of a resettlement plan to help released prisoners, however evidence also showed them suggesting 'a few days of education at his local community' (an allegedly euphemism for the political re-education camps). Between January and February, he described spending 18 days shackled and hooded with over 50 others in a jail, then at an epidemic prevention centre. He went incommunicado in Mar 2020.

On 22 January 2020, three officers from the Dongjiang Police Station (Wuxi, Jiangsu) barged into the home of a female petitioner - who petitioned for wage arrears for the past eight years - residing in Jiangning district (Nanjing, Jiangsu). She was tortured for 26 hours. She was cuffed upon arrival and beaten on the floor till she was bruised and her teeth were knocked out. They interrogated her on a tiger bench, threatening to imprison her by association with an unnamed criminal suspect. She was sent to the Shifosi Detention Centre in Nanjing afterwards, where she was detained for another 10 days.

On 23 January 2020, a petitioner and her sister from Fuzhou, Fujian were intercepted by 'rogue gangsters' hired by the government at the Fuzhou Railway Station. Her sister had her mobile phone taken by the triad members and left on one of the roads in Xindian Town, Jin'an District. The sister later received a call from a staff member of a mental hospital that the petitioner had been brought to and detained in a mental hospital. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 23 January 2020, a female rights defender-cum-petitioner was abducted by 6-7 men onto a vehicle at Fuzhou South Railway Station Square in Cangshan district (Fuzhou, Fujian) when she was traveling to Beijing to submit a petition. After two months, her family learned that she was admitted to a psychiatric hospital, but they were forbidden to visit her. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 30 January 2020, four men and two women were attacked by 10 unidentified men for reasons unknown while they were working on the 'Lennon Wall' of Yuen Long MTR Station (coded as Hong Kong-Yuen Long). Some of the attackers held sticks and wore dark-coloured shirts, and fled after the attack. The six victims sustained injuries to their heads, eyes, hands and faces. After months of investigation, three assailants were arrested on 18 Nov 2020.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 2 February 2020, a man was beaten up with a sack pulled over him at a police station in Mei Foo, Sham Shui Po district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Sham Shui Po). He had been arrested for battery towards a police officer during a demonstration on the same day.

On 4 February 2020, several residents of Nanchang City, Jiangxi Province were accused by epidemic prevention personnel of not reporting their return from Wuhan City (the epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak). The residents were reportedly pushed to the ground and violently beaten by the epidemic prevention personnel. This was one of a number of similar incidents reported of epidemic prevention personnel using violence while performing their duties.

On 6 February 2020, a citizen journalist and lawyer from Qingdao who reported on the coronavirus epidemic in Wuhan prefecture (Hubei) (coded to Jiang'an) disappeared and lost contact for more than 24 hours. It was reported that he had been forcibly quarantined by the authorities for reporting on the situation of the coronavirus epidemic in Wuhan. Without any formal charges being brought against him so far, he had been incommunicado and held at an unknown location for nearly 14 months, until he was reported to have been reunited with family on 29 Mar 2021 with limited freedom of movement within a specified area.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 7 February 2020, an imprisoned man was beaten by prison guards at the Pik Uk Correction Institution in Sai Kung district (Hong Kong) for being one of six prisoners who sang the anti-ELAB anthem 'Glory to Hong Kong.' He was allegedly routinely slapped and hit during his eight-month sentence till 30 Jun 2020 for possessing a Molotov cocktail at the anti-government protests in Hong Kong last year.

On 9 February 2020, a citizen journalist and businessman who had reported about the coronavirus situation was taken away by plainclothes police from his residence in Wuhan prefecture (Hubei) (coded to Jiang'an) (coded to Jiang'an), and firefighters were seen prying open the door. He had been detained and released several times between 1-9 Feb for streaming and posting videos about the coronavirus condition and corpses inside Wuhan hospitals. His WeChat account was then shut down, and his conditions and whereabouts remained unknown as of 26 Dec 2020.

On 11 February 2020, a man running a small massage business in Ezhou City, Hebei Province was beaten by officials from the Industry and Commerce Bureau. He had attempted to explain to the officials that he would not be able to survive without the business, after the officials had ordered for the shop to be closed due to the coronavirus outbreak. The police was then called to the scene, who punched the man's face, kicked him and struck his back with a stick before taking him to the police station.

On 14 February 2020, three men were punched and kicked by epidemic prevention personnel stationed at a checkpoint in Henan Province. The three men were entering Henan Province from Hubei in a Hubei-registered vehicle and had an argument with the epidemic prevention personnel on their authority to seal roads and villages. The three men refused when they were forced to 'kneel down to apologize' and were beaten by the personnel. This was one of a number of similar incidents reported of epidemic prevention personnel using violence while performing their duties.

On 15 February 2020, a human rights defender was taken away by the police in Panyu District (Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province), on the grounds of subversion of state power. He was initially thought to be held incommunicado, but it was subsequently confirmed and reported on 7 March 2020 that he was held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL). His sister was told by Shandong police on 20 June 2020 that he has been officially arrested after being held in RSDL.

On 16 February 2020, a villager from Huizhai Village of Hualong District (Puyang City, Henan Province) was reportedly tied to a pole by epidemic prevention personnel for failing to wear a mask while going out. The incident prompted strong reactions from internet users, leading to the set up of a working group by local authorities to investigate the incident. It was later reported that the villager failed to wear a mask everyday or obey the personnel's advice, prompting 'more extreme measures' to be taken against them.

On 16 February 2020, three people were playing mahjong at their own home, when several epidemic prevention personnel and police officers barged into their home in Xiaogan City, Hunan and smashed the mahjong table. Several police officers also surrounded the three people and beat them up. This was one of several reports of abuse by law enforcement officers while performing their duties for the prevention of the coronavirus outbreak.

On 16 February 2020, a woman was transferred from the Haidian Public Security Sub-Bureau Case Processing Centre in Haidian district (Beijing) [coded as Beijing-Haidian] to an unknown location by five to six plainclothes and unidentified persons. She was placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) from 16 Feb to 19 Jun - under charges of inciting subversion of state power - during which she was subjected to sleep deprivation, blinding with light and forced to sit motionless in a fixed position for 8 hours a day. It was reported that the victim had worked on managing volunteers for the COVID-19 pandemic.

On 16 February 2020, a female social justice activist from Beijing was taken into custody by the Beijing authorities. She was held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL). The arrest was likely prompted by a tweet sent out by the activist on 24 January 2020, which was critical of the Chinese authorities' attempted coverup of the coronavirus outbreak. Some international media had also reported that her enforced disappearance might be related to the recent arbitrary detention of her partner, who is a prominent human rights lawyer. She confirmed on Twitter herself that she has been set free on 19 June 2020. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders][women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 26 February 2020, a citizen journalist was suspected to be taken away and held incommunicado by personnel from the Public Security Bureau in Wuhan City, Hubei Province. He had been in Wuhan reporting from the front line of the coronavirus outbreak, and was likely to be have been taken away by the authorities. He was livestreaming from his place of residence when there was a knock on his door, and his camera was abruptly cut off. This was part of an ongoing crackdown on people who had been reporting or sharing information about the coronavirus outbreak.

Around 1 March 2020 (beginning of month), a Uyghur singer was arrested in Qazanchi district of Yining city (Ili, Xinjiang) and detained incommunicado for watching a fictional Turkish historical TV series. The man's mother and sister were initially also arrested, but were released 15 days later. Six months after his arrest, police visited his home to gather clothes, which led relatives to believe he had been sentenced and transferred to prison, but the man's status is still unknown at the time of reporting on 11 November 2020.

On 2 March 2020, a Church of Almighty God member was tortured during her arrest in Hubei province to reveal information about her faith and the Church. Police officers cuffed her hands behind the tree, and sprayed hot liquid onto a mask that covered her face. When she was interrogated the next day, an officer hit her head with an iron key chain and slapped her on the cheek with an iron object.

On 2 March 2020, a Church of Almighty God member was tortured by the police after his arrest in Hubei province. Police officers covered the surveillance camera in the interrogation room, twisted his arms behind his back and beat him.

On 3 March 2020, a supermarket employee was beaten by a large number of personnel from the urban management bureau in Jianghan District (Wuhan City, Hubei Province). It was reported that the supermarket employee was distributing groceries in a community during the coronavirus outbreak, as part of a collaboration between the residents of the community and the supermarket. This was one of a number of similar incidents reported of law enforcement personnel using violence while performing their duties during this period.

On 6 March 2020, an independent documentary director and poet was taken away in Beijing, likely by the police from Haidan Police Station. As of 12 April 2020, he had been held incommunicado for 38 days at an undisclosed location under surveillance. His wife had attempted several times to communicate with him by passing letters through the police department. It was reported that he was working on a documentary on a detained Chinese activist when he was taken away on the grounds of 'Inciting subversion of state power'

On 10 March 2020, a Three-Self church in Xiazhuang Village, Dawu Township (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) was demolished by over 200 government personnel (including officials from the Religious Affairs Bureau) and police officers. All church belongings, worth tens of thousands of RMB, were also buried in the rubble. During the demolition, the person-in-charge of the church was also beaten by police officers, after he attempted to question the authorities on why the church was being demolished. The person-in-charge sustained two fractures in his ribs from the assault.

On 11 March 2020, more than 100 personnel from the local urban management bureau and excavators were dispatched to forcibly demolish houses in Zhaotong City, Yunnan Province. During the demolition, a large number of villagers broke through the epidemic prevention checkpoint to try and halt the demolition. A large number of urban management personnel violently pulled the villagers out of the cordoned area. 5 to 6 authorities reportedly beat up an old man, and some authorities used sticks to hit the bodies of villagers who rushed forward to help the old man. Some people were reportedly injured.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: CPC: Communist Party of China; Labour Group (China)
NOTES: On 12 March 2020, a property tycoon and member of the Beijing chapter of CPPCC (National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference) was reportedly detained and held incommunicado at a Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (the highest internal control institution of CCP) training facility in Beijing. He was reportedly detained for publishing an article online criticising the government's response to the coronavirus outbreak.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), a female member of the Church of Almighty God was arrested in Beijing and taken away to a local police station for interrogation. While in custody, she was forced to blaspheme God. She was then beaten and sprayed some liquid into her eyes by the police, who demanded her to disclose information about her church. She was released from the police station the next day.

On 18 March 2020, a villager was crushed to death by an excavator in Xiaqiao Village, Yangzhou City, Jiangsu Province by government officials, after attempting to block the demolition of his village. It was reported that the villagers have been fighting against the forced demolition of their village for more than a month. After the incident, the officials dispatched a large number of police officers to seal off the area, while aggrieved villagers demonstrated and placed more than 80 wreaths at the site. 1 man killed.

Around 23 March 2020 (week of), a prisoner in Xi'an prefecture (Shaanxi) (coded to Weiyang) was hospitalised for surgery while officials from the district- and prefecture-level courts and police stations forbade visitors. The prisoner, former director of a national botanical garden, had been imprisoned for theft, bribery and corruption -- allegedly false accusations pinned onto him by higher-ups as retaliation for a workplace dispute. In Apr 2020, his wife was allowed to see him, finding a wound on his scalp while he had fallen into a vegetative state. Authorities refused to grant access to any surveillance footage about the incident.

On 24 March 2020, the deputy mayor led more than 100 local government officials, urban management and law enforcement personnel to Houwangzhuang Village (Heze City, Shandong Province) to ask the villagers to sign a compensation agreement for the demolition of their village. Villagers refused to sign the agreement, stating that the town government had refused to disclose the state's land requisition policy and compensation standards, and that the compensation was too low. While the village leader was reasoning with the deputy mayor, an elderly man allegedly knocked into the deputy mayor, which infuriated the deputy mayor who then beat up the elderly man. Several other villagers and government personnel were involved in the ensuing scuffle. 3 women, 1 man and 1 teenager were reportedly injured. The injured elderly man was taken to a hospital for treatment, before being detained by the town government. He was released the next day.

On 25 March 2020, a female petitioner from Huangpu District, Shanghai was beaten by stability maintenance personnel at the Shanghai People's Government Office for Calls and Letters in Huangpu District (Shanghai). One of the personnel strangled the back of her neck, before dragging her towards a police car parked by the side of the road. The petitioner's head and face were slammed several times against the police car.

On 27 March 2020, a food delivery worker was pushed to the ground and beaten by several people from the Shenzhen Urban Management Bureau in Huaqiangbei Subdistrict (Shenzhen City, Guangdong Province). A passer-by who witnessed the incident attempted to reason with the urban management officials, but was instead beaten by them. At one point, a urban management official jumped up and kicked the passer-by to the ground, before a number of other officials surrounded and kicked the passer-by. It was reported that the food delivery worker, who was using an electric bicycle, had mistakenly driven onto the pavement.

On 29 March 2020, a photographer from Wuhan who had been working for a German television broadcasting company reportedly went missing in Wuhan, after he had been reporting on the coronavirus outbreak in the city. It was reported by several news publications that he was likely to have been taken away by the Chinese authorities for his coverage on the coronavirus. His enforced disappearance was the fourth incident of journalists who had been reportedly missing or detained by the Chinese authorities since February 2020 due to their coverage of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan.

On 30 March 2020, a university student in Shandong was reportedly held incommunicado, after publishing a video on his Twitter calling for Xi Jinping to step down. It was been reported by RFA that he had been taken for questioning by the local police, on suspicion of 'picking quarrels and stirring up trouble'. In the video, he criticised the Communist Party of China for its land reform, Cultural Revolution, persecution of Falun Gong believers, Tibetans, Hong Kong and Xinjiang among other issues. He had previously been administratively detained for five days for speaking out against the government. At the time of reporting on 1 April 2020, he had remained uncontactable.

Around 4 April 2020 (from 2 to 6 April 2020), government officials subjected a Catholic priest to a torture method called 'exhausting an eagle' (a type of sleep deprivation method), and shone strong lights in his eyes 24 hours a day over 4 days. The priest was taken away by more than a dozen government officials from Saiqi Town (Fu'an City, Fujian Province) on 2 April and detained in a remote secret interrogation facility, where he was confined in a small room. He was only released after he was forced to sign the application to join the state-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Around 4 April 2020 (from 1 - 8 April), a human rights lawyer was tied to a tiger bench while interrogated by authorities during Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) (coded to Laishan) in Yantai prefecture (Shandong), where he had been held for at least three months. The authorities were reported to be from the Yantai Public Security Bureau. He was also subject to sleep deprivation for at least 73 days during RSDL.

On 4 April 2020, a villager from Dingliu Village was taken away by the police in Gaoqu Township, Sanyuan County (Xianyang City, Shaanxi Province) (coded at Sanyuan County), for attempting to reason with a construction company that their construction project had affected the discharge of sewage from the village. The construction company later called the police and the villager was taken away for interrogation on the grounds of attempting to 'block construction'. After a few hours later at the police station, the villager was sent to the intensive care unit of a hospital because he was comatose from severe trauma. While the police alleged that the villager inflicted the injuries upon himself, his two daughters claimed they heard sounds of someone getting beaten from across the police station, and strongly believed that he was attacked by the police during his detention. The daughters were also pinned to the ground by police officers at the police station, and one of them sustained injuries to her hand, face and waist. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 7 April 2020, a brother and a sister were taken away by police in Linfen city, Shanxi (coded to Yaodu), for picking quarrels and provoking trouble, and obstructing official duties. They were placed under residential surveillance in a designated location before being officially arrested and transferred to Linfen Yaodu Detention Center. In October 2021, the brother was sentenced to 5 years in prison as he refused to be evicted from his home.

On 7 April 2020, a pro-democracy dissident was transferred from a prison in Qingjiang Town (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province) to a hotel in an undisclosed location, after serving his 10-year jail term. It was reported that while the authorities had used the pretext of 'quarantine' for coronavirus, the dissident remained uncontactable and had yet been released at the time of reporting.

On 13 April 2020, a female human rights activist was taken away from her place of residence in Yubei District (Chongqing) by the police to the police station in the same district. During her detention which lasted more than 20 hours, she was handcuffed and shackled on a 'tiger bench' (a type of bench used to torture people). The activist had been arrested or harassed by the authorities several times on the grounds of 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble', for petitioning after her house had been forcibly demolished. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 15 April 2020, a plaintiff was prevented from going through the security check at the Wuhou District Courts (Chengdu, Sichuan) for a scheduled court case, then beaten by several court police officers after an argument with the bailiff. He was hit in the head, chest and ribs, sustaining injuries including soft tissue damage and a loosened jaw.

On 19 April 2020, three people working in Beijing were taken away 'in secret' by public security personnel of the Sub-Bureau of Chaoyang district, Beijing. One was released on bail after being detained for 25 days, while two were detained under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL), on the grounds of 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble' and 'harbouring criminals.' It was reported their detention was likely due to the open source archive that they run, Duandianxing, which stores deleted articles from mainstream and social media. The website was also archiving coronavirus-related articles, including censored materials. On 12 June, they were officially charged and transferred to Chaoyang Detention Centre.

On 1 May 2020, a tax evasion suspect was assaulted by four task force officers while being placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) by the Dejiang County Public Security Bureau at Wenzhou Hotel in Dejiang County (Guiyang, Guizhou). The abuse resulted in a loss of hearing in the victim's left ear. Throughout his detention, he was forced to sit on a small, uneven plastic stool in a fixed posture for 18-19 hours a day, and was subjected to sleep deprivation, silent treatment, and other forms of harassment. The victim developed diseases related to his prostate, lumbar spine and sciatic nerve. He was later transferred to criminal detention on 2 Jul 2020.

On 1 May 2020, a female petitioner from Xinwu District in Jiangsu Province was beaten by two local government officials in Xinwu District (Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province). She was reportedly injured in the head and ear. It was reported that she had been illegally detained and beaten for more than 400 days in total, for petitioning against the demolition of her house.

On 3 May 2020, 200 officials from the National Security and Religious Affairs Bureau raided a Protestant house church in Xinglin Residential District (Xiamen City, Fujian Province) and attempted to forcibly ban the believers from congregating. There was pushing and shoving between the officials and the believers, and during the scuffles, many believers were injured, including a believer who sustained slight fractures in his ribs. 9 believers were taken away by the officials for interrogation.

Around 5 May 2020 (as reported), a woman was forcibly taken away by government officials from her place of residence in Zhuzhou City, Hunan Province and admitted into a psychiatric hospital. This came six months after she had been release from the psychiatric hospital. It was unclear if she had been administered antipsychotic drugs after being admitted to the hospital this time around. She was previously forcibly admitted into a psychiatric hospital in 2018 for splashing ink on a portrait of Xi Jinping.

On 6 May 2020, 8 petitioners from Shanghai were taken away by stability maintenance personnel at Hongqiao Railway Station in Minhang District (Shanghai) and sent on 'mandatory vacation'. The identities of all the petitioners (except for one) were unconfirmed at the time of reporting. It was reported that they were planning to petition during the annual parliamentary sessions in Beijing which will commence on 21 May 2020.

On 6 May 2020, a petitioner who was staying in Beijing ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions (due to start on 21 May 2020) was taken away in Beijing by interceptors from his hometown. According to his friend, he had reportedly been taken to Majialou 'black jail'. This was part of the increased security measures imposed by authorities in Beijing ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions.

On 8 May 2020, a female petitioner was taken away by four local 'interceptors' while she was working at the World Flower Garden in Fengtai District (Beijing). She was forcibly repatriated to Liaoning, where she was detained in a hotel for 14 days, on the grounds of being quarantined as part of the prevention measures during the COVID-19 pandemic. It was reported that ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to be held on 21 May 2020, security measures had been stepped up targeting petitioners and activists.

On 9 May 2020, a petitioner from Chongqing was taken away by stability maintenance personnel from Chongqing in front of his rental house in Beijing. He remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 12 May 2020. This was reported that his enforced disappearance was likely due to the upcoming annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020.

On 11 May 2020, a female petitioner from Chongqing was taken away by security maintenance personnel at Chongqing North Railway Station (Yubei district), where she was bound for Beijing. She had since remained uncontactable and her friend reported that she was likely to have been taken away due to the upcoming annual parliamentary sessions due to start on 21 May 2020.

On 11 May 2020, a petitioner from Changshou District, Chongqing was taken away from his home in Changshou District (Chongqing) by stability maintenance personnel and epidemic prevention personnel for compulsory quarantine, under the pretext that he had visited Hubei Province which is an epidemic region. He was headed to Beijing earlier in the day, but was forcibly taken off the train at Hubei Enshi Railway Station by the train attendant and police. It was reported that the authorities had been using 'compulsory quarantine' this year ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions this year to stop people from petitioning.

On 11 May 2020, a female petitioner was forced to sit on a 'tiger bench' for more than 20 hours while being detained at a police station in Quan'an Town (Neijiang City, Sichuan Province). She had been forcibly taken away by the deputy secretary of Quan'an Town while she was submitting a petition at the Sichuan Provincial Letters and Calls Bureau the day before. She was released in the morning of 12 May 2020.

On 15 May 2020, a petitioner from Fujian was taken away by private security personnel hired by Jin'an district government outside the Letters and Visits Bureau of People's Government of Fujian Province in Gulou District (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province). He was then detained in a 'black jail' in Jin'an district. It was reported that he was forcibly taken away to prevent him from petitioning during the annual parliamentary sessions due to start on 21 May 2020.

On 15 May 2020, a female citizen journalist was taken away from her rental house in Nanshixia Village, Gu'an County (Langfang City, Hebei Province) by the police. She was then handed over to the local government officials and detained in a hotel until the end of the annual parliamentary sessions. After the detention, she was repatriated to her rental house for treatment of her back pain.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), a female Church of the Almighty God member was arrested in Jiangsu province (coded to Xuanwu) and tortured during police interrogation. They placed a hood sprayed with chili water on her head, and wiped her lips, nostrils and eyes directly with a paper towel soaked in chili water.

On 16 May 2020, a female petitioner from Longxing Town, Chongqing was forcibly taken away by two women (including a police officer) in Beijing and then detained at a hotel in Beijing. She was later sent to a hospital in Shijiazhuang, Hebei for treatment due to serious discomfort in her body (cause of discomfort not specified). This was part of the intensified security measures ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020 to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2012-); Labour Group (China); Militia (Pro-Government)
NOTES: Around 16 May 2020 (month of), the local government hired workers, security guards, and local thugs to demolish trellises in the vegetable gardens larger than 50 acres in over 20 villages in Shuitou Town, Pingyang County (Wenzhou City, Zhejiang Province). Three elderly farmers were beaten when they tried to prevent the removal of trellises. One was slapped on his face until his mouth was bleeding, while another one was pushed to the ground with a guard pressing on his neck, and the third farmer had urine poured over his head.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), a female petitioner from Chengdu was intercepted in Xicheng district (Beijing) by officials from her hometown, ahead of the Lianghui annual parliamentary session, then transferred to a temporary extralegal detention center in Fangshan district. It was reported that she was then repatriated to Chengdu, where she was held under soft detention until the annual parliamentary session concluded.

On 17 May 2020, a petitioner was taken away from Beijing by personnel from the Yunyang county and Panshi town governments and repatriated to Yunyang County (Chongqing), where he was interrogated while seated on a 'tiger bench' for 24 hours. He was later transferred to a hotel in Yunyang County to be held for 14 days, on the grounds that he must be under surveillance during the annual parliamentary sessions.

On 17 May 2020, a female petitioner was taken away by the police while she was on a bus in Beijing. She was reportedly detained in a 'black jail' in Fengtai District and has yet to be released at the time of reporting on 21 May 2020. This was part of the intensified security measures ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020 to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition.

On 17 May 2020, three human rights activists (including two women) from Chongqing were taken away by unidentified persons in Chaoyang District (Beijing), and remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 21 May 2020. They were likely to have been taken away as part of the intensified security measures ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020 to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 18 May 2020, a man residing in Chongqing was taken away near his place of residence by four stability maintenance personnel from Dadukou District. He remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 21 May 2020. He was likely to have been taken away as part of the intensified security measures ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020 to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition.

On 18 May 2020, a female human rights activist was beaten by a group of unidentified black-clad people at one of the Beijing representative offices in Beijing. She was forcibly taken away by the group and remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 21 May 2020. She was likely to have been taken away as part of the intensified security measures ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020 to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 18 May 2020, 20 government-led personnel and police officers demolished a Buddhist temple in Shucheng county (Anhui) after declaring it a dilapidated building, and reportedly beat up two believers (including a female believer and a monk) who asked for documented approval of the demolition and tried to film the scene. Those who posted video footage of the act and submitted a petition to higher authorities were ordered to stop.

On 19 May 2020, an Uyghur man from Toutunhe district (Urumqi, Xinjiang) was detained the second time for an unknown reason and taken to camp, where he was held until 30 August 2020. Between 2017 and 2018 he had been detained for trying to travel to Australia with his wife.

On 19 May 2020, a female petitioner was beaten by the secretary of the local community, after being taken away to the community office in Xinwu District (Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province). It was reported that her mobile phone was taken away, and she vomited blood after being assaulted. She had since been placed under surveillance at her place of residence, which was guarded by 4 to 5 people. It was reported that she had been illegally detained and beaten for more than 400 days in total, for petitioning against the demolition of her house.

Around 19 May 2020 (from 15 to 24 May 2020), a female petitioner was reportedly assaulted by government officials while being 'quarantined' for 14 days on the grounds of COVID-19 prevention in Longhu Town, Fengdu County (Chongqing) when she claimed that they were breaking the law. It was reported that her clothes were torn after the assault. She was first taken away from Gu'an County (Langfang City, Hebei Province) by the secretary of the Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission of Fengdu and forcibly repatriated. The government official stated that she was 'unstable' and denied her of food for many times during her detention. The petitioner managed to escape detention on 24 May 2020.

On 19 May 2020, a female petitioner was intercepted by personnel from Neijiang city government, the police station, and village staff members while she was waiting for the train to Beijing at Chengdu North Railway Station at Xindu District (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province). She was taken away to a police station in Quan'an Town (Neijiang, Sichuan), where she was forced to sit on a 'tiger bench'. She was released the next day.

On 19 May 2020, a female petitioner was transferred from the Public Security Bureau of Yunyang County (Chongqing Municipality) by government officials to a hotel at the edge of Yunyang county for 'compulsory quarantine' for 14 days, possibly as a pretext to prevent her from travelling to Beijing during the annual parliamentary sessions to petition. She had been forcibly taken away from a hotel in Zhuozhou City (Baoding City, Hebei Province) by government officials from Yunyang County on 17 May 2020, before she was repatriated to Yunyang and subsequently detained in the basement of the Public Security Bureau of Yunyang County on 18 May 2020.

On 20 May 2020, two mother-and-son petitioners were taken away after seeking help at the Dongcheng district police station (Beijing) and transferred to Jiujingzhuang Relief Center 'black jail'. On the same night, they were escorted by 20-30 officers and around 10 hired triad members to Yongdingmen Hotel (the Changzhou Liaison Office in Beijing), then on 21 May to Jiutouniao Hotel, and on 22 May to Gaoqing gas station in Zibo, Shandong. On 22 May, they returned to Changzhou and were locked in Zhengzhang Hotel 'black jail' until the mother was forcibly admitted to a local psychiatric ward on 3 June, and her son remained until his release on 22 July. From 20 May to 22 July, they were reportedly beaten and robbed by officers, triad members, government officials, and put in abusive situations harmful to their health and personal hygiene.

Around 20 May 2020 (between 20 May - 21 May), a female petitioner and her mother were forcibly taken away and beaten by unidentified persons at Tianjin Binhai Airport in Dongli District, Tianjin. They were then driven and left behind near Cuiyu Road in Yubei District (Chonqing) at 9pm on 21 May 2020. One of the women reported that both of them were beaten by the unidentified persons during the journey. It was reported that they were likely targeted as part of the intensified security measures ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020 to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

On 20 May 2020, a human rights activist from Chongqing was arrested in Tiananmen, Dongcheng District (Beijing). He was then taken away to the police station for interrogation, before being transferred to Jiujingzhuang 'black jail' to be detained for several hours. Staff members from the Chongqing Municipal People's Government Office in Beijing later arrived at Jiujingzhuang and escorted the activist back to Chongqing where he continued to be detained at an unreported location.

On 21 May 2020, a female petitioner was taken away from Deping Road Station in Pudong District (Shanghai) by two employees of a private security company. She was then detained in a farmhouse in Qianwei Village, Chongming District (Shanghai), where she was abused by the two private security personnel, in retaliation of the petitioner filing a court case and a complaint with the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection against the subdistrict office last year. She managed to escape the next day by jumping off the window from the third floor while the guards were asleep.  [women targeted: civilians - other/no affiliation]

On 21 May 2020, a petitioner from Nan'an District, Chongqing was forcibly taken away in Beijing by government officials from the representative office in Beijing. He was repatriated to Nan'an District where he was quarantined at a CCP party school in the district for 14 days, despite being tested negative for COVID-19. The petitioner believed that he had been forced to quarantine as part of the intensified security measures ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020 to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition.

Around 21 May 2020, at the start of the annual parliamentary sessions in China, the parents of a petitioner from Nanjing were taken away by government officials in Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province and detained in a black jail in Qixia District (Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province). After the petitioner tried several times to request for the release of his parents, he jumped off the Nanjing Yangtze Bridge.

On 21 May 2020, a female petitioner was forcibly taken away from her uncle's home located 60 kilometres away from Zhangjiaguang City (Suzhou City, Jiangsu Province) by 8 to 9 police officers. She was dragged and beaten by several police officers and auxiliary police while being taken away to a car, causing many bruises on her body. She was later briefly detained in Chengbei subdistrict office, before she was taken back home for compulsory isolation for 14 days due to COVID-19, on the grounds that she had left Zhangjiaguang City.

On 22 May 2020, a woman from Chongqing was forcibly taken away from a police station at Tiananmen Square in Dongcheng District (Beijing), by a person claiming to be from the Beijing Liaison Office of Chongqing Provincial Government (although the person did not produce documents to prove this). She was subsequently taken to Gaojiachang 'black jail'. After being tested negative for COVID-19, she was repatriated to her hometown in Liangping District, Chongqing.

On 22 May 2020, a female member of The Church of the Almighty God (CAG) was taken away by four police officers in Guang'an City, Sichuan Province to a police station. She was then locked to a 'tiger bench' for nine hours. It was reported that a total of 11 CAG believers in Guang'an City were arrested on the same day.

On 22 May 2020, a prisoner was held in solitary refinement and exposed to chlorine dioxide (highly concentrated disinfectant) at Songyuan Prison in Songyuan prefecture (Jilin) for questioning the guards after his five-minute phone call allowance with family was reduced to two. The gas left him out of breath and nearly comatose, and reportedly took him ten days to recover after the gas exposure.

On 22 May 2020, a married couple was forcibly intercepted by a police officer, while they were waiting for the Beijing-bound train at Zhengzhou Railway Station in Erqi District (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province). A group of police officers and government personnel from the community and subdistrict offices appeared right after they were intercepted. They were then taken away to and detained at a hotel, likely to prevent them from travelling to Beijing to petition. This was part of the intensified security measures ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions scheduled to start on 21 May 2020 to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition.

On 22 May 2020, a female human rights activist was taken away by the police in Beijing and forcibly repatriated to Chongqing on 23 May 2020. She was then detained in a farmhouse in Nan'an District (Chongqing), on the grounds of being quarantined as part of the COVID-19 prevention measures. This was likely part of the intensified security measures during the annual parliamentary sessions which started on 21 May 2020, to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 24 May 2020, a female petitioner was forcibly taken away in Beijing by officials from the Beijing Liaison Office of Wuxi Municipality. She was repatriated to Wuxi and was reportedly assaulted by the officials, where her clothes were torn. She had been in Beijing to petition against the demolition of her ancestral house in Chaqiao, Anzhen. This was part of the intensified security measures during the annual parliamentary sessions which started on 21 May 2020, to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition.

On 24 May 2020, a female petitioner was taken away from Beijing by personnel from the Xiaogan municipal government and Nanyuan police station and forcibly repatriated to Hubei Province. She had remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 27 May 2020. It was reported that she was likely taken away as part of the intensified security measures during the annual parliamentary sessions which started on 21 May 2020, to prevent people from travelling to Beijing to petition.

On 24 May 2020, two female petitioners from Wuxi, Jiangsu were forcibly taken away from Tiananmen Square in Dongcheng District (Beijing) by Beijing police. They were taken to the police station, before being transferred to a hotel and detained by officials from the Beijing Liaison Office of Jiangsu Province.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: DAB: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong
NOTES: On 24 May 2020, an unidentified man was reportedly harassing and insulting volunteers who were stationed at a street booth opposite Fortune Plaza in Tai Po District (Hong Kong), campaigning and collecting signatures in support of the legislation of the national security law. The man also smudged the campaign materials at the street booth. He later rode away on his bicycle and crashed into the chairperson of the DAB Tai Po Branch, causing injuries in the chairperson's right foot. It was not clear if the man deliberately crashed his bicycle into the DAB Branch chairperson. At another street booth in the same district, two black-clad people assaulted volunteers stationed at Tai Wo Estate. The volunteers sustained injuries in their head and were sent to the hospital.

On 27 May 2020, a Christian from Hubei was taken away from his residence in Fangshan District (Beijing) by 10 police and personnel from the Hubei representative office in Beijing. His wife stated that the police confirmed that he had been taken away by the public security bureau but his whereabouts remained unknown at the time of reporting on 28 May 2020. It was suspected that he might have been taken away ahead of the 31st anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square Protests, as he had previously been involved in commemorative events for the Tiananmen Square Protests with his wife.

On 27 May 2020, a retired agricultural worker-cum-petitioner from Heilongjiang was arrested by the police in Dongcheng district (Beijing) and then handed over to three workers employed by his former company. They forcibly repatriated him to Heilongjiang province by car, and illegally restrained him to a room in a public bathhouse for 15 days on the grounds of 'coronavirus quarantine.' After 15 days on 11 June, a police officer instead informed the victim that he would be detained for 'a case he filed for in Beijing.' He was still detained at the time of reporting on 29 Oct 2020.

On 28 May 2020, a Christian from the Early Rain Covenant Church was assaulted in Chengdu City, Sichuan Province by the local police, subdistrict and community officers as he was preparing to move out to Caojiaxiang in another district of the city. Another Christian accompanying him was also beaten with the government personnel. The believer was evicted from his residence on 27 May 2020 in his hometown of Pingchang County after being administratively detained for 15 days. It was reported that this was part of a broader campaign by the authorities to evict believers of Early Rain Covenant Church from their jurisdiction and Chengdu.

On 28 May 2020, a female street vendor was attacked by urban management officers in Banchang Town (Tongren City, Guizhou Province). It was reported that the urban management personnel were driving vendors off the streets when the female vendor got into an altercation with the officers. A officer then kicked the vendor onto the ground, before picking up a broom to continue beating the vendor. The vendor had since filed a claim with the urban management department, but was told that the officers acted in self-defence after she attacked the officers first.

On 30 May 2020, a rights defender was taken by police officers from his home in Changsha prefecture (Hunan). It was later suspected that police officers from Yunnan province (specifically the Public Security Sub-Bureau of Yuelu district, Changsha prefecture) were responsible for the arrest, as a source close to the police informed that the rights defender was transferred to Yunnan the next day (31 May) under claims of involvement with 'an armed group.' As of 6 July 2020, his family had not received any official correspondences (verbal or written) from the police regarding his whereabouts or the charges brought against him.

On 30 May 2020, a poet was taken to an unknown location after 40 police officers captured him from his home in Chuxiong Yi Autonomous Prefecture (Yunnan). Several of the poet's relatives were interrogated and others were placed under forced house arrest. He was charged with 'inciting subversion of state power' this time after being targeted repeatedly for the online political commentaries he uploaded between 2003 to 2014. While the police informed his family that he is under criminal detention, the police were unable to state where he was held, and his whereabouts remained unknown at the time of reporting on 14 September 2020.

On 31 May 2020, a Beijing resident was taken away likely from his place of residence in Beijing by the police, after he participated in a global online commemorative event ahead of the 31st anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square Protests. He had since remained uncontactable and his whereabouts are unknown at the time of reporting on 4 June 2020.

Around 31 May 2020 (end of month), a former veteran (who was also a petitioner) was taken away by a large number of officials (including the chief) from the Weibin District Public Security Bureau from Xi'an City, Shaanxi Province. He remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 31 May 2020. He had just escaped around the same time after being illegally detained by the Baoji government since November 2018. It was reported that he had been illegally detained by the local government seven times for his petitioning.

On 1 June 2020, a human rights activist from Zhuzhou City was taken away from Zhuzhou City, Hunan Province by public security personnel. He was then taken on a 'mandatory vacation' in Jiangxi and Anhui Province. During this period, he was placed under 24-hour surveillance by public security personnel and not allowed to post about the June 4th Tiananmen Square Protests on the internet. He was sent back home on 5 June 2020 after the anniversary of the June 4th Tiananmen Square Protests was over.

On 3 June 2020, a man was summoned to the Guangyi Police Station in Liangxi District (Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province). He had since remained uncontactable for almost 24 hours at the time of reporting. It was reported that this was part of the intensified security measures ahead of the 31st anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square Protests.

On 3 June 2020, at least three petitioners were taken away from Beibei District (Chongqing) by 20-30 unidentified persons hired by the Chongqing stability maintenance office. While they were being dragged into the car, the group of unidentified persons assaulted several petitioners. The petitioners were subsequently taken to Daxigou police station in Chongqing.

On 3 June 2020, a political prisoner-cum-human rights defender from Yichang, Hubei was taken away from his temporary residence in Yichang City, Hubei Province by public security personnel. His wife later confirmed that he had been taken on a 'mandatory vacation', to prevent him from 'causing trouble' ahead of the 31st anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square Protests. After he was taken away, all the posts on his Twitter account were erased. The public security personnel stated that they would send him back to his place of residence on 11 June 2020.

On 3 June 2020, a female citizen journalist was taken away from Beijing by personnel from the public security bureau of Dingzhou City, Hebei. She remains uncontactable at the time of reporting on 4 June 2020. She had recently been detained at a hotel on 15 May 2020 to prevent her from reporting during the annual parliamentary sessions.

On 3 June 2020, a woman from Nankai District (Tianjin) reportedly went missing, believed to have been taken away by the local police. She remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 4 June 2020. She had recently been restricted by the local police for several hours on 19 May 2020 ahead of the annual parliamentary sessions.

On 7 June 2020, a female human rights defender was placed in heavy handcuffs and foot cuffs while being detained at the Qingyuan Detention Centre in Qingyuan prefecture (Guangdong). The two cuffs were chained to one another, forcing her into a curled position for a period of six days. She was also beaten up by other detainees who were held in her cell, though the reasons for the assault were not reported. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 10 June 2020, a middle-aged pro-establishment man attacked a female online media reporter at Citygate, Tung Chung in Islands District (Hong Kong). The reporter was at the scene filming two demonstrators who held a 'Lunch with You' rally at the mall, when the man, who was allegedly unhappy with the demonstration, attacked the reporter. The man was arrested by the police, while the reporter was sent to the hospital for treatment.

On 11 June 2020, an owner of a flower shop was smashed in his head with a flower pot by an officer from the urban management bureau in Quyang County (Baoding City, Hebei Province). It was reported that the flower shop was operating illegally and occupying a road. While the owner and his wife were attempting to move their goods away, the urban management officers continued to seize their properties. The aggrieved owner shouted at the urban management personnel, before an officer picked up a flower pot and smashed it in the owner's head. His wife also sustained some abrasions in her leg during the scuffles. It was reported that the urban management personnel had been mobilised for law enforcement against merchants who were operating illegally on the roads, as part of the county government's campaign to beautify the appearance of the county.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: DAB: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong; Former Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 12 June 2020, a man (who was later identified to be a former community officer of DAB) attacked an Epoch Times reporter and members of the public with a knife at Kwun Tong Station (Yue Man Square) Minibus Terminus in Kwun Tong District (Hong Kong). Several people stepped forward to subdue the assailant after the attack, and the man was arrested. One man who sustained injuries was sent to the hospital for treatment. The incident took place when people had gathered around a street booth that had been set up in commemoration of the first anniversary of the first major police clashes during the anti-ELAB demonstration on 12 June 2019.

On 12 June 2020, more than 100 personnel from the Religious Affairs Bureau, Public Security Bureau and demolition workers raided a church in Zhengzhou City, Henan Province. They removed church properties, subdued believers and demolished the church. It was reported that one believer was beaten up by the officials during the demolition.

On 15 June 2020, a woman disappeared incommunicado for at least 25 days (as of 11 July) after visiting the Dashiba Police Station in Jiangbei district (Chongqing) to collect her living subsidies. She was assaulted by officers from the same police station on 19 November 2018, and became disabled as a result.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Muslim Group (China); Prisoners (China); Uyghur Ethnic Group (China)
NOTES: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), a Uyghur imam and sheikh from Guma county died in a prison facility in Hotan prefecture (Xinjiang) (coded to Hotan City), as reported in an article about religious persecutions and deaths in detention in Xinjiang. He had been arrested by authorities in Feb 2016 without any official reason given.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), a Tibetan student from Guinan (Mangra) county, Qinghai was detained while working as a researcher at Tibet University, Lhasa city proper (Lhasa, Tibet) with whereabouts unknown at the time of reporting on 8 Dec 2020. He was thought to be arrested for circulating booklets containing unauthorized views of Tibet's political history.

On 17 June 2020, the wife and brother of a poet reportedly went missing after they visited the police station in Donggua Town (Chuxiong Yi Autonomous, Yunnan Province). The brother had since remained uncontactable for 9 days at the time of reporting on 25 Jun. The wife had been uncontactable till the time of reporting on 16 Sep 2020, when it was revealed that she was formally charged on 24 Jul with inciting subversion of state power. The poet had recently been arrested by the police on 31 May 2020, and was formally charged (same charge) on 3 Jul.

On 19 June 2020, a tax evasion suspect was beaten in the head, shoulders and legs by four task force officers during a car ride from the Dejiang County Public Security Bureau (Guiyang, Guizhou), where he was taken for an interrogation session while being held under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) since 1 May. It was reported that intimidation tactics like this happened every time he was taken for an interrogation session at the Bureau. He was later transferred to criminal detention on 2 Jul 2020.

On 19 June 2020, a human rights activist and his wife were taken away from a railway station in Xi County (Xinyang City, Henan Province) by the county's party committee secretary, deputy mayor and director of the public security bureau. They were then detained in a 'black jail'. They were released 13 hours after they were first intercepted at the railway station. It was reported that they had been intercepted by the government officials while making their way to Xinyang Intermediate People's Court to hear a court case.

Around 21 June 2020 (between 21 - 22 June), a rights defender from Xuzhou, Jiangsu was taken away by public security officers in Fengtai district (Beijing) and escorted back to Dandong, Liaoning, where he was quarantined in a hotel for 14 days on the grounds of 'preventive/quarantine measures in relation to the coronavirus.' He was tied up with metal wires during the detention, and was reportedly incommunicado for 20 days.

On 21 June 2020, a petitioner went missing after making a phone call from the Haizijiao Police Station in Daxing District (Beijing). He had since remained uncontactable at the time of reporting on 22 June 2020. It was reported that the petitioner had been petitioning for 17 years, and was recently in Beijing to petition during the annual parliamentary sessions.

On 22 June 2020, a woman was cuffed and beaten by the police of Sanmiaoqian Township Police Station while visiting farmlands confiscated by the village government in Wan'an village, Sanmiaoqian township of Poyang county (Shangrao, Jiangxi). She sustained bruises and fractures to her skull and ribs.

SOURCE: BBC News; CRLW; South China Morning Post; Amnesty International; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Around 25 June 2020 (from 19 - 28 June), an academic scholar and lawyer - also founder of the New Citizens' Movement and Open Constitution Initiative, and human rights defender - was tortured with sleep and food deprivation for ten days during Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) in Beijing after formal charges on 19 June for 'inciting subversion of state power.' He was first taken away on 15 Feb in Panyu district, Guangzhou city (Guangdong) by police officers who searched his friend's home in the name of a 'coronavirus check.' After the RSDL, he was transferred to the Linshu County Detention Centre (Linyi, Shandong) and was held there for over half a year at the time of reporting on 21 Jan 2021.

On 28 June 2020, a female petitioner with high paraplegia was forcibly repatriated by the village secretary and three 'assistants' from the Dazhong subdistrict office in Dazhong Subdistrict, Dafeng District (Yancheng City, Jiangsu Province), after requesting the office to pay the agreed medical expenses as soon as possible. After the petitioner refused to get into the car, her clothes and pants were reportedly removed by the 'assistants', although the details for removing her clothes were not mentioned in the report.

On 28 June 2020, a pro-democracy 'yellow shop' owner and his wife were assaulted by 4 unidentified assailants near their restaurant on Sai Yu Street, Yuen Long District (Hong Kong). It was reported that he was pulled out of his car and beaten by the four assailants. The owner sustained scratches to his face and neck, whilst his wife sustained injuries to her right eye and arms. The owner stated that while he was unsure of the reasons behind the attack, he suspected that it may be politically motivated.

On 28 June 2020, a woman and her 9-year-old son were attacked by two men near a street booth for pro-Beijing group 'Protect Hong Kong Alliance' on a footbridge connected to the Long Ping MTR station in Yuen Long District (Hong Kong), due to conflicting political opinions. The assault took place after the woman had written a swear word on the petition form, before dozens of supporters (of the national security law) surrounded her and hit her in the head. Her son was reportedly punched in his eye after confronting the assailants. It was reported that around 20 white-clad people holding rod-like objects had gathered at the MTR station throughout the afternoon.

On 29 June 2020, a forced evictee was beaten up by seven to eight eviction operation personnel at his home in Qujiang district (Xi'an, Shaanxi) (coded at Xi'an City) then held at a 'black jail' for a day. When he returned, they had demolished his house, looted four vehicles worth of belongings, a mortgage agreement and proof of his hospital stays and medical diagnosis.

Around 5 July 2020 (beginning of month), a Uyghur student was arrested in Karamay city (Xinjiang) and sent to a re-education camp. He was later formally arrested on 16 October 2020. The official reason for his arrest is for inciting ethnic hatred and discrimination, but other sources suggest that the contents of his phone may also have been an influencing factor.

On 6 July 2020, an restaurant employee was assaulted by two unemployed men at the restaurant in Tsim Sha Tsui, Yau Tsim Mong district (Hong Kong) with glass bottles and hard objects. The restaurant was one of seven outlets of well-known pro-democracy local restaurant/cafe chain Lung Mun Cafe, whose owner announced on 30 June that they official quit the informal pro-democracy business alliance Yellow Economic Circle (established during the anti-ELAB protests to support pro-democracy shops and businesses). The victim was hospitalised due to bleeding and injuries to his neck and arms.

On 7 July 2020, a female petitioner was intercepted by officers from Jinhua Police Station on her way to the Urban Administrative and Law Enforcement Bureau in Guta district (Jinzhou, Liaoning), then forcibly sent to the psychiatric ward in Kangning Mental Hospital. It was the fourth time she was sent to Kangning as per orders by high-level law enforcement authorities.

On 7 July 2020, church members were attacked and beaten by security guards in Yongfu village (Wenzhou, Zhejiang) when officials from Yongjia county (Wenzhou, Zhejiang) led a 100-personnel demolition operation (mainly private security guards) to remove crosses from two Protestant venues, including a Three-Self Church and a house church.

On 9 July 2020, local government officials beat up two civilians and hostel owners at their ancestral home-converted-hostel in Pingyao county (Jinzhong, Shanxi) and took them to the police station, then evacuated all customers and locked the building. This followed a county-level forced demolition document that was signed on 3 July. The affected properties were given a 15-day grace period to turn in their houses and property rights. This operation was unannounced, and there were reportedly over 210 households (including 30 ancestral homes) that were confiscated overnight.

On 12 July 2020, at least 500 private security guards and 60 police officers led a land eviction operation in Beiliwang village of Chang'an district (Xi'an, Shaanxi) under the leadership of the chief of Qinyu Police Station. When villagers arrived on the scene, they were manhandled by the private security guards while police officers assisted by arresting eight of them. Later, both security guards and police officers assaulted and injured the villagers. Three villagers were hospitalised, and those arrested were still incommunicado as reported on 22 July 2020.

Around 13 July 2020 (month of), a female Church of Almighty God member from Jiangxi province (coded to Honggutan) was locked in a wooden cage after being arrested by the police. She was confined to the wooden cage for 24 hours a day, and was subject to sleep deprivation. The torture lasted 15 days, and left her with rheumatism.

Around 16 July 2020 (month of), a Church of the Almighty God member was arrested in Jiangsu province (coded to Xuanwu) and tortured during police interrogation. An officer poked him with an electric baton, aiming twice for his genitals, and shocking his thigh. He was also ordered to stare at a strong light.

On 22 July 2020, a married Christian couple publishers were placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL) by the police in Gaoling city (Xian, Shaanxi) for publishing and selling Christian publications. On 23 October 2020, they were officially arrested and detained at two detention centers. On 19 August 2021, they were sentenced to seven years in prison.

On 23 July 2020, two men assaulted a pro-democracy cafe owner with a screwdriver at his own cafe on Sai Yu Street, Yuen Long District (Hong Kong). This was the second of two attacks on the owner and his family since 28 June, and was suspected to be politically motivated as the shop itself was well regarded as affiliated with pro-democracy business alliance Yellow Economic Circle. The owner was hospitalised with bleeding and injuries to his head.

On 27 July 2020, a preacher from a Three-Self church was taken away by the police from Fengtai county (Huainan, Anhui). She and her out-of-town husband (who was escorted back to the county) were held at an undisclosed location. Authorities targeted the church when the new preacher was unwilling to preach as required by the government. [size=no report]

SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 28 July 2020, residents were severely injured and assaulted with tear gas by forced eviction personnel and armed thugs during an unannounced demolition operation at Xitai village in Huairou district (Beijing). Around 2700 personnel were reportedly present, and the demolition was conducted over a week. It was reported that the Jiuduhe government ordered the demolition.

On 28 July 2020, more than 30 Public Security Bureau officers were dispatched to a 70-people service at a Sola Fide house church in Nanbu county (Nanchong, Sichuan), and arrested about 50 congregation members and a pastor. They confiscated all religious texts and several electronic appliances, and tore down the cross before shutting down the site. The pastor was kicked several times when he resisted his arrest and tried to reason with the police. Some were released the same day, while others were detained from 4 to 15 days.

On 1 August 2020, a human rights defender from Chongqing was strangled by the chief of Yuejin Village Police Station (Dadukou, Chongqing) during a black-jail detention at Yanzhao Hotel in Baoding prefecture (Hebei). Earlier in the day, he was intercepted by the chief and 12 of his subordinates at Shijiazhuang station while aboard train Z4 traveling to Beijing. Many rights defenders traveling to Beijing, specifically from Chongqing, had reportedly become government targets in the first week of August.

On 1 August 2020, a human rights defender and her son were stopped and assaulted in their local residential area in Yubei district (Chongqing) by a group of plainclothes officers from Huixing Police Station. While her son was hospitalised, the rights defender was taken away in a police car and placed under 10 days of administrative detention. She was preparing to submit an administrative complaint case in Beijing, and was amongst several rights defenders from Chongqing who had reportedly become government targets in the first week of August.

Around 1 August 2020 (beginning of month), at least 15 members of The Church of Almighty God (CAG) were arrested by the police from Wuyi county (Jinhua, Zhejiang). Three of them were sent to 'forced indoctrination' at Beiling Mountain Villa. It was reported that some hotels, leisure and entertainment centers across China are often used as 'education centers', where the government secretly detains and 'transforms' religious believers and dissidents.

On 2 August 2020, a female rights defender-cum-forced evictee from Nan'an district, Chongqing was taken from Shijiazhuang prefecture (Hebei) by an unidentified group of people while aboard train Z4 traveling to Beijing. She was held at Yanzhao Hotel in Baoding prefecture (Hebei) as of 4 Aug under the order of Shijiazhuang government orders, and was one of several Chongqing petitioners who were intercepted on the train that day. Many rights defenders traveling to Beijing, specifically from Chongqing, had reportedly become government targets in the first week of August. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 2 August 2020, a female rights defender-cum-forced evictee from Rugao, Jiangsu was intercepted by the police at Beidaihe Train Station in Beidaihe district (Qinhuangdao, Hebei), and transferred to two hotels (Yarun Hotel then Hairi Jingguan Hotel) where she was finally restricted in a form of 'black jail.' She had been intercepted and attacked multiple times in the past 6 years, and was one of several civilians prevented from entering the Baidaihe district during an annual summer high-level CPC conference (the 'Beidaihe conference'). [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 3 August 2020, a female rights defender from Jiangbei, Chongqing was assaulted by government-hired personnel during a black-jail detention at Shijiazhuang Hotel in Shijiazhuang, Hebei. Many rights defenders traveling to Beijing, specifically from Chongqing, had reportedly become government targets in the first week of August. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 4 August 2020, a female petitioner (and employee of farmland management enterprise) was assaulted at the Public Security Bureau in Xushui district (Baoding, Hebei) after her arrest. She was kicked, tripped, slapped, and her clothes were torn. She was one of 39 protesters arrested following a series of attacks and demonstrations related to land rights activism that day. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 8 August 2020, a female petitioner from Jiangbei district, Chongqing was taken to Jiujingzhuang 'black jail' in Fengtai district after she was intercepted on the streets of Beijing. Local stability maintenance officials escorted her back to North Chongqing by train Z49 the next day. The incident was reported to be part of a series of interception and detentions to prevent politically-motivated travels to Beijing during the Beidaihe convention in Qinhuangdao prefecture (Hebei).

On 8 August 2020, a female petitioner from Chongqing was sent to Jiujingzhuang 'black jail' in Fengtai district after being taken away by the police at Beijing Railway Station in Dongcheng District (Beijing). The incident was reported to be part of a series of interception and detentions to prevent politically-motivated travels to Beijing during the Beidaihe convention in Qinhuangdao prefecture (Hebei). [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 10 August 2020, a construction worker was injured after law enforcement officials from the Urban Management Department of Dingyuan county (Chuzhou, Anhui) repeatedly struck the platform he was standing on, induced instability and eventual collapse. He was further assaulted by the group after falling onto the floor. Several passers-by and shopfronts were hit.

On 10 August 2020, a citizen was beaten up in a car by two urban management officials in Changchun prefecture (Jilin) after he remarked on the sight of the two of them overthrowing a merchant's deep-fried dough stick wok on the road. He was hospitalised and suffered from soft tissue damage and broken ribs.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Farmers (China); Prisoners (China); Tibetan Ethnic Group (China); Women (China)
NOTES: Around 14 August 2020 (month of), a female Tibetan herder-cum-detainee was hospitalized in Biru (Driru) county (Nagqu, Tibet) amidst her detention, ''badly bruised'' and unable to speak. She was first taken into custody in June along with her cousin, both for sending religious books to India and having a history of promoting Tibetan culture, language and identity. She died two days after her hospitalization on 16 August 2020.
On 14 August 2020, four urban management officers pushed and assaulted an elderly female vegetable vendor on the streets of Kaifeng prefecture (Henan) during a row about street vending activities.

SOURCE: Reuters; DW; Radio Free Asia; Liveuamap
NOTES: On 14 August 2020, an Australian female citizen and financial journalist (born in China) for CGTN (the English-language channel of CCTV) was arrested in Beijing municipality and placed under Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location (RSDL). Australian authorities learnt of her arrest on the same day. It was then suspected that the arrest could be related to her public comments about China's handling of the coronavirus pandemic. Six months later, the Australian foreign ministry stated that charges of 'illegal disclosure of national secrets overseas' on 5 Feb 2021.

Around 15 August 2020 (month of), the priest of Yongshan Miaozu (Miao ethnic group) Church and his parents were taken away by the police in Zhaotong prefecture (Yunnan) and held in secret detention.
